PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Faulkner moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to government business order of the day No. 8 (Native Title Amendment Bill 1997).

We have a situation where community expectation about the Native Title Amendment Bill debate is at fever pitch. What occurred last night is that at last reluctantly the government brought on the bill to commence the second reading debate on a no quorums, no division basis. A time last night which was suggested by the opposition to conclude that second reading debate was utilised by the government to commence it. So the bill came on for debate last night.

Of course what is happening here is that the government is trying to use this very transparent device of the second reading speech for the native title legislation bill to clean up its own legislation program.
Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senators on my right will have an opportunity to participate.

—This is a very cynical use of the government's legislation program because I do not believe for one minute that the government would be able to hold government senators here in Canberra after the conclusion of the Wik debate. They know that and that is why they are not willing to bring the debate on.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian community as one wants this debate to come on. Senators should read the papers this morning and look at what the advertisements are saying. They want to bring on the debate and they are asking the Senate to deal with it. Yet the government steadfastly refuses to bring this matter on for debate.

Mr Howard said it all. He was the one who put the demands to the Senate earlier and for some time he has been saying, `Bring the debate on. Let the Senate get on with the debate.' But the government will not do so. It only managed a small part of the second reading debate to be conducted last night, which is a time when the Senate does not ordinarily sit. Senators of course know, but perhaps in the general community it is not well known, that the Senate does not sit beyond 8 o'clock on a Tuesday night. Special arrangements were made to allow that debate to commence.

We had three hours of debate on the Native Title Amendment Bill and three hours after the debate commences, the government is proposing not to continue it. This is possibly the most important piece of legislation that this parliament will be considering. That is indefensible. It is absolutely unjustified for the government to say, `We will commence the debate, but we have no intention of continuing it.'

There are many senators who want to make a contribution on the second reading—and that is right and proper—including a very significant number from the government. That is absolutely justified. If you do not conclude that second reading debate, then of course the committee stage almost certainly cannot commence this week.

That is what the government is saying. It is a deliberate and transparent attempt and device to ensure, using the vehicle of the Native Title Amendment Bill , that the balance of the government's legislation program goes through.

The spin doctors of government are up there in the gallery saying, `There is an agreement not to bring this debate on.' That is categorically untrue. The Labor opposition had argued that that debate should commence at 12.30 p.m. on Monday. The government refused to bring the debate on and what we are saying now clearly and definitively is, continue the debate that was started last night; the community demands nothing less.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Just briefly, I think the real contrast of good faith was the way in which the Labor Party dealt with the Mabo legislation. Instead of bringing it on several weeks before the end of the session, they dealt with their whole program and brought Mabo on on the last day. Then basically, with the support of the Democrats and others, had the Senate continue to sit to almost Christmas to finish it.

SPEECH.PARA: The contrast is the way in which we have handled this matter. We have brought it on a couple of weeks before the end of the session. We sat last night sensibly to get on with the second reading debate. We are happy to sit tonight to get on with the second reading debate. We are happy to sit tomorrow night. We are happy to sit on Friday. We will sit every night next week. If necessary, we will come back and sit the following week.

TALK.START.PARA: —We asked to sit on Monday morning, and they said they would not sit.
—They will not sit. As Senator Campbell reminds me, we offered to sit on Monday morning to get on with this debate, and Labor said no.
—You know that's not true.
—It is true. We offered to sit Monday morning; Labor said no.

—Order! Stop the clock. There are far too many interjections. In this part of the debate there are five‐minute opportunities for people to speak, and they should be able to have that opportunity to present their case.
—I have already called them to order, prior to your coming into the chamber, Senator Ray.

—Of course, the Labor Party is seeking to destroy the balance of the government's program for this session. There are important bills with starting dates and which must be passed this session. We know that it will be impossible to bring those bills on after completion of the Wik debate. That is why sensible practice is to finish those critical bills—only the critical bills—use the evenings to get through some of the second reading debates on Wik to get the process started and then get on with the committee stage of Wik.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many bills on the Notice Paper that the government has voluntarily removed because of the importance of Wik and the small number of bills that remain. But they have to be dealt with. We are happy to leave the ones that do not have to be dealt with until next year. What is left is just the completion of the sugar bill, on which the debate has been part heard. It has been suggested to me that there is about an hour to go. It has been suggested that the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Parenting and Other Measures) Bill 1997 —a critically important bill—has about an hour to go as well. We would have liked to have got on with the youth allowance bill, but we have deferred that to next year because of the pressures of the program.

We believe the states grants legislation can be dealt with in about 15 minutes. The last one is the migration bill, on which other parties in this place have already foreshadowed we are going to be defeated. So an expeditious debate could be facilitated and the vote taken. It has to be voted on, however, because the existing migration agents scheme comes to an end at the beginning of the next session. In other words, there is not time to deal with this legislation before the existing scheme ceases. That is why it has to be dealt with at this time.

We have about three hours of debate, using sensible debate approaches. It could be completed this morning, and then we are free to get on with Wik. If we get some time opportunities next week, then we would like to fit into those time spaces messages that are coming back on a couple of bills.

The four bills—the sugar bill and the three other ones—need to be completed this session. The only way they are going to be completed—as Labor knows; it is interested in wrecking it—is if they are dealt with this morning. That is why we are bringing them on. There has been no secret about that. The Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Campbell) informed Labor at our last meeting that we had to finish these bills and it was our intention to proceed to finish these bills. It is sensible practice. It is sensible programming. I urge the Senate to get on with these debates and get them out of the way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —This action of the government shows that the government has no commitment to pastoralists, no commitment to Aborigines and no commitment to the parliament. It follows the actions of yesterday; constantly this government bypasses parliament at every opportunity they get. They do not want to debate anything in this parliament. They want to sit in a corner by themselves and make the decisions without any scrutiny. That is the problem with this government.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen it with the debate about sugar, which they dodged for months and which they brought into the House of Representatives by tabling a customs proposal which prevented this parliament from having any real part in the debate about the sugar tariff. That is because they did not want a debate on something which was flying in the face of an electoral promise they made. In the same way, having raised the expectation of the community and given to the community an opportunity to be involved, they said to them, `Go away, you are making too much noise. We do not like what you are saying.' This is the problem.
Government senators interjecting—
Senator Abetz interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Abetz and other senators will cease interjecting.

—I am interested in what Senator Faulkner has said because he is right: the government is going around telling everybody that there was an agreement that this is what should happen. The Australian Democrats understand that the Wik debate should have been the primary and the only matter for consideration during these two weeks. There was no agreement. The only agreement the government ever have is with themselves. They sit in a corner and talk to themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: I will tell you what the Australian people believe: not only should they sit in a corner but also they should have dunce caps on because of their inability to come to this parliament and present business in a way in which we can deal with it—in fact, withdrawing the most important legislation that this government has put to the parliament in the whole of its term.

I was interested to find that finally this government was able to find somebody, in a sanitised advertisement yesterday, to support them on this—the Business Council of Australia. What I think the government really is afraid of is the fact that yesterday thousands of people—represented by over 100,000 hands—said to the government, `You are wrong.'

That is the kind of debate and the kind of opposition that this government cannot cope with. But the people out there spoke yesterday, and the people's representatives in this place want to continue this debate today. The people have spoken and they will not be silenced by this government. The Democrats will support the Labor Party on this suspension of standing orders because that is what the people of Australia want to happen, and that is the only way we can treat this matter with the importance that it deserves. I will say again: this government has no commitment to pastoralists; this government has no commitment to Aborigines; and, most of all, this government has no commitment to the parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens (WA) quite clearly stated on the record last night that we believe this bill should be withdrawn. It is clear that the government has not given its amendments to anybody to look at. We are dealing with an extremely important bill for Australia and its society, and we have not seen the government's amendments. If the government feels that it is necessary to spend more time working on its amendments, what we will be seeing is a new proposed bill.

BREAK.PARA: I think the Senate has time this week to finish the government's program because, quite frankly, if what we are being presented with is a new bill, we should be doing what the Greens and a growing number of people in the community have been saying: `Withdraw the bill. Go back and talk to indigenous Australians. Find out what you are doing wrong in terms of the process. Start talking to those people more fully. Provide information to those people who have been led to believe that it is necessary for them to go into legal conflict when, in fact, that is not necessary. Start providing real information to the constituents.' That is what is necessary. If we have a situation where we finish the rest of the program and the government withdraws the bill, we can all go home.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, you'll be going to Kyoto—you're not going home.

—I would love to go home. The last thing I want to do is spend time having to go and speak to the Australian community when the government will not on the issue of greenhouse. I would love to go home rather than having to do that. However, I am happy to support the suspension of standing orders because I think the way this issue has been put together and the way the government is manipulating the process and not consulting—in fact, it will be presenting us with an entirely different bill with zero consultation with the people whom it will most affect—is a national shame. I will be supporting the suspension of standing orders to debate this very important issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill made a rather dissembling speech this morning when he said, `The government always made clear it wanted to get this amount of the program through.' That part is true. What he was not able to say was that this side of the chamber was signed up to that. If we were, we would have progressed this, we would have finalised it and we would have kept our word.

SPEECH.PARA: Twice in the period 1995-96 I was part of negotiations with the coalition to get a minimal amount of legislation through the parliament. In the process we jettisoned scores of bills. Twice in that period the coalition scabbed on its word, and we did not even get the minimalist position. When Senator Hill comes in today and says, `We should get this amount of legislation through,' he cannot even point to an agreement with the Labor Party, the Democrats or the Greens that we had signed up to.

It is quite clear from the way the Wik debate is going that there will be amendments moved in this chamber. They will be amendments that will require all the drafting skill of the clerks and everyone else. By the time they are transmitted to the House of Representatives, and by the time they are considered there and a message comes back, this chamber will have to wait around for a day to a day and a half.

When precise calculations were given by Senator Hill today that it will only take X amount of time to do one bill and Y to do others, we could have quite easily done that at the end of the session. But we feel let down. It was our understanding that the Wik debate would start at 12.30 p.m. on Monday, and it did not. It was one of the reasons we encouraged the Tuesday night sitting on a no division, no pairs basis to conclude the second reading debate. So we feel doubly let down.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is Kim Carr in all this? I thought he was Manager of Opposition Business.
—He is actually very sick at the moment. I do not really think he should be subject to debate, because this happens to us all from time to time.

SPEECH.PARA: There is one silver lining in all of this that I enjoy: that is, Senator Hill and Senator Campbell are humiliating the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), and that always brings me a bit of joy. Ten days ago the Prime Minister issued a big statement—a big BS. He called on the Senate to get on with the Wik legislation. He demanded that this chamber address the Wik legislation. This could not be cheap populism by the Prime Minister. This could not be a Prime Minister that would ever appeal to prejudice and to cheap point scoring. He must have genuinely wanted this chamber to get on with it. He would not have just put out such a statement to puff up his chest and use us as a whipping horse, would he? No, he would not have.

Senator Ellison acknowledges that the Prime Minister would never do that. Of course not. So how do those opposite reconcile their action with his statements of 10 days ago? He has called upon this chamber to get on with Wik, to debate Wik and to have it resolved in one form or another. This group of coalition senators is totally defying the Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, ha ha!

—Senator Abetz laughs. I wonder why the Prime Minister has not been on the phone about this issue. He has had time to get on the phone from Vancouver to tell the Manager of Government Business to apologise. He has been able to make that particular phone call. He has picked up all his faxes on the opinion polls of the last two days, we know that. Surely he has had time to pick up the phone and make one phone call to the Manager of Government Business yet again and say, `Get on with debating Wik because it is surely more important than the other seven items of business that you want to have precedence over.' But you will not bring it on.

SPEECH.PARA: It is no use talking about intransigence in this chamber. This coalition government has been given more days, more hours and more opportunities to debate business than has been accorded any government in the last 15 years. The average of government business as a percentage time of the Senate is constantly on the rise. The opposition has been responsible in restricting the amount of MPIs and urgency motions to give the government the opportunity to get its legislative program through.

But the Prime Minister has demanded that we get on with Wik. The only response we have had from the government and Senator Hill is that these other items on the agenda—the customs, social security and migration legislation—should all have priority. The only conclusion we can draw from this is that, the moment this chamber finishes debate on Wik, the irresponsible anarchists opposite want to make a run for home because they regard running for home as more important than these seven items of legislation. If they are serious, they would stay here after Wik and debate them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond briefly to a couple of points that I think do need to be made clear. Firstly, the coalition has always made its position clear during the last number of weeks in negotiations about how to handle a heavy legislative program, including the so‐called Wik debate which will, as we now know, include the debate in committee stage of some 600 amendments; I am sure that is some sort of record for a piece of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been discussions about how to facilitate that committee stage debate in an effective way between the minister responsible and people on the other side of the chamber. But there is a recognition that, even with the best goodwill and the best organisation in terms of preparation of running sheets and grouping of amendments and so forth, it will be a long and complex debate. One indication given privately to the Special Minister of State (Senator Minchin) was of the order of 50 hours just in the committee stage.

The coalition did make it clear from the outset that we would try to whittle down the core program that we needed to get through by the end of this year. I must acknowledge what Senator Ray says, and it is a point that Senator Margetts made in private meetings and also in the chamber recently, that there may be an opportunity to do some pieces of legislation while messages are going backwards and forwards between the Senate and that other place. The coalition will be seeking to do that.

We have whittled down the list now to include only those items on the Notice Paper today, that is, the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill, the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Parenting and Other Measures) Bill, the States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill and the migration bills. We think that those items, if we can get on with them, can be handled almost entirely this morning, and that has always been our intention. It was made quite clear to the opposition that that was the government's intention.

We have compromised by dropping other items off and I indicate to the Senate now that the coalition government will seek to bring on those other matters that are on the Notice Paper—specifically, the Productivity Commission Bill, the workplace relations amendment message and the legislative instruments message—to be dealt with if there is a capability of doing so should there be a hiatus when there is a message going back to the House of Representatives in relation to the Native Title Amendment Bill. They are the four items we seek to deal with. We have always made that clear to the Manager of Opposition Business. I think it is fair to say that the opposition never agreed.

They also did not agree to one other item which would have facilitated exactly what Senator Robert Ray said. When we sought the extra sitting week we also sought to have an open‐ended adjournment so that we could facilitate the completion of these items and the native title bill, so that when we got to the end of the session there was not an automatic adjournment of the Senate that was outside the control of the government. We wanted an assurance there and we were denied that; we could not get agreement on that either. That was our part of the contract and the opposition refused to agree to that, and that should be put on the record. That discussion about the adjournment question comes from the letters that were tabled and incorporated, I think by Senator Faulkner, earlier this week.

Senator Ray has drawn the Senate's attention to the failure of the Senate to deal with some items of the former government's legislative program in the dying days of the last sittings in 1995. It contrasts somewhat with the assurances that Senator Hill, then the Leader of the Opposition, gave to Senator Faulkner, then the Manager of Government Business, in relation to the completion of the former government's program in 1995.

TALK.START.PARA: —All assurances which Senator Hill broke.
—Senator Hill did not break them. In 1993 the government did get its entire program. On 8 December 1993 Senator Faulkner said:

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of discussions amongst honourable senators, and in view of a number of undertakings given to me by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) on behalf of the opposition in regard to the legislation program for the remainder of these sittings, the government will not be proceeding with government business notice of motion No. 1. I inform the Senate that I will be proposing that the routine of business for the remainder of this session will include agreed provisions to ensure that, firstly, general business time tomorrow and—
The bottom line is that the government got every single piece of legislation that was agreed in 1993 and the then opposition facilitated the debate of native title. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —We are really debating the suspension of standing orders. I want just to say that, by and large, I am not supporting it at this stage, but I did agree and suggest that we do sit extra times on Wik, and that seems now to be becoming accepted right around the chamber. I am happy about that but, in regard to the items of business the government has got at the present moment, one of the indications given by the Leader of the Government was that the migration legislation agents bills will not take long because he believes that they are going to bite the dust anyhow if the Senate does not support them. If that is his belief I would happily go along with that, but I have been considering these matters carefully and have not made up my mind on them. I expect that that particular measure will take a considerable amount of time—far more than you think it will.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very important issue. A service for accurate information on immigration is not only a service but a right. Whether that right will be catered for by the privatisation of migration agents is another question, as is whether voluntary agencies such as the Victorian Immigration Advice and Rights Centre and the IARC in Sydney will get funding or have to rely on the beneficence of the migrants agents institute.

These questions need to be considered very thoroughly. I do not think that we can do that in five minutes. I do believe that, if we find when we come to the migration agents legis lation that it is to go on for some considerable time, it might be better if we come back to the native title bill and deal with the matter at a later stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for this debate has concluded.

PARA.TAB: That the motion (Senator Faulkner's ) be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I was in full flight yesterday when time defeated me. But at the time I was talking about the fact that the mantra of international competitiveness has been used to deny everything from environmental protection to native title, industrial awards and basic human rights. So, on balance, I will not support the government on this issue. If it can be excised through the ALP's amendment, I will consider voting for the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 . If not, there is nothing in this bill that commends strong support. I would be happy to support the other elements of the bill should the government wish to bring them back at another time, but I will not support it in its current state.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to say explicitly that, because of the way the Senate numbers appear to play out, it seems that the decision has been given to the National Party senators. If this tariff goes ahead, it will be only because the Nationals have voted for it. If they even abstain, the vote will go the other way and the tariff will remain. The National Party senators have crossed the floor twice in my term in the Senate, and I know they can do it.

The question is, `What are their priorities?' I understand this is entirely their decision. Everyone else has looked into the issue as they have seen it. The fate of the sugar issue rests squarely now with the National Party and they will have to deal with their constituency as they see fit. I guess they are going to have to justify their decisions to their constituencies as well as to their fellow colleagues. That is the issue as I see it. Unless the bill is substantially different from what it is now, it will not get the vote of the Greens (WA).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —The Howard government promised the sugar industry at the last election that it would not remove the tariff. There has been debate about that point already. It is clear that it has broken that promise. The government relied on the view of industry leadership to justify the abolition of the tariff. But, frankly, that leadership was put in a very tough position. It was given a choice of a single desk selling arrangement or the tariff. In other words, it was put in a position where it was being used—pressured—to give the government the excuse to break its promise.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no clear evidence to support the assertion that such a trade-off was required. It should be clear from the evidence that was put before the Senate inquiry into the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 that rank and file canegrowers are very much of a different view—very much indeed. That is the clear evidence that was put to the inquiry. Rank and file canegrowers want this government to honour its election promise. We even had the member for Kennedy, Mr Katter, present a submission to the inquiry acknowledging that this action was in breach of a clear election promise and that the canegrowers in his electorate wanted the promise kept. Those canegrowers want a single desk marketing structure to be maintained and they also want the tariff to be left in place. They do not want to trade one for the other, nor should they.

This is not, on the other hand, an action that is required to meet our international trade obligations. We are way ahead on that score. No-one can be critical of us on that score if indeed we maintain the $55 a tonne sugar tariff. So this is a matter of ideological obsession on the part of the drys within the Howard cabinet in the Liberal government. It is also about the National Party leadership being done over once again. Those National Party senators opposite will have to wear that decision in their electorates once again. It is clear Mr Katter from Kennedy is aware of that, because he has distanced himself from the decision of the government.

Unfortunately Senator Boswell, the Leader of the National Party in the Senate, came in here yesterday to seek to support the government's decision and to attack the position taken by Senator Woodley on behalf of the Democrats. I must say that my interpretation of the way Senator Boswell presented his points yesterday led me to the view that he would have been much more comfortable had he been standing across in Senator Woodley's place and taking Senator Woodley's position on this matter. Clearly he was uncomfortable with the fact that on this issue he is not carrying out the wishes of the electors who support the National Party in Queensland, in particular the sugar industry.

He had to introduce a host of other factors to seek to downplay the relevance of the Democrats' position to rural industries. He could not play them on the issue because clearly he was playing them on the issue against the interests of his own electors. Estimates which have been put to the Senate inquiry into this bill put the cost of the Howard government's action in removing the tariff at about $3,000 per year per grower. The New South Wales government estimated that around 2,000 jobs in the sugar industry could be placed in jeopardy by the loss of the sugar tariff.

There are also a number of other points that the Senate should consider in this matter. The minority report noted that despite assurances from the Australian soft drink manufacturers no plans had been made to import sugar. The ACCC believes that import competition will provide an effective constraint on their pricing decisions. It is also significant that the soft drink industry conceded during the inquiry that savings of around $7 million per annum the soft drink industry will gain from the loss of the tariff will not be passed on to consumers. I want to refer to the evidence given to the inquiry by Mr Gentile. He was asked questions about the impact of the savings of $7 million per year by Senator Forshaw. He was asked:
There did not seem to be a difference, but that—
Mr Gentile —I can honestly say to you that whilst there is a saving of over $7 million to the total soft drink industry in Australia—
Senator FORSHAW —Per year?

Mr Gentile —Per year. That is saving. It is easy to calculate. Whilst there is a saving of that sort of order, the unit cost for one bottle or one can of soft drink is quite small—the impact of sugar on that can of soft drink is quite small. So, you have got to take it into account in terms of your total cost. You cannot take one ingredient and say that you will reduce the price of that ingredient, so automatically that price on the supermarket shelf will reduce by X. It does not happen that way, and anyone who has been in the business knows that.

So he was saying you cannot say that because we are going to reduce the price of sugar that is going to be factored into the price of a soft drink. We are not going to say that the amount of sugar means that there will be a reduction of 0.5c or 1c to the unit cost, that we are going to reduce the unit cost. Indeed, we are not.

If you look at his evidence, all he was prepared to say was that the marketing of soft drink led to discounting and that, effectively, somehow the reduction in the cost of sugar would be factored into the discounting cost. In other words, if the market requires discounting, then the industry will recover the cost of that discounting from the savings presented to them by the removal of the sugar tariff and, potentially, the reduction in the cost of the sugar to the processors.

Of course, the producers' sugar is sold at a price which factors in the tariff—or which did up to 1 July this year. They have already lost that. The price of sugar in Australia now should have reflected a reduction consequent to the removal of the tariff, because that has effectively been implemented retrospective to 1 July. In addition, the domestic price of sugar factored in the potential cost of transport of imported sugar from the nearest port, which is Thailand as I understand it.

So there should have been a considerable reduction in the price of sugar. That should have already been factored in to the price of the products of various producers—be it the soft drink manufacturers or the confectionary manufacturers, such as Cadbury's referred to by Senator Brown. But no evidence has been presented to us, that I am aware of, that shows that such a reduction has taken place.

Any suggestion that this measure is going to have a great impact on consumers has not been borne out by the facts as they are able to be demonstrated to date. I repeat: notwithstanding the fact that this legislation has not yet been passed, the tariff was effectively removed on 1 July and the removal of the tariff impact should be measurable at this time.

Given the weakness of anti-dumping legislation, it is possible that future imports of sugar could seriously threaten the viability of the domestic industry—a concern heightened by the ACCC prediction that there will be a significant rise in the world sugar production and refining capacity in the future. That is the ACCC's view. If that is the case, this is not a rational decision taken in the context of domestic needs and international obligations. It is an irrational decision forced by an economically conservative philosophy taken by members of the government and will be paid for by regional Australia in the form of income foregone and jobs lost.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was your government that put the working group together.

—The minister says that it is somehow the opposition's fault because we put a working group together. But I will remind the minister that it was not our government but his government that put the pressure on the working party in terms of the trade-off between the single desk and the tariff.
—What rubbish!

—The minister says: what rubbish! But his government was the only body that was in position to do that. When you look at the timetable that the working party was working to, it was your government, Minister, and not our government that was in position to apply that pressure. Let us look at the evidence that the committee took from, for example, the Australian Cane Farmers Association. This is reported in the government's majority report to the Senate on this matter on page 7 at 2.5:

SPEECH.PARA: ACFA stressed that the organisation supported the majority of the SIRWP recommendations, but had always opposed total removal of the tariff:

`To the best of our knowledge, most industry organisations, and in particular the two grower organisations, did not support the removal of the sugar tariff in their submissions to the Sugar Industry Review Working Party. We ask the questions: what motivated the recommendation to remove the tariff, and why following the release of the Sugar Industry Review Working Party recommendations was there no opportunity provided for further consultation with the industry?'
It goes on:

When the recommendation was released it was quite obvious that there was an outcry on the tariff issue. I believe that it is on record that we supported, in general, most of the other 74 recommendations. Of those 74 recommendations, most were of an industry nature. There was a lot of disagreement with those remaining 74, particularly the one relating to the changes to the pooling arrangements, but we recognised that that was an industry issue and it was going to take a long time for us to attempt to satisfy all those who had opinions about that.

However, I make the point that the one opinion that was common to all concerned the recommendation to remove the sugar tariff. The tariff had value as an anti‐dumping mechanism. We believe that dumped sugar is a possibility in Australia.

That was said by the Australian Cane Farmers Association of Australia. That is the body which said basically that the review did not reflect the industry body on that issue. But they were prepared to wear the other 73 of the 74 recommendations on the review of the industry—that is their evidence. There is no point in shaking your head, Minister, because that is your government members' majority report on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a quote from one of the witnesses.

—That is in your report and it is a fair reflection of the evidence. That is right, Senator Crane: you fairly reflected the evidence—and I am not being critical when I say that. That was the view of a significant number of witnesses. The Australian Cane Farmers Association wanted that evidence to be before the Senate and you properly put it there. I am not being critical; I am saying to the minister that that is the evidence your report properly presented to the Senate. That is what the report says.

SPEECH.PARA: The evidence of the Chairman of the Cane Growers Association is reported on pages 8 and 9 of the committee report. Mr Harry Bonanno, a member of the sugar industry review working party and the chairman of the cane growers, told the committee, as stated at point 2.10:

Certainly the governments, both state and federal, were emphatic that we had to comply with the national competition policy. There is no doubt about that. I understand the English language perfectly, and there were no ifs or buts. It was impressed upon us that it was fairly desirable to have a unanimous decision come out of the review. That is not an easy thing to come up with, a unanimous decision out of a review, when there are such differing views to commence with.

We had to work through all of that and we paid a heap of money to consultants to give us all of the opinions we could lay our hands on to show how we could comply with national competition policy. We had to pass the public benefit test, and there is no way that we could hold the tariff and hold single desk selling and still pass the public benefit test for our industry, especially with the single desk selling.
On page 9, he said:

When we signed off on the recommendations, every organisation had a representative there. After they signed, some of the organisations chose not to follow, perhaps, the commitments that their chairman, or whoever he was at the time, had made. Frankly, I believe I have made a commitment on behalf of Canegrowers, and the Canegrowers Council subscribe to that view because they have supported me in that determination.

Mr Bonanno is saying that the individuals took a position which they believed reflected the views of the industry. He also admits that when those views became known, in a number of cases the organisations disowned that decision. In other words, the decisions that were taken were not taken with the full backing of their organisation and the organisation was not prepared to support it. That is reflected in the evidence that was put before the Senate committee. There are serious concerns about this matter, in regional Queensland and northern New South Wales in particular, in terms of the impact on some of the regional centres. I have a letter here from Cairns City Council and I will read part of it. It says:

In recent times, the federal government has seen the reality in consequences of removing the tariff from the car industry and consequently did not proceed with that recommendation. It also appears that the consequences on the Australian textile industry could be disastrous with the loss of Australian jobs. Hopefully these industries will receive a considerate hearing. Council again asks all senators to please consider the consequences on the towns and cities along the Queensland sugar belt which most rely on the sugar industry's viability for their employment. Collectively, this area could lose $18 million annually to their local economies. In the Cairns local authority area alone, the loss would be $1.2 million annually, with $2 million for the whole of the Cairns region.

That is the view of Cairns City Council. To give an example from New South Wales, the Northern Rivers Regional Development Board Incorporated wrote to the minister. I have a copy of a letter dated 24 September. They said:

The removal of the tariff will have a most detrimental effect on the sugar industry in New South Wales and, to a lesser extent, in Queensland. In view of the coalition promises that were made to the sugar industry prior to the election, for example, on February 12 1993, the coalition shadow minister, Bruce Lloyd promised `the sugar tariffs would be phased down to $15 per tonne by the year 2000 and retained at that level'. Also a declaration was signed at Murwillumbah in June 1992 by Senator Bill O'Chee, Don Beck MLA, Larry Anthony and Mike Emerson opposing any additional cuts to sugar tariff.

I emphasise in relation to the New South Wales situation that the evidence before the inquiry was that they rely more on the domestic price of sugar than the export price of sugar. Queensland exports the majority of its product. That is not clearly the evidence in relation to the New South Wales growers. As I understand the evidence, their product is grown predominantly for domestic use.

This decision will have the greatest effect in northern New South Wales. The reduction in the price to the growers will be more keenly felt in New South Wales as compared to Queensland as their price will be reduced the most in proportion to the totality of their crop.

TALK.START.PARA: —Premier Carr says 2,000 jobs will go.
—I have already referred to that decision.
—He is wrong. The sugar working group says the jobs will increase.

—The sugar working industry group does not have the confidence of the industry. Unfortunately, they do not have the confidence of the industry on that issue, Minister, but I would be interested to hear your comments in this debate. No doubt, we will entertain further discussion when we get into the committee stage.

—I rise to speak on the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 . I begin my comments by highlighting the title of the report that was brought down. It was called Winning globally . These are very significant words. I also highlight in this place the fact that 85 per cent of our sugar is exported. Only 15 per cent is consumed in this country. Virtually the only chance that the sugar industry has to expand—there is potential to grow—in New South Wales, Queensland and Western Australia, albeit it is in its embryo stage there, is through exporting.

BREAK.PARA: I highlight what has occurred in this particular debate. Just recently—the decision that has been made here has had a lot to do with whether the sugar industry can expand—Korea decided to reduce the tariff on Australian sugar entering the Korean market by 40 per cent. That will bring the tariff down to three per cent.

I also highlight in relation to this debate the fact that recently Brunei, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Israel, Kazakstan, Kuwait, Latvia, Malaysia, New England, Singapore, Slovenia and the UAE have already reduced their tariffs on our sugar to zero. If anybody thinks that that would not have occurred as a result of the decision that has been made, they are fooling themselves. It is part of the reciprocal arrangements in terms of increasing trade. It is a position that those opposite held—Senator O'Brien shakes his head—when they were in government. If anybody believes that this would not have occurred if we had adopted a different position, they are absolutely wrong.

I pay tribute to Harry Bonanno for his leadership. In terms of winning globally, Mr Ron Verri, President of the Australian Cane Farmers Association, was a member of that working party. I also point out that they spent over $3 million on the Boston report to come to their conclusions. It is true that there are 74 recommendations.

The terms of reference for that working party belong to the previous federal Labor government and the previous Queensland state Labor government. The directions and the letters that were sent belong to the previous government as far as competition policy is concerned. They were signed by none other than Senator Bob Collins. He made it quite clear that they had to abide by competition policy—your policy. Furthermore, when they made their decision—this is one which the industry up there supports—they put more import on the single desk selling system for the domestic market than they did on the tariff.

Also, in terms of this decision, in moving to export parity pricing for the domestic market, you cannot have export parity pricing and apply a tariff by definition. Even if you reintroduced the tariff, it has no effect—it does not apply. We have to realise that when we are dealing with this particular debate.

The decisions, the guidelines and the whole process were put there by the Labor Party. The directions which they had to comply with were put there by the Labor Party. It is true that the report came down after we came into government, but I also challenge those opposite in terms of their policy position. Had they put this report down, they would not have changed their position; they would not have gone against this. We know that.

I wish to talk about another aspect of what has to be dealt with in the short time that I have left, one that is very important in this whole debate. It relates to the impact of the merger between CSR and Mackay Sugar. One must not forget that the basic reason that the ACCC changed their position was purely and simply because the tariff was removed. The only anti‐competitive element went. Let us look at that a wee bit further, because it is very important.

When Professor Fels and his officers appeared before us they made it absolutely crystal clear that if the tariff was brought back on, they would have no option—it is in the committee's report—but to seriously review the particular decision, that is, the merger. He made it very clear without being able to say it, because it is not a decision of his in isolation, that they would have to review that particular decision.

The losses from over production in the refining sector are costing Queensland growers somewhere in the order of $22 million a year. It is coming directly out of the pockets of Queensland growers. So we cannot ignore that when we are dealing with this particular issue. As we work through the various aspects of it, one thing is very important. The evidence came through—what Senator O'Brien said was correct about Mr Gentile—that you could not identify at the end the savings to consumers. However, what he and other witnesses made clear is that because of the overproduction in the refining business in this country, the tariff had long been traded away. That is borne out by the prices when you compare the domestic prices which exist.

One of the reasons for the difficulties that the refining industry has in terms of the current situation in sugar is, purely and simply, that oversupply. Unless that is addressed, not only are the growers going to lose $22 million a year but also the other shareholders in the refining industry in Queensland, which are primarily in the order of 40 per cent, are going to lose a lot more money as well. We must not forget either of these groups of shareholders.

So they have got, if you like, a hand in both camps, and they should be protected. To turn around this decision now not only would be not in the best interests of the sugar export industry and of the total sugar industry in Australia; it would cost growers an enormous amount of money, and it has already cost them a lot.

This was a bold report, it was a good report. It was based on the terms of reference set down by the Labor Party. It was based on the directions and instructions that were given by the previous minister, Senator Bob Collins, and if Senator Bob Collins were here I am sure he would be prepared to acknowledge that particular fact. He said only that they had to comply with the necessities of competition policy, which was also in legislation he brought in. So, when you pick the populist route, never forget who put that in place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bartlett, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I recognise the pressure of business at this time of year but I believe this is an issue of great importance. As has been clear from the contributions to date, it is an issue of particular significance for farmers in Queensland. It is certainly an issue of importance to the Democrats. As the tariff slashing approach of this government follows on from the tariff slashing approach of the previous Labor government, it is an issue of great concern to the Democrats and, as a Queenslander and a Democrat, I feel it is appropriate for me to make some contribution to this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Crane just spoke about the report entitled Winning globally. That is a fairly inspirational title but it is probably important to consider the flipside of that, which is that while some people are winning globally—it looks to me from this that the big winners globally will be people like Coca‐Cola—some people are certainly going to lose locally. Those people are the farmers and their communities in regional areas, communities which have been hit harder than most by the policies both of this government and the previous government.

I realise that politics is a curious business and that you do get some strange suggestions being put forward from time to time. Certainly I found it curious and difficult to believe Senator Boswell's suggestion that the reason why the government is breaking such a clear‐cut promise is that the industry basically came to it on bended knee and said, `Please break your promise and remove the tariff.'

TALK.START.PARA: —They did.

—Maybe that is correct but I tend to believe the suggestion and the evidence that was put to the Senate committee that there was a little bit of a gun to the head when the industry was on bended knee and that might have forced their hand a bit.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Boswell also suggested that he was a great believer in maintaining tariffs some years back when the world market was corrupt, but apparently now the world market is no longer corrupt. The suggestion that the world market is no longer corrupt is something that, again, I find fairly difficult to believe. Senator Woodley quoted in his speech sugar beet growers in the European Union who specifically said that if they had to compete at world market prices they would be wiped out. There is obviously a little bit of corruption still out there in the big, bad world and, again, this naive suggestion that we can unilaterally reduce tariffs to zero is something that the Democrats find fairly astonishing.

I suppose that, having been following politics for a long time, the fact that the National Party might not actually be following their words with action and doing things that are actually in the interests of farmers but selling them out instead is not necessarily a great surprise to me. I have seen that happen many a time in Queensland over the years. Something I am even more surprised about is the apparent view of Senator Brown, from the Greens, that he is considering supporting the removal of the sugar tariff. The vision of Senator Brown joining the zero tariff, free trade, level playing field brigade is one that I find a bit surprising—auditioning for the new Captain Zero role!

That would increase the profits of multinational companies, like Coca‐Cola, at the expense of regional communities and farmers in regional areas. I find that quite surprising. I had the understanding until recently—and I had no reason to think otherwise—that he would follow the usual approach that the Greens have taken in relation to tariff issues and that Senator Margetts outlined in her speech—that unilateral reduction of tariffs is not really the way to go. It is a bit surprising that he is apparently thinking twice about that issue.

The Democrats acknowledge that there are environmental issues of great concern in the sugar industry and that they need to be addressed. I found it a little bit offensive that Senator Brown in his speech suggested that Senator Woodley was unaware of the environmental impact of the sugar growing industry. Perhaps because it happened predominantly prior to Senator Brown's coming into this place, he is not aware of the ongoing work of Senator Woodley in this area over a couple of years in pressuring both the previous government and the current government about the impact of sugar cane farming on the mahogany glider habitat, in particular, but also the other practices of the sugar industry which impact on the environment. To make that suggestion about Senator Woodley or the Democrats, who have done more than anyone in Queensland to highlight some of the environmental damage that the sugar industry has caused in Queensland, is just mistaken.

Senator Brown's second reading amendment brings up the issue of single desk selling—something, of course, that the Democrats do support—but he also said that the single desk selling issue and the tariff cut issue are not linked. The dissenting report from the Senate committee inquiry into this issue also found no evidence to demonstrate that single desk selling would automatically be dismantled if the tariff was retained. Senator Margetts also pointed out that there is no link between the issue of single desk selling and the tariff. That is part of the nub of this issue and why there is no justification for reducing the tariff in this way.

Senator Margetts made quite a number of good points in her speech about why it is such a strange way to go, to support the elimination of the tariff, to unilaterally remove tariffs down to zero. As she said, the only real advantage in dropping the tariff goes to big confectionery manufacturers and there are some potential drawbacks for rural communities and for farmers in moving unilaterally to free trade, both in terms of any leverage to get any other nation to lower trade barriers and in moving towards a regulated, fair market system instead of towards a free market system. I implore Senator Brown to listen again to those words before supporting something which goes further down the unregulated, free market track.

Senator Margetts again said in her speech yesterday that there appear to be no certain positive environmental consequences either from cutting the tariff or from keeping it there, and that there are potential drawbacks with either option. Trying to link the tariff cut with environmental issues is a flawed approach. No‐one is saying that there are no environmental issues that the sugar industry needs to address, but the Democrats believe it is a strange way to go to try to get an industry to address environmental problems by kicking them in the guts. The Democrats have said many a time that that is a false dichotomy and that we need to look at exploring ways that increase jobs while preserving and protecting the environment. We come down to the core issue on this bill of how people are going to vote. As was pointed out in the Senate committee's report, the issue of a tariff is the only one out of the 74 recommendations of the sugar industry review working party that can be dealt with by legislation. TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 . The particular issue we are concentrating on is the review of the sugar tariff issue.

SPEECH.PARA: The review of the tariff in Queensland's Sugar Industry Act 1991 was established by the Commonwealth and Queensland governments in October 1995. This was a time of a Labor federal government and a Labor state government. The terms of reference required the review to be consistent with the principles of the Competition Principles Agreement's national competition policy principles and specified that the objective of any new Queensland legislation should be to facilitate the sustainable development of an internationally competitive export oriented industry which would benefit both industry participants and the wider community.

The sugar review began in October 1995 and reported to both the governments on 29 November 1996. The working party was chaired by Sir Eric Neale on 1 July 1996 and then by Mr Bruce Vaughan. Membership of the working party included representatives from the grain growing and milling sectors, sugar users, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and Queensland's Department of Primary Industries.

In respect of the tariff it is important to note how it operated. As imports of sugar into Australia are negligible, the tariff did not act as an instrument for stopping competitive imports of sugar into Australia. Rather it served to redistribute income from consumers to producers via the domestic pricing arrangements operating in Queensland. Prior to 1 July 1997 the Queensland Sugar Corporation priced domestic sales at or close to import parity, which included the value of the tariff. Potential loss to customs revenue is, therefore, not an issue in this case. Duty collected on raw cane sugar in 1996‐97 amounted to the massive sum of $772.

In endorsing the recommendations of the working party, the government was mindful that, provided the recommendations were implemented fully as a package, members of the working party, including representatives of the peak industry organisations, supported them unanimously. The package of recommendations had already been fully endorsed by the Queensland government. This government considers the package as a significant step towards maintaining an internationally competitive and sustainable export oriented industry. It will position the industry well to meet future challenges from other producers around the world as well as competition from alternative sweeteners and from other crops.

The package is designed to provide a framework for increasing efficiency, reducing costs, improving raw sugar marketing services and increasing the opportunities for innovation. It provides for all domestic refiners and industrial users to have access to raw sugar at world prices.

The package of arrangements will overcome a number of current constraints on the performance of the Queensland sugar industry which impact negatively on the overall community. The arrangements represent significant change now. Moreover, they set in train an ongoing process of change which will be driven essentially by the industry itself. As reflected above, the removal of the tariff is consistent with the working party recommendations to set domestic sugar prices at export parity.

Making the domestic price equal to the world sugar price will increase the ability of Australian manufacturers of products containing sugar to compete with imported products and will encourage them to innovate, to become more competitive and to reduce prices to consumers. This has been covered by many of the speeches in the second reading debate. Additionally, the transport cost advantage Australian suppliers enjoy will continue to offer a natural path of protection from imports of both raw and refined sugar. Export parity pricing for domestic raw sugar sales will result in the prices received by growers through the pooling arrangements reflecting world levels. If domestic prices are equal to world prices, the tariff is rendered ineffective and will not provide further assistance to sugar producers.

In accepting the working party's recommendations to remove the tariff on sugar imports, the government was mindful of its own sugar policy announced before the last election. In that policy the government undertook, `to not reduce the sugar tariff beyond the present level of $55 a tonne', which was set to continue until 30 June 1997. Given that the working party recommendations had the unanimous support of the chairmen of the peak industry bodies, which represented over 95 per cent of cane production, and given the effect of export parity pricing on sugar sold domestically, the government decided to endorse the industry backed recommendation to remove the tariff from 30 June 1997. Senator Boswell covered this very effectively in his speech. He made the point that the industry came to the government and said, `We want to accept that package.'

The sugar industry review working party wrote to the Minister for Primary Industries in Queensland, Mr Trevor Perrett, and to the federal Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, the Hon. John Anderson, on 29 November 1997. The letter was signed by all members of the sugar industry review working party, including Mr Verri who represented the Australian Cane Farmers Association. I seek leave to incorporate that letter in Hansard.
