—There is no point of order.

—There are some things that you should adhere to, if that is the case, and one of them is coming out honestly and saying just what you were doing. You were trying to stir up a constituency in an area where you will never have one, not while you are taking the position you are taking with farmers regarding things like Wik and not when you are saying to the canefarmers up there, `We are going to introduce a death duty. That is our policy.' An inheritance tax is a death duty. They are the sorts of things you are telling your farmers. You come in here and try to pretend that you are representing the canegrowers of Queensland.

BREAK.PARA: Regarding the comments made by other speakers, the hypocrisy of the Labor Party is amazing. They went down the track reducing tariffs all over the place. They were responsible for setting up this working group. They set the terms of reference. The working group came in and made a unanimous recommendation which we accepted. As Senator Boswell quite correctly said, we listened to what they told us. They said they wanted these recommendations implemented lock, stock and barrel. We said, `Certainly'. We went to the last election with a policy. But it was not just the canegrowers but every person on that working group—cane producers, canegrowers, users, millers—who unanimously agreed that they wanted this implemented.

Senator Brown knew a lot more about what this legislation was all about than either the Labor Party or the Democrats. What Senator Brown said in the main was absolutely correct. It is one of those rare occasions were I almost entirely agreed with. I would like him to pass on my thanks to the person who prepared that information for him because they were correct.
I have no more comments to make on this matter. I believe it is important that we do clean up the few bits of legislation left so that we can get on to the Wik debate.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Brown's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

BREAK.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the committee's attention to the fact that the proposed amendments to this bill have been drafted as requests. This is because the bill effectively increases some tariffs and is therefore a bill imposing taxation, which the Senate cannot amend. The question is that the bill stand as printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
Schedule 4, items 1 to 5, page 7 (lines 6 to 20), omit the items.

The opposition has proposed a request that the House of Representatives agree to schedule 4 being amended by the removal of items 1 to 5, page 7, line 6 to 20. They are the items that relate to the decision to remove the $55 per tonne sugar tariff. If the request is supported by the Senate and ultimately accepted by the House of Representatives, the sugar tariff would be retained or, more correctly, reinstated. I want to make some comments about our proposed amendment. In doing so, I want to clarify a couple of issues that arose during the second reading debate.

It seems that Senator Boswell and, to a lesser extent, Senator Parer can debate this issue only by resorting to personal attacks. I am not terribly concerned about personal attacks from Senator Boswell. When Senator Boswell stands up and calls people thick and says that they are dopes and so on, I am reminded that this is the same senator who attacked the members of the High Court and inferred that they were all thick, unelected and—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Chair, I raise a point of order. I have never said that the High Court was thick or unelected. If Senator Forshaw is going to quote me, I ask that he not further continue his misrepresentations about what I have accused him of in the first place. He is only adding to his misrepresentations in this place. If you are going to quote me, quote me accurately or do not quote me at all.
—There is no point of order. This is a matter for debate.
—Senator Boswell, you should listen to what people say.
—Senator Forshaw, you might like to address the chair.
—I did not seek to quote Senator Boswell; I said that was what he inferred about the High Court. Anybody in the community would know what Senator Boswell was inferring about the High Court.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to turn to the issue of representing what people actually say. During the second reading debate, Senator Boswell and Senator Parer sought to attack the Labor opposition and other parties for reflecting the views of representatives of canefarmers who appeared before the Senate committee. When you allege that people are hypocrites, they are thick, they are dopes and they are misrepresenting the position, what you are saying is that the evidence that was given to the Senate committee's inquiry was evidence given by people who were apparently thick, hypocrites and dopes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Chair, I take a point of order. I continue to ask Senator Boswell to withdraw that remark. He is implying that I have said this about the industry. I ask you to call him to order and point out that I have never said that about the industry. What I pointed out was that it was him that I was calling thick and ignorant.

—Madam Chair, on the point of order: your first ruling was correct but I think Senator Forshaw has now gone further. Senator Forshaw is now imputing an improper motive to Senator Boswell and that is why Senator Forshaw should be asked to withdraw.

—Madam Chair, on the point of order: I believe there is no point of order but I want to say that at this point Senator Boswell seems to be incredibly sensitive. He is the one who used the word `thick' in reference to Senator Forshaw. It now seems that he is so sensitive. If it is too hot in here for him, he should go and take a cold shower.
—There are no points of order. This is a robust debate. I would ask Senator Forshaw to continue and to continue to address the chair.

—I would ask honourable senators to listen to what I am saying. What I have said is that the allegations that have been made by members of the government about senators on this side of the chamber are allegations made to try to discredit us. However, in doing so, they really seek to discredit the witnesses who came before the committee.

SPEECH.PARA: What we have pointed out to the Senate is that which Senator O'Brien read from in his remarks in the second reading debate. What I read from in my remarks in the second reading debate and what Senator Woodley referred to in the second reading debate was the evidence given to the committee by representatives of the Cane Farmers Association.

I want to read some of that evidence again for the benefit of Senator Boswell and other senators. This is the evidence which we clearly relied upon in our report to support the retention of the tariff. It was the farmers and their representatives who came to the committee and said that they were railroaded effectively into supporting the recommendation because they had it put to them that there was a choice—either the tariff or the single desk mechanism. We now know that that is not a choice they should have ever had to make.

I will not again read in detail the evidence, because it is in the report and it is in Hansard. But, if you are going to stand up and support the position adopted by the government, at least have the decency and the honesty to recognise that the evidence put to the Senate inquiry from canefarmers' representatives was that they did not want the tariff removed. Their evidence was that they would suffer financially if it was removed. Their evidence was that they did not really get a proper say in the working party process. Indeed, as Mr Allison said:

Of the 75 recommendations that were contained in the Queensland sugar industry review working party report, there was only one recommendation on which this organisation went public, and that was the recommendation in relation to the tariff. That one recommendation was comprehensively condemned by both Queensland and New South Wales alike. To the best of our knowledge, most industry organisations and in particular the two grower organisations did not support the removal of the sugar tariff in their submissions to the sugar industry review working party. We asked the questions: what motivated the recommendation to remove the tariff and why, following the release of the sugar industry review working party recommendations, was there no opportunity provided for further consultation with the industry?

Clearly, from the time that the recommendation was made, there were expressions of concern being put forward by representatives of the Cane Farmers Association that they were not happy with the outcome of the process; that they believed that people had actually been put in a position on that working party where they had no choice; and, further, that the cane farmers and the other sugar interests in northern New South Wales, who would be most significantly affected by this decision, really did not have an appropriate voice within that working party process. In our arguments to this Senate, we have quoted the evidence of the witnesses themselves from the industry.

The government comes back and says, `Well, this whole process was established by the Labor government.' It is true; the working party was established in October 1995 and, of course, there was an election in March 1996 in which the coalition parties were successful and took government. The working party reported in November 1996, almost nine months after that election. So don't try to suggest that because the process was set up by the Labor government somehow the outcomes were ones that we preordained.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you filibustering? What about Wik?
—Senator Parer, if you want to bring on Wik, here is your opportunity. Move a deferral now, Senator Parer, and we will bring it on. Come on; have the courage.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important that those in the sugar industry hear this debate because of the misrepresentation of their position. If, as the government argues correctly, the working party process was under way in October 1995, why was it that the coalition went to the election in March 1996 with a policy to retain the tariff and the single desk? One has to ask what the motivation was for that.

It is clear from the evidence to the committee that significant sections of the industry do not support the removal of the tariff. In fact, when given the opportunity to finally have their say before a senate committee dealing specifically with this legislation, they asked this parliament to retain the tariff. Clearly we are persuaded by their position and, on that basis, we will be asking the Senate to support our request that these provisions in schedule 4 be omitted and that the tariff be retained.

I will make a couple of other quick comments in regard to the amendments. Firstly, with respect to the amendment that was moved by Senator Brown and dealt with in the second reading debate, it should not in any way be taken that, whilst we did not support that amendment, we are not supporting the retention of the single desk. That is patently obvious. Our problem with the amendment, for the benefit of Senator Brown—because there was no opportunity in the second reading debate to canvass many of those issues—was that we believed that, particularly, subclauses (c) (iii) and (iv) were unacceptable. If they had been excised we probably would have been able to support that amendment.
But that is the past and we are into the committee stage and the other amendments. Certainly, we are committed to the retention of the single desk and the retention of the tariff.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to reply to the interjection by the government that we are filibustering. What we are doing is replying to outrageous statements made by the minister—and, to a certain extent, Senator Boswell—in his second reading speech. It is in the minister's hands. If he does not want us to reply to those kinds of outrageous statements, then he knows what to do: don't make them.
—It is all right for you to make them, isn't it?

—I am going to tell you. I certainly am going to take the opportunity to reply to them in supporting Labor's amendment—a very sensible amendment. I support this amendment because I wrote to the government at least a week ago suggesting in a letter that they might do what Labor is now having to do by amendment. It would have given them the opportunity to have acted sensibly so that we could have separated the sugar issue from the other issues in this bill, but I have not even had a reply to my letter. We will certainly support the Labor Party's amendment at this point.

SPEECH.PARA: There were a number of statements made by the minister. One of them was in response to my not giving permission to incorporate the press release. Senator Forshaw has already given you reasons why this was so. I did not give leave to incorporate because evidence given by Cane Farmers at the inquiry clearly showed that that one press release they put out was not authorised by the officials of the Cane Farmers and was put out by mistake.

Very clearly, they are absolutely opposed to the abolition of the sugar tariff, and I will give you more evidence to support that. The Cane Farmers Association itself gave me 5,000 names and addresses of cane farmers so that we could put out a survey to find out what cane farmers really think. The surveys returned show that over 90 per cent of cane farmers are opposed to what the government is doing. So much for the Cane Farmers Association being in support of the government.

The minister's reference to inheritance tax was a very interesting one, because it is this government that has imposed an inheritance tax on the aged people of Australia through its entry fees to nursing homes.
Let me also reply to the minister's statement about Canegrowers in Mackay. I understand that the cane growers association in Mackay are very sensitive about this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shallow and naive, they reckon.

—You are, Minister. Let me tell you why Canegrowers in Mackay are so sensitive about this issue: they have been told by the government—Senator Crane repeated it this morning—that the merger between CSR and Mackay will not go ahead if the sugar tariff is restored. Obviously once again this government is holding a gun at the head of cane growers to ensure that they stay on board with the government. This government is incredibly worried about what is happening with cane farmers in Queensland and New South Wales because it knows it has lost most of them. At the next election, which I can hardly wait for, we will see.

BREAK.PARA: That might have been Canegrowers in Mackay. At meetings I had with the cane growers—all members of Canegrowers—in Babinda, Gordonvale and Ayr they all contradicted what the cane growers in Mackay were saying and what Canegrowers in Brisbane were saying. I do not want to bag that cane growers association, but I know that Harry Bonanno particularly has found himself in an absolutely invidious position because the government has put him in the situation where, instead of representing his growers, he has had to go along with the government, agree with the government and defend the government on something which is totally indefensible. I have a lot of respect for Harry Bonanno—he is a very genuine man—but he has been put in an impossible situation.

The minister referred to Ian Ballantyne's assertion that my numbers are wrong. Let me tell senators where the numbers come from. They come from figures supplied by ABARE. They come from figures supplied by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy in the hearing that we had and the evidence which they gave to that hearing. They came in further evidence to the inquiry during the hearing that we held in Brisbane. They came in a letter to me from the Australian Sugar Millers Council. All of them confirmed that the figures we have given about the average loss to cane farmers are correct.

The other issue that Canegrowers in Mackay have raised is whether or not the survey was a good one. I would not mind if the cane growers associations conducted their own surveys. If they think the returns that I have been getting are wrong, let them conduct their own survey. That is not a problem, but they have not done it and they will not do it because they know the result.

Perhaps that is as much as I need to say at this stage, although I may be provoked to say a little more. We will see what happens. At this stage I indicate the Australian Democrats will certainly support the Labor Party's amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicated in my second reading contribution that the Greens (WA) will be supporting the ALP amendment and that, without the passage of the ALP's amendment, we will not consider supporting the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there are some things that do have to be responded to, and I will try to do that in an unemotional way and apologise to my friend over there. In the heat of debate sometimes these things happen, but let us approach this rationally.

SPEECH.PARA: The sugar industry were asked to review themselves by the former Goss and Labor Party governments. Involved in that review were people representing all parts of the industry. I will read them out: Mr Vaughan, who was the chairman—I think he was later replaced; Mr Bonanno; Mr Newton, who is in the box at the moment; Graham Davies, from the millers association; Robert Reilly, who was a member; Mr Gentile; and Mr Verri.
On 21 November 1996 a unanimous report was put down which said:
We are pleased to present the unanimously agreed report on the Sugar Industry Review Working Party 1996, signed off within the original timetable.

The report goes on and has on it the signature of Mr Verri, who represented the Australian Cane Farmers Association in the sugar working party. This was then followed by a press release on 18 December 1996. The press release—I think Senator Woodley has some misapprehension about incorporating this—said:
Unique, Comprehensive and Achievable were some of the words used by the ACFA executive and Directors in describing the SIRWP Report . . .

Mr Allison, General Manager ACFA, said that he believed the general industry would accept the Report as a unified, solid approach to the future direction of the industry. In doing so, he believes the report also reflects the maturity of the industry.

Mr Allison said, "In digesting the report we should remain cognisant of the fact that this report is the result of a review that was carried out under instruction from Government and within the guidelines of National Competition Policy.

So he endorsed the report. But, further to that, Mr Verri, Mr Bonanno and the chairman at the time came down to the national parliament and had a meeting with all coalition senators and members of parliament who were interested in any way in the sugar industry. Larry Anthony and Bob Katter were there; all of us were there. Mr Verri was there, too, representing the Australian Cane Farmers Association. They pointed out that, in the interest of the industry, they wanted us to support the removal of the tariff. I pointed out to them then that it was going to cause some problems. They said, `We've reviewed it ad nauseam. We've had—' to use the vernacular `‐ a gutful of it. All we want to do is get it away. We want a unanimous report. Let's get back to the job.'

But in charges Senator Woodley muddying the water. I can understand Senator Woodley's problem. With the desertion of his leader, he now finds himself going to an election with two per cent of the vote. Where is the biggest vote? It is with the cane farmers in Queensland. He sees an opportunity to go and stir up an industry. This industry is one of the best industries in Australia. It has increased the returns by 124 per cent and there is a 60 per cent increase in production. It is going like a German band it is doing so well.

You come in and stir the whole thing up. No wonder I get excited. Here is an industry that is making money, doing well and really forging ahead. It cannot get another stick of cane through the mills it is going so well. It cannot take another stick of cane; it is in top production. You come in here, stir the industry up and send out—I say this with all due respect—a very silly survey. If I said to you, `Do you want a trip to New Zealand?' you would say, `Yes, I'd love a trip to New Zealand.' If I said, `Do you want to swim?' you would say, `No.' But you put out the part of the survey that says, `Do you want a trip to New Zealand?' You do not tell them anything else about the industry.

These people have relied on the leadership in their industry to take them forward, and it has been one of the best industry leaderships. But you go down and pull the mat right out from under them, right out from under the second most successful primary industry in Australia, and you wonder why I get excited. It is because you stir them up and you do not tell them the truth.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Forshaw and Senator Woodley, if this government had not removed the tariff, which was a commitment going into the election, and said, `We're going to break our commitment,' I would have fought it tooth and nail; I would have crossed the floor against it. But that was not the case. The industry came to us. First, it said in the sugar industry review package, `Take the tariff off.' Secondly, the Australian Cane Farmers Association and the Queensland Canegrowers Council issued press releases saying, `Take it off.' Thirdly, they personally flew down to Canberra and said, `Take the tariff off us. We've reviewed it ad infinitum. Let's get it away. Let's get it so that we get a unanimous report. We're going into a 90 per cent export market. The rest of the countries in the world have reduced their tariffs. Next year 90 per cent of the product will be going out.' And then someone changes their mind.

I have to say—and I exclude Senator Woodley from this, but I do not exclude the Labor Party; I think Senator Woodley is probably misguided—that the hypocrisy of the Labor Party has to be seen to be believed: to remove all tariffs on everything that moved in primary industry before anyone else had removed their tariffs, and then to come in here when you have done that and, thinking there are a few cheap votes to be gained in the sugar industry, do this. Even the press gallery are flabbergasted at your audacity to do this. If you think you are going to win votes like this and you think you are going to get back, you have no chance. The press will take the long handle to you on this one.

If you want a constituency, if you want to reconnect with your blue-collar workers, you are never going to get the cane farmers as long as you live. They will never vote for the Labor Party. They will never vote for you. They never have voted for you and, with what you are doing to the 10-point plan, they never will vote for you. After your decisions on Wik, they never will vote for you. Senator Woodley, with due respect to you, they think you are a nice old guy that goes around. Two or three of them turn up at some of your meetings. Four turned up at one. They think you are a good fellow, but they are not going to vote for you because they really just do not identify with the Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —How long can you keep selling them out, Ron?

—I have never sold the canegrowers out. I have told you guys that three times they came to the coalition and said, `Take the tariff off,' and that is what happened. But of course you see a cheap vote out there and you try to go for it. This is very unfortunate for an industry that have been divided by Senator Woodley. I say to them: once this bill goes through, pull together behind your leadership. It has taken you to being one of the most successful primary industries in Australia. Do not get diverted by all this opportunism by the Democrats and by the Labor Party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe this debate should be brought to a conclusion. But, while we continue to get this kind of stuff from Senator Boswell and the minister, I am afraid the debate will go on, because we are simply not going to cop this. Senator Boswell, you might be interested to know that I had a phone call just before I came into the chamber from the Cane Farmers Association asking me how it was going and whether or not the National Party were going to support them. I said, `I don't think so.' They said, `We hope it's on broadcast because we're certainly going to listen very carefully to this debate.' So they have been listening to you, Senator Boswell.

SPEECH.PARA: You said that I do not tell the truth. I am not going to reply by saying that you do not tell the truth. But I have to say that I have never heard anyone turn language on its head so effectively as Senator Boswell just did. He put the proposition that somehow or other I was undermining the industry, pulling the mat out from under the industry. I have never heard anyone try to say that they were supporting, or try to prove that they were helping, an industry by reducing their income. I will not say that is an untruth, Senator Boswell, but I have to say it is the most amazing reversal of language that I have ever heard—that somehow or other supporting an industry is taking away the farmers' income. The proposition is absolutely incredible.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Boswell also said that I had stirred up the industry. Senator Boswell, I do not know why you do not listen. I did nothing about this until the industry approached me. I got letters and phone calls and invitations to go and meet them. I did not do that for weeks until they became absolutely insistent. So I went and met with a number of the groups. I conducted a survey. What more can you do to ascertain what an industry really wants?

I am almost flabbergasted by the way Senator Boswell is able to say black is white and white is black. However, I guess the vote on this bill will be a significant one. But I think the vote some months down the track of cane farmers in Queensland and who they vote for will be even more significant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —I am motivated to rise in this committee stage of the debate by the comments of Senator Boswell. I wanted to draw his, the chamber's and the listening public's attention to comments by Laurie Oakes on 17 June in the Bulletin . He said, talking about the National Party and this issue, on page 44 of the Bulletin :

SPEECH.PARA: The sugar seats are not to be sneezed at. There are five of them—and almost certainly there will be six following the redistribution of electoral boundaries under way in Queensland—which could swing from the National Party to Labor. (In a couple of other Coalition‐held seats, sugar industry votes can be important.) They are especially vulnerable because the Coalition flagrantly broke a solemn and unequivocal election promise on the sugar industry. It promised not to lower the sugar tariff below the existing $55 a tonne. At that level, the policy said, Australia was already more than meeting its obligations under GATT. The National Party MPs and candidates in sugar seats all ran very hard on that promise. Now, not surprisingly, they are in trouble.
Howard, Anderson and their colleagues use the defence that the sugar industry in Queensland wanted the tariff to go.
That is a familiar sound; isn't it? That is exactly what Senator Boswell is telling the Senate today. Mr Oakes goes on:

That is simply untrue. The industry was mugged—told it had to choose between the tariff and a single‐desk marketing system. It decided that loss of the tariff was preferable to deregulation. Sugar industry representatives were also told that the government would be cutting car tariffs and that they—like other rural producers—would benefit from that decision. Howard himself made the link with car tariffs the day he told the government party room that he had decided (without consulting backbenchers from sugar seats) that the sugar tariff had to go. When several Queensland Nationals remonstrated with him at the end of the meeting, he gave them a guarantee that the car tariff would go as well. That mollified them to some extent but, after the car industry decision last week, they would have searched in vain for evidence of policy consistency.

I can understand Senator Boswell being extremely embarrassed at the position he now finds himself in. The invitation remains for Senator Boswell and his National Party colleagues in the Senate to come and sit with us when we vote for our amendment and we divide and are sitting across there. Senator Sandy Macdonald can look after the interests of the sugar industry in northern New South Wales and join us as well. We will pass the request and send it back to the House of Representatives and the coalition party room can consider the matter again. You can debate the matter again on the basis that, if you were given a promise on the basis of consistency with the car industry, you certainly have a good argument to say that there is a justification to change it. There is. I have heard no argument to the contrary.

Let us not have members of the National Party from the House of Representatives and the Senate talking about crossing the floor when it does not count. Today when it does count and it can count, put your hand up and cross the floor and vote with us on an issue that is in the interests of your constituents. But don't go around on other issues, when you know your crossing the floor will not change the result, and say, `I'm going to cross the floor; I'm going to make an important statement on this matter.' Let us have an actual demonstration of commitment on this issue and cross the floor on this issue.
It is clear that the support for this measure is not there in the industry. The general manager of the Sugar Millers Council has said:
It is fair to say large numbers of growers and millers will not agree with the Government's decision.
The General Manager of the Australian Cane Farmers Association, Mr Allison, has said:
Cane farmers from Mossman in north Queensland to Maclean in New South Wales have been scathing in their assessment of the recommendations by the Sugar Industry Review Working Party.
There is a groundswell of opinion and overwhelming opposition to the recommendations to remove the tariff.

In the Courier‐Mail there is a reference to Mr Harry Bonanno, Chairman of Canegrowers Queensland saying that cane growers `had reluctantly accepted the tariff's demise as part of a compromise to retain the industry's single desk selling arrangement.' It is important to note that that is not a Commonwealth animal; it is an animal of the Queensland government. It is not a matter that is in this bill at all. This bill does not touch, nor can the Commonwealth by legislation touch, the issue of the single desk.

TALK.START.PARA: —Get on with it. We want to get on with Wik.

—The minister says, `We want to get on with this, because we want to get on with Wik.' I am happy to sit down if he will stand up and move that the committee report progress so we can bring the Wik debate on. But if you are not going to do that, Minister, then we will debate this bill properly. You wanted it on the Notice Paper . You are not going to curtail the debate on the basis that we have to deal with Wik, when you are not prepared to bring it on. If we are going to deal with this bill, then the cane growers of Queensland and the people of Australia expect us to deal with it properly and not guillotine it.
—Stop being repetitious and get on to something concrete.
—Minister, you are not helping the time of this debate by interrupting.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sandy Macdonald interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator. I am anxious to hear your contribution to this debate as well. Mr Ballantyne said on PM :

SPEECH.PARA: If either side of government could have guaranteed our industry that the retention of the tariff would have also guaranteed the retention of our other marketing and structural arrangements, then we probably would have had a different approach.

But they have not, of course. This is an issue on which the government has broken a promise. The National Party has a chance to stand up for its constituency; and we are interested to see whether they do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to add a couple of further comments to the remarks made by Senator O'Brien. It is a pity that Senator Boswell has not remained, but I can understand it. Apparently he was getting a bit worked up and wants to cool down. I want to refer to Mr Katter's evidence before the committee. He was asked by Senator Woodley:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Katter, in your submission there is the statement:
`Mr Borbidge made it abundantly clear to Mrs De‐anne Kelly, Federal Member for Dawson, that the abolition of the single desk selling mechanism is now no longer an option.
Senator Woodley asked:

You go on to say that that really should have affected the way the working party sugar review made its decision and that if they had known that at the time they would not have agreed to lose the tariff.

I will refer again in a moment to Mr Katter's further comments. The Senate inquiry took place after the release of the report of the working party. The working party was clearly under the impression—more than the impression, clearly under the thumb—that at the time the working party was considering its review of sugar industry issues, including the tariff and the single desk and so on, they had to make a choice between the single desk and the tariff. Indeed, the witnesses before our committee said, `Look, if we have to choose between one or the other, we will go with the single desk.' I am sure Senator Woodley and Senator O'Brien will remember that being said. They believed, as was said, that they had a gun at their heads on this issue.

That all occurred between October 1995 and when the working party did its work up until, as Senator Parer said, the report was released in November 1996. The Senate committee, which met in the last few months to look specifically at this issue and this legislation, is the most up‐to‐date position you have.What came out from Mr Katter's evidence was that people were under a misapprehension. They were under the thumb—they thought they had to make this choice between the tariff or the single desk. Further on in his evidence, Mr Katter said:

After the report of the working party, assurances were given by the Queensland government that the single desk was not at risk, that it would stay and that is something that the Australian Labor Party in Queensland is committed to, and that the coalition parties in Queensland are committed to, so whichever government was in power ultimately at any time in the state government in Queensland growers could be guaranteed the single desk would continue.
Mr Katter went on and said:

So, the deregulation of the sugar industry is not on the table. There is no reason for us to make this decision because of that. That is not on the table unless the federal coalition, the federal opposition, the state coalition, the state opposition and the other political parties in Australia are all telling the most flagrant, outrageous lies. It is not on the table. So if it is not on the table, why the hell are we abolishing the tariff?
Senator Woodley said:
So it really is not a choice between the single desk or the tariff, they are not alternatives?
Mr Katter said:

No, definitely not. That is not now the situation. However, and I have to say this because I went public at the time and backed the sugar review, I believe that they most certainly had that problem, the sugar review.
I cannot blame them for making this decision. If I had been there with Ron Verri and Harry Bonanno, I am pretty certain I would have done exactly what they did.
Senator Woodley said:
So that is the gun at the head thing?
Mr Katter:
Yes, definitely.

That makes it abundantly clear that, at the time, the cane farmers felt they were in that position as were their representatives. So, Senator Parer, they did come down with that recommendation, but you have to look at the circumstances that surrounded it. It is no response to stand up here and say, `Oh well, they had the review,' and because they had a review and, because they made the recom mendation, that gave you the out to change your policy.

Why is it that the coalition can say that they were able to change their policy because of the wishes of the working party, but when the growers come along later and say, `Hang on a minute; we actually believe that the original recommendation was wrong, and it was based upon a false premise,' how come they are not allowed to say their position has changed? If you, the government, say that you are entitled to change your position from a policy put before the last election, why don't you give the same right to the growers who came along to the Senate committee and said, `Hang on a minute, Parliament.'

What you are relying upon in terms of their support for the working party is falsely based and is no longer the position, if it ever was. That is the real hypocrisy. You want the luxury of being able to say, as Senator Boswell said, that you changed your policy position because you were asked to. But when you were asked later on to stick with the original position because those people were misled in the first place, you said, `Sorry, fellas, it's too late. We'll hold you to your first recommendation but we will not allow you to rely upon the evidence you gave to the Senate committee.' This is not some Labor Party beat-up. This is what Mr Katter said and this is what other members of the National Party clearly also believe.

Finally, the other point in all of this, to add weight to it, is that the position has changed. There has not just been a change in terms of the people coming to realise that they were forced into making a choice which they should not have had to make between the single desk selling system and tariffs, but also we should look at the evidence given by Mr Allison from the Australian Cane Farmers Association. He said:

The sugar tariff as it stood more than met Australia's obligations to the World Trade Organisation, another point we would like to make. However, the federal government policy in relation to the reduction and/or removal of tariffs appears to have shifted, and that is very obvious. That is borne out by recent decisions in relation to the motor vehicle industry, and the clothing and footwear and textile industry. The question has been asked by our members: why should the sugar industry bite the bullet when any reciprocity it might have expected in relation to cost reductions in other industries will now obviously not be passed on owing to a shift in federal government policy?

That is a fair and legitimate question. Government, quite rightly—it had to be pushed before it reached the right decision with respect to the TCF and the vehicle industries—changed its position. If the members of the Liberal Party cannot bring themselves to it, at least members of the National Party may now have the courage to change their position on this issue and support our amendment to retain the tariff in the sugar industry.

PARA.TAB: That the request (Senator Forshaw's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
Clause 2, page 2 (lines 3 and 4), omit subclause (5), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (5) Items 1 to 5 of Schedule 4 commence 10 days after the Minister for the Environment has tabled in the Senate a report from the relevant authority or authorities certifying that there are sufficient regulatory and enforcement measures in place to ensure that:

TAB.TAB: (a) the habitat of threatened or endangered species will not be affected by clearing under the Sugar Industry Infrastructure Program or for any other reason related to the growing or production of sugar; and
(b) that wetlands are protected from such clearing; and
(c) that fisheries are protected from such clearing and its consequences; and
(d) that the Great Barrier Reef is fully protected from the impact of such clearing or from the growing and milling of sugar; and
(e) that all the Commonwealth's responsibilities to protect habitat, species, wetlands and world heritage areas are fulfilled with respect to:
(i) the Biodiversity Convention; and
(ii) the World Conservation Strategy; and
(iii) the Ramsar Convention; and
(iv) the World Heritage Convention; and
(f) that measures are in place to ensure that:
(i) any clearing on existing sugar cane farms is consistent with best landcare practice; and
(ii) clearing of marginal lands for cane farming will not occur; and
(iii) that the result of reducing profits and increasing competitive pressures for farmers will not result in negative environmental impacts.

PARA.TAB: (5A) Items 6 to 84 of schedule 4 commence, or are taken to have commenced, on 1 July 1997.

SPEECH.PARA: My request is for a change to the commencement of the tariff reduction segment of this bill, should the bill be passed. I outlined in my speech during the second reading debate a number of the problems about knowing whether the outcome of the tariff reduction would impose direct environmental costs in Australia as well as general global environmental costs and any indirect costs associated with free trade that we know it will impose.

Since the issue of direct environmental costs is uncertain, I am seeking with this amendment to ensure that unforeseen costs will be minimal. I am attempting to do so by tying the commencement of this measure to the fulfilment of Commonwealth duties, which the government should be fulfilling anyway. I do not see this as an impossible request; I see this as an explicit assurance that the government will fulfil the duties that already exist.

In my proposed subclause 5, I place the responsibility to report to the Senate where it belongs, which is in the hands of the Minister for the Environment whose duty is at least to protect our natural heritage, the diversity and integrity of the ecological system, for the people of Australia. The minister also has a duty to ensure that people are not endangered or affected badly by environmental pollution. I do not ask for an impossibility. The minister has certain responsibilities under Commonwealth law and under international agreements and I ask that there be sufficient regulatory and enforcement measures in place to ensure that these responsibilities can be met.

Once the minister reports to the Senate that this is in place, the sugar tariff section commences after 10 days, a period which allows some feedback and questions. That is a fairly rapid response. It is only a major delay if the government has not got such measures in place and must put them in place and, in that case, I would have to say any delay is appropriate and responsible to get the regulatory framework right. If it is not there, I guess you would wonder what the government was doing anyway.

In my proposed subclause 5(a), my request refers to the need to protect threatened or endangered species. There are a number of such species in Queensland, particularly in the rainforest and mangrove areas being cleared. The mahogany glider is one such species but there are a range of other species: the cassowary, the Proserpine rock wallaby, the Apollo jewel butterfly, the black‐necked stork, the eastern curlew and the cotton pygmy goose, as well as orchids and other plants.

But the issue is not just in regard to the direct clearing of habitat. Clearing of mangroves and wetlands releases acid from soils and these are often released in conjunction with other minerals disturbed. These react with aluminium and manganese and heavy metals such as cadmium. Both the acids and the metallic compounds get washed into the wetlands and offshore areas, killing aquatic, wetland and shoreland plants and seagrass, being concentrated up to 1,500 times in filter‐feeders and the gills of some fish and creating bioconcentrations of toxins—which we have seen or heard of in relation to red spot; basically the fish is almost rotting away in front of us—and the death of habitat and the direct poisoning of animals, including those up the food chain, such as the threatened dugong.

It should be obvious to anyone who knows anything about nature or possesses even reasonable intelligence that, if habitat clearance is affecting rare and endangered species, it is affecting ordinary species as well. In fact, one of the greatest critics of the expansion and clearing in relation to the sugar industry infrastructure program, or the SIIP, has been the fishing industry and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. Both recognise that the impact of the clearing is often devastating to fisheries. Fish spawning areas and coral reef ecologies are focused on the rare and endangered species because they are the ones the Commonwealth has powers to protect although it has powers in relation to some areas of great significance, such as the Great Barrier Reef. But it is important to understand that, while my amendment focuses on specific species and regions, a response adequate to protect them will have a marked effect in terms of protecting other more common species.

Paragraphs (b), (c) and (d) specifically look at protecting wetlands, fisheries and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park from sugar related clearing and sugar production. This is important since clearing results in the activation of potential acid soils into actual acid sulfate soils. While Canegrowers, the growers association, thinks clearing wetlands gets you into more trouble than it is worth and is opposed to the clearing of wetlands, the SIIP and Queensland government appear to be clearing in the interest of sugar expansion. While it may not be cleared for sugar, there does appear to be clearing of hundreds of hectares of coastal wetland in North Queensland for sugar infrastructure under the SII scheme. This particular scheme involves the diverting of the Murray River into the Tully River.

The complaints came in from all sectors after clearing of massive areas of protected habitat occurred last July. These included complaints from the head of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and the director of the Australian Marine Conservation Society, who said the state government would:
. . . put one of Australia's best wetlands under threat for a proposal that doesn't even sound like good engineering.

I wonder if this is one of the reasons why the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority are under threat from the government at the moment—because they spoke up. It would create more problems for the sugar industry than it would solve. General manager of Canegrowers, Ian Ballantyne, said:
I'd swear on a stack of bibles we are not involved and would not countenance clearance of wetlands.
Mr Veitch, deputy chairman of Sunfish, said:

It's like an atomic bomb going off. It's both economic and environmental vandalism. We're talking about ruining areas that are the breeding grounds for juvenile barramundi, mangrove jack and a whole range of (fish) species, not to mention species like the mahogany glider and the cassowary.

This particular bit of clearing happened two months after another outcry at state government plans to drain thousands of hectares of tropical wetlands between Cairns and Townsville to aid the sugar industry under the SIIP.
Dr McPhail, chair of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, said:

What we're concerned about is that, in the development of sugar cane, the costs of the loss of habitat, and the recreational amenity, and the economic benefits through the fishing industry, appear not to have been taken into account.

He outlined again the dangers of the cumulative effect of land clearing on the Great Barrier Reef—on habitat; acid sulfate release, which was linked to massive fish kills; the depletion of fish nurseries; damage to seagrass beds, with effects on dugongs and turtles; and damage to commercial fishing grounds. Again, the Canegrowers representative said they did not know of the plans meant to benefit them and:
Certainly wetlands are not favoured areas for going into as far as cane production goes.

My conclusion is that the state government is proceeding with clearing on the basis that big infrastructure projects are really good and that there is no need to consider either the environmental costs or the views of the industry that infrastructure is meant to serve. This is particularly why I think it will not matter whether there is a tariff or not in that respect or whether the sugar industry is doing well or badly. This is a state program with its own moment and objectives.

Although the damage and outrage were reported in the Australian in both instances I cited in relation to habitat clearing, and in other major papers at the time and on national network television, when asked by Senator Lees on 7 May, the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill, responded on 17 June that he knew of no problems with the SIIPs, which are partially funded by the Commonwealth, and of no problems with the mahogany glider, although the Commonwealth funds a rescue package.

Paragraph (e) of my amendment ties the Commonwealth to fulfilling its responsibilities under the various international agreements, including the biodiversity convention, which protects species; the world conservation strategy, under which both species and representative habitats are to be preserved; the Ramsar convention, which is for the protection of wetlands and includes Bowling Green Bay in Queensland and the Ord and Lake Argyle areas in Western Australia; and the World Heritage Convention, under which the Great Barrier Reef is listed. All of these are currently being affected by sugar production.

I am not saying this is the fault of cane growers. If they are honest—and it is difficult to maintain a lie in the public eye—then they actually do not support the environmental damage being done purportedly for their benefit. I accept that. The Commonwealth has a duty to ensure that such damage does not continue when it is clearly in the province of the Commonwealth and within Commonwealth powers to prevent or stop such damage.

Paragraph (f) of my request for an amendment would ensure that measures were in place to ensure that the outcome of this tariff elimination did not mean that growers were struggling and may be tempted or economically forced to use more exploitative practices in growing. Again, land care is a major issue, dealt with under the auspices of the Commonwealth. Rural adjustment schemes are also under effective Commonwealth control. One manifestation of the problem may be farming in areas which are marginal rather than rehabilitating or planting in these areas.

Another manifestation is excessive water use in areas where ground water is used. The water table is sometimes drawn down to the extent that surrounding areas are affected. In coastal areas, it may be drawn down to the extent that saltwater incursions result and the ground water becomes tainted and brackish.

BREAK.PARA: Yet another manifestation may be the attempt to use extra fertilisers, pesticides and herbicides rather than risk losing any production from more environmentally sound levels. Farmers will not use more than they think they need, especially where money is short. But they are uncertain about the effect on sugar yield of reduction of agrochemicals. They will also play it safe and use more rather than less if they are under pressure.

In short, there are a number of pressing environmental problems in relation to the sugar industry. In spite of that, it is expanding in Queensland and there are proposals for expansion in Western Australia along the Ord and Fitzroy rivers. The federal government does have powers to protect the environment and so can act in at least some of these cases. My amendment asks it to assure the Senate that it is acting, that it is checking for compliance with any reasonable conditions and frameworks it is setting and that it has the ability and will to control breaches. I do not think this is unreasonable. It is asking the government to do what it should be doing in any case. I commend my amendment to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to endorse this amendment. It is quite tough. It would create extraordinarily onerous conditions for the government, only because the application of environmental rigour is not something that has ever been part of the national government's agenda.

SPEECH.PARA: The implementation of the biodiversity convention, the World Heritage Convention and the Ramsar convention to protect wetlands, for example, ought to be a thing that is automatic. Instead of that, the continued expansion of cane fields in Queensland—and potentially from the Ord—involves the filling of wetlands, the loss of mangroves, the loss of streamside reserves and the process of pushing towards extinction rare and endangered species, many of which are not well known.

I reiterate that just two years ago I was in the area of Ayr and Home Hill and was distressed to see broadacre clearing of land where rare and endangered orchids and butterflies were. There was no investigation, no setting aside of habitat and no protection that could be seen as scientifically or socially responsible. There is a lot to be put in order as far as the industry's expansion is concerned.

I have already given the committee the figure of some 400,000 hectares of land cleared over the last five years. There is the potential for that sort of awesome rate to continue into the future. The industry has been helped along by a quite sizeable injection of Commonwealth assistance through irrigation schemes. Without that, much of the expansion could not proceed. As I said yesterday, the time to discuss the environment has to be when bills like this Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) come before us. They are essentially about such matters as tariffs and the ability of the industry to progress and expand domestically as well as in overseas markets. There is an ineluctable tie between the expansion of an industry like this and the regression of environment. That is what is occurring at a rapid rate.

The implementation of do‐it‐if‐you‐will guidelines does not work. It requires government regulation if the national heritage and all that goes with that is to be protected. The magnificence of the diverse ecosystems of much of the eastern coastline of Queensland, for example, is in tatters, due to rapid expansion not just of sugarcane but of a whole variety of modern interests. To protect what is left of those ecosystems and to protect the national interest requires at least as much effort in terms of legislation as is being put into recognising the benefits that can flow to the sugar industry from good regulation. One requires government action; so ought the other. What Senator Margetts is presenting to the Senate here is an effort to say, `Let us look at the environmental side of the good health of this industry and, therefore, at the good interests of local communities and at the national concern for the deteriorating national estate in this country.'

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will be supporting the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bartlett, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —When I was last speaking in the second reading debate on the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Parenting and Other Measures) Bill 1997 I was interrupted by question time, and I note I have four minutes to go before I get interrupted again. So I will try to compound my remarks and finish before we hit matters of public interest, which I am sure will be a matter of great regret to everyone.

SPEECH.PARA: Previously, I was saying that one of the main thrusts of this bill is to reduce the stigma attached to the sole parent pension. I indicated the Australian Democrats' broad support for that and our concern at the very large stigma that repeatedly was being heaped on welfare recipients around the nation through the media by what can only be described as an overblown and inaccurate series of articles, over a protracted period, which implied that there was a very large problem of fraud and cheating out there involving many hundreds of thousands of people.

The Democrats believe it is important that that myth be dispelled. We ask the government, if they are serious about reducing the stigma attached to welfare recipients, to speak out a bit more strongly against some of those misleading media reports rather than, as it appears from time to time, fuel them. I simply make that plea to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) in relation to that issue.

Certainly, when the peak welfare body in this country, the Australian Council of Social Service, dared to suggest that the overpayment figures were being dishonestly presented, it got a fairly heavy bagging from the minister for its troubles. The minister reportedly said that ACOSS was putting its head in the sand in saying that there were no people cheating.

I want to put it on the record that the Democrats, as well as ACOSS, I am sure, are not claiming that there is no cheating. None of us supports people who commit deliberate fraud on our welfare system. However, the Democrats are saying that there needs to be an honest representation of the level of fraud that is being committed and reports that have been pumped out in the media over recent months are not an accurate and honest representation of the level of fraud. The reasons for overpayments are numerous, but the important point is that the overwhelming majority are not the result of deliberate actions taken by people who are intent on defrauding the Commonwealth. I suggest that most are due to honest mistakes under an extremely complicated system. Again, I use that to reaffirm the Democrats' support for moves that reduce the complication of our social security system.

The Democrats will be moving a number of amendments in the committee stage on a few issues, and I will speak to those at that time rather than go on about them now. I certainly hope that the bill before us goes some way towards reducing the social stigma that may be attached to sole parents and that it leads in some way to reducing the complexity of the welfare system, although I am not convinced that it achieves that aim. I look forward to the minister taking proactive steps to address any similar stigma that attaches to other social security recipients in general.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security Legislation Amendment (Parenting and Other Measures) Bill 1997 is, for the most part, nothing but a further attack on one of the cornerstones of our society: the family. Families are being slugged with extra costs for child care, extra costs for aged care and extra costs for medical care as a result of this government's—
