SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 November this year, the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee handed down its report on the constitutionality of the Native Title Amendment Bill. Throughout its hearings and afterwards, certain elements in the media were engaged in a shameless misrepresentation of the facts. This was done either deliberately or through gross ignorance. Unfortunately, I think it may have been the former.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason I raise these misrepresentations is threefold: firstly, to set the record straight; secondly, and, more importantly, to try to disabuse the minds of those representatives of the media who might actually believe what they have written or broadcast; and, thirdly, to request that those involved in the media stop and think of the harm they are doing by adding to the divisiveness of the debate by making the comments that they are making.

In seeking to set the record straight, I am fortified in the knowledge that one's standing as a parliamentarian, low though it may be corporately, is still well ahead of media representatives whom I wish to take to task today. The committee was requested by the Senate to look at the constitutionality of the Native Title Amendment Bill, a proper course of action and a very timely one, given that it appears every taxi driver and parish priest has become a constitutional expert overnight.

The committee was very fortunate to hear from many legal experts, in particular, Dr Gavan Griffith QC, who has been involved in approximately 200 constitutional cases. He happens to be of the view that the legislation is constitutional. As Dr Griffith advised, on one occasion he was in the High Court with 16 counsel against him but he still went on to win the day. It is not a question of the quantity of the legal advice but the quality of the legal advice that ought be checked up on and that will ultimately determine the issues.

The quality of Dr Griffith's advice is recognised by all, I would suggest even by his opponents. Dr Griffith QC was in good company: David Bennett QC, the then President of the New South Wales Bar Association, along with Dennis Rose QC. How were these eminent legal opinions reported in the media? We had stories such as this one that appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald:
The NSW Bar Association, requested by the Federal Government to give evidence—
of course it wasn't; it was the committee that requested them to give evidence, not the federal government—
on its Wik legislation, has advised that it is unconstitutional, further undermining the Government's claims to pastoralists that its 10-Point Plan would create certainty.
Further on the Sydney Morning Herald reported:

The committee chairman, Senator Eric Abetz, Liberal, asked for submissions from the Bar Association and the Government's former chief general counsel, Mr Dennis Rose, QC, now with Blake Dawson Waldron.
The Bar Association president, Mr David Bennett, QC, and Mr Rose advised that the legislation probably was unconstitutional.
As soon as Mr Bennett gave his evidence, he opened up his comments to the committee by saying that that report in the Sydney Morning Herald was incorrect.

I spoke to Mr Dennis Rose QC, who agreed that I put on record—and I did so on page 326 of the Hansard—that he did not agree with the way that his views had been presented in the media. Mr Dennis Rose QC and Mr David Bennett QC were of the view that the legislation was constitutionally valid.

In my own home newspaper the Hobart Mercury said that it was argued by all but two of the legal opinions sought by the committee. Clearly that was wrong. There was Dr Gavan Griffith QC, Mr Jackson QC, Mr Bennett QC and Mr Rose QC. That is at least four. Where did the journalists get this misinformation from? By regurgitating the Labor Party press release that was put out on this issue.

My concern is that the public have got a raft of misinformation courtesy of Labor press releases in relation to this committee inquiry. But I believe there are certain journalists who have taken a particular view of this legislation and have written all these stories accordingly, irrespective of the facts. But worse was still to come.

When the committee handed down its report, I issued a media release entitled `Native Title Amendment Bill—Constitutional', in big bold type face on top of the media release. But all the stories in the media the very next day were that we as a committee had found that the legislation was unconstitutional. The Sydney Morning Herald were at it again. They put more spin on the report than Shane Warne could muster on his best day. For the record, let me read the conclusions of the committee:
The Committee is of the view that, on balance, the High Court would find that the Bill is constitutionally valid.
Nothing I submit could be clearer. In relation to just terms compensation, we stated that we thought it may be of benefit for the minister to:
. . . review the relevant provisions . . . to confirm that the legislation meets the constitutional requirement for the acquisition of property on just terms.
I would have thought that was pretty simple, pretty precise and pretty clear.

But what galls me is that this misinformation just kept on being put out that somehow this report did not support the constitutionality of the legislation. Then what happens? We hear this myth being reported on the John Laws program. I am not a listener to the John Laws program, I hasten to add, but when it was reported to my office I rang the producer of his show. I said, `I happen to be the chairman of this committee. This is not what the committee found. What made John Laws say that on his program this morning?'

Guess where they got it from? By reading the Sydney Morning Herald. It tells a very sorry tale about the media—that they feed off each other—and the authority for that misinformation being spread to literally hundreds of thousands of Australians was the misinformation in an article in the Sydney Morning Herald. There was no research, no consideration and no reading of the report—just a simple regurgitation of an article in a newspaper became the authority for John Laws to announce to his hundreds of thousands of listeners that this report did something different from what it actually did. Unfortunately, the disinformation spreads.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did they correct it?

—No, it was not corrected. Although they kindly did take my number, they never rang back to allow me to correct the issue on air. Some might say that I am somewhat overcritical of the media in relation to this event but, unfortunately, I have seen it in relation to native title in virtually every single aspect. But today I am limiting my comments to the Senate report.

SPEECH.PARA: What am I supposed to make of a journalist who deliberately misquotes the report in trying to put questions to me? I refer to the World Today program where I was asked a number of questions by Catherine Job, and the transcript makes very interesting reading. Catherine Job said to me, `But you've recommended that amendments be made.' There was not a single suggestion for an amendment in our report. I answered, `No, we haven't made any suggestions for any amendments.' Why would she put that to me?

She then goes on to ask, `So what does this mean—' and purports to quote the report when she says, `The committee recommends that these possible deficiencies are not only fundamental flaws, but may be easily remedied by amending the bill.' What does the report actually say? Page 43 of the report says:
The Committee notes:
. . . the view that these possible deficiencies are not—
I stress `not'—
fundamental flaws but may be easily remedied by amending the Bill—

All we were doing was saying that some people had come forward with this particular view that it was not a fundamental flaw and we suggest the minister might have a look at those opinions. But there was a deliberate misquote when she asserted on the program:
So what does this mean: `The committee recommends that these possible deficiencies are not only fundamental flaws, but may be easily remedied by amending the Bill'?

That was a complete misquote of the report and, unfortunately, the thousands of Australians listening to that program would have thought that she was quoting correctly and that I was back‐pedalling. The truth is she was not quoting the report; she was misquoting the report; and I believe she did a great injustice to the profession of journalism within this country. She was trying to put words into the mouth of the committee which were the exact opposite of what was actually said.

Such a complete misrepresentation of the facts, I have got to say, is totally and utterly unacceptable from those who purport to be professional journalists advising this country on such an important social issue as native title. It does the journalists personally no credit. It does their profession as a whole no credit. But, more importantly, it misinforms the public whom they are supposed to be serving in disseminating the information that comes out of this Parliament House. So it is with a great degree of regret that I have had to put these matters on the public record.

I find it very distasteful that, when you have got eminent QCs such as Mr Bennett and Mr Rose giving of their time voluntarily—no money whatsoever being paid to them in making their submission—they have their submission so distorted and misrepresented in the media. All that that does, I suggest to my friends in the media, is to add to the confusion within the public mind about the whole sensitive issue of native title. Let us have a good discussion about the issues involved, let us keep the hyperbole out of it and let us deal with the facts. But misrepresenting QCs who give their time on an honorary basis—voluntarily, free of charge, for a cause that they happen to believe in—just to score points, and for others to seek to misquote the report—

TALK.START.PARA: —As long as they don't work at the Law Reform Commission—eh, Eric?

—Senator Conroy, I suggest to you that, if you want to keep interjecting, you might be well advised to listen to legal opinion and learn from it. If you did, you might not find yourself in the trouble you find yourself in before this Senate at the very moment—and you know what I am referring to. So, Senator Conroy, I suggest that you desist interjecting, otherwise you might tempt me even further.

BREAK.PARA: To conclude, the misrepresentation of QCs' advice to the committee is unacceptable. Then the writing up of the committee report in such a dishonest fashion is also unacceptable and is a great disservice to the Australian community who have a right to expect that when journalists report these things they will do so in an honest and forthright manner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 November last year the new National Party of Australia headquarters were opened in Canberra. The three storey building, named Sir John McEwen House, was opened by Sir John's widow Mary. The National Party moved in. It was on the move. It was in government. It had a new building and the future looked bright. A year later, nearly to the day, the National Party announced that it would virtually close down its national secretariat. The five Canberra based staff were given notice to quit by the end of the year. There were rumours that the new building may have to be sold. As you would expect, they have been denied. The National Party's federal Treasurer and former member for Gwydir, Mr Ralph Hunt, blamed the depression in Canberra for the National Party's financial crisis, the same crisis that Senator Ian Campbell in a speech in Western Australia described as a `fantastic achievement', a statement that his office told the media at 10.30 a.m. on Monday he stood by. A few hours later the Senate was informed that he had issued an apology.

SPEECH.PARA: Apology notwithstanding, the Howard government has waged war on Canberra with devastating effect. It has cut thousands of jobs from the public sector. Those job losses have affected every small business in the national capital. It has brought this economy to its knees. In doing so, it has plunged its coalition partner into a financial crisis less than two years after winning government, a financial crisis from which recovery will be difficult.

But the problem for the National Party is not only in Canberra. The level of financial support for the party in the bush has also waned. The problems in rural Australia, like Canberra, are of the National Party's own making. In opposition, the Deputy Leader of the National Party and then shadow minister for primary industries and energy, Mr Anderson, issued a promise a day. He said that the Howard government would give a clear direction to restore profitability and maximise trade opportunities for rural Australia. The future was one of extraordinary opportunity and excitement, he boasted. A Liberal-National Party government would provide and maintain the necessary impetus to ensure that that opportunity was realised. The promises from Mr Anderson and his optimism about what he could deliver in government displayed all the features of the John McEwen House venture—a grand opening, promising all things to all people, but delivery?—nothing.

On the question of the restructure of the Australian Wheat Board, at Grains Week `96 the minister outlined his plans for the grains industry. He said that three fundamental principles should guide the process. They were self-reliance, grower ownership and control of marketing, and fully commercial marketing. He was, in fact, progressing a policy initiative of the former government and the industry. In April of 1997, Mr Anderson announced a new commercial venture for wheat marketing. He said that on 1 July 1999 the Australian Wheat Board would be replaced by a grower owned company:
This will place ownership and control of marketing in the hands of the growers so the industry can control its own future.

The enabling legislation for the first stage of this process has just passed the Senate. The Labor Party sought to have the bill delayed, not necessarily because it was flawed, but because we wanted to see the details of the whole Australian Wheat Board restructuring package. We thought it appropriate that the parliament knew exactly what it was signing up to. We did not want to pass the first tranche of legislation and take the rest of the package on faith. After all, we are talking about a fundamental restructuring of a multi-billion dollar export industry.

A very large section of the industry agreed with this approach. The New South Wales Farmers Association was concerned about the future of grower control—one of the minister's three principles—if the model was progressed. Their concerns were ignored. They wanted an answer on how the government planned to tax the Wheat Industry Fund. They were told that an answer would be forthcoming. The Western Australian Farmers also wanted the taxation issue clarified before the process went any further. These two states account for 75 per cent of the nation's export wheat production.

The Australian Grain Industry Task Force also raised concerns. But Mr Anderson ignored them. Instead, with the aid of the Democrats, who chose to support the President of the Queensland Grain Growers Association rather than the rest of the country, Mr Anderson forced the bill through. Bad luck for the growers in Western Australia and bad luck for the growers in New South Wales. If their concerns about how the model might finally impact on grower control are realised, bad luck for wheat growers generally, because that is apparently the government's position on this matter. We are now told by the government that the taxation regime to apply to the new structure will not be known until some time next year. The government has its legislation through, so the industry can wait.

Then we come to the question of the AQIS charges. Last April Mr Anderson rightly identified the Australian meat industry as a sector crucial to our economic and social well-being. It generates $4 billion a year in export earnings and provides thousands of jobs, mainly in rural and regional areas. He also identified AQIS inspection charges as a significant component of meat processing costs. In the 1996 budget there was a subsidy to help meet the costs of AQIS inspection charges for the meat export sector. Again, Mr Anderson was following the approach of the former government by keeping inspection charges for the export sector at a reasonable level while the AQIS reform program was progressed. But in the last budget he was comprehensively done over in the Expenditure Review Committee of cabinet. Thanks to the Liberal dries, out went the subsidy and up went industry charges. In some cases, they jumped by 300 per cent.

The response of the processors was predictable. They would cover the increased the government charges through lower prices to producers. Gone was the process of progressive reform of the meat inspection service, and with it the progressive introduction of cost recovery to the industry. The government decided that the industry would not only have to meet the cost of its own restructuring but also pay directly for the costs of restructuring AQIS. As with Mr Anderson's approach to the Wheat Board restructure, the government had determined a course and the industry would have to wear it.

The industry surveyed its members and found both anger and economic difficulty. As I said earlier, some companies faced increases of up to 300 per cent. The minister then responded by attacking the industry, but he was eventually forced to back down because he had no choice. The cost increases he sought to impose on an industry recovering from very difficult market conditions would have been blocked in the Senate with the full support of every cattle producer and meat processor in the country.

So what of the beef industry? In May last year the minister announced early action to reform the meat industry. In fact, he was just progressing another Labor reform. Some 18 months later we are told that the reforms of the meat industry, earmarked for early action, are being developed. We were told by a senior departmental officer at the recent estimates hearings that no formal structures have been put in place yet `because of the need to develop structures'. We were told that the amount of funding required to progress the new arrangements, given high priority for early action last May, that is May of 1996, will depend on the agreements reached as to what companies will actually do. It seems that we are not even to first base on this matter. So much for the minister's commitment to maintaining the impetus for reform.

What of the pig industry? In June 1995 the minister gave a rousing speech in parliament in support of the pig industry. He identified two key issues: the question of effective labelling of product must be fixed, and anti-dumping arrangements had to be improved. He described Australia's labelling laws as totally inadequate. He said that Labor's handling of the issue was a disgrace. He said that he would fix it, that it would be given priority on his reform agenda. So what has happened on anti-dumping laws? Nothing. What has happened on country-of-origin food labelling? Nothing. All this minister has done for the pig industry since March last year is approve more imports and threaten to kill off export opportunities by ramping up export inspection charges. He did not even get the risk assessment process for these applications right. The public health risk assessment for imported cooked Canadian pig meat at the request of the pig producers was reviewed by the food science division of the CSIRO and found to be inadequate. The industry's concerns about aspects of that assessment remain unanswered to this day, despite the minister approving the application.

Nor did the assessment take into account a new disease found in the Canadian pigs, that is, post‐weaning multi-systemic wasting syndrome. AQIS officers were asked whether they could give an assurance that the protocols approved for Canadian pig meat would provide adequate protection against this disease. They said that no such assurance could be given because not enough was known about the disease. AQIS say they think it is okay but are not prepared to suspend protocol to make sure. Clearly, the minister is happy to take the risk.

Then there is the very important issue of Ovine Johnes disease in the Australian sheep flock. While Ovine Johnes is having its greatest impact in New South Wales and Victoria, its eradication is a national problem that requires a national solution. The minister's response is:
It is a question of the state government and their various instrumentalities as well as industry agreeing to a national approach.
Later he said:
. . . a watertight case with national agreement is a prerequisite to me being able to reasonably put this before the Commonwealth government.

This disease is causing great hardship to many farmers and the minister is walking away from the issue. He says he is not interested in helping unless all the states and all industry come to him with a unified position. He did not apply that test to wheat. He simply ignored the views of the vast majority of growers. He did not apply the test to AQIS charges. This time he ignored the whole industry.

Finally, I wish to comment on the minister's centrepiece—`Agriculture—Advancing Australia', or the integrated rural policy package. This package is little more than a rebadging of the suite of rural programs developed by the former government. There is little new money—the NFF estimated only about $30 million a year. The key initiative in the package, the three year moratorium of gifting provisions, was exposed as almost impossible to qualify for. According to the Department of Social Security, only 600 people out of the 10,000 expected to apply will qualify.

Like the new Sir John McEwen House, this minister promised much but has delivered little. Is it any wonder rural Australians are as disillusioned with the Howard government as their city cousins? I remind the Senate that this is the minister who went to the last election pledging to revive the heartland. Given his appalling track record, it is little wonder that many people in the bush are asking one simple question: where is the resuscitator?

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Party of Australia Native Title

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —One is tempted to make comment on some of the wildly inaccurate statements we have just heard from Senator O'Brien.
—Well, do so.

—I am happy to do so. One of the interesting things about Senator O'Brien is that he has never, in his brief time here in parliament, let a bit of fact—even the tiniest bit of fact—get in the way of his ALP propaganda machine. Some of the comments he has made about the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) are outrageous. The suggestion that the `Agriculture—Advancing Australia' package was a rebadging of Labor Party policies is outrageous, and Senator O'Brien knows it. It is outrageous because this government has committed in excess of $200 million more to assistance for primary industry than the previous government ever did. If that is a rebadging, it must be the biggest rebadging in the history of this nation. It must be the biggest political rebadging that this nation has ever seen.
—Nonsense.

—All Senator O'Brien can do is sit on the other side chamber and say `Nonsense.' Senator O'Brien, `nonsense' is the correct word but it is best applied as a description of your own contribution because that is what you have treated the Senate to—utter nonsense. Everybody in rural Australia knows that this package, amongst other things, replaces the old and inefficient income equalisation deposits. Why were they inefficient? They were inefficient because the Labor Party gutted them when they got into government. Former senator Peter Walsh ensured that they were gutted. They will be replaced by a farm management deposit that will ensure that primary producers have 100 per cent deductibility for a contribution in the year in which they make it and that it is only taxed when the deposit is drawn down in times of hardship.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know how often Senator O'Brien goes around the bush, but I will tell you one thing: I have gone a long way around the bush in Queensland to discuss this, and everybody I have come across is unanimously in support of it. They see it as a massive improvement, and they see it as a wonderful opportunity for farmers to ensure their own financial viability. But Senator O'Brien, in all of his political bigotry, does not even brother to talk about those things. Why? Because it does not support his biased view of the world. We know what Senator O'Brien's view of the world is.
Senator Conroy interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Conroy, I understand they were going to name a suburb after you, but they decided that you were not worth it. Then they considered naming a street after you, Senator Conroy, but they could not find one narrow and twisted enough. We have had enough of your interjections, Senator Conroy. You cannot make a decent speech; you will never make a decent interjection. In fact, I think Senator Conroy will probably just go down as an interjection in the political history of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: What I rose to speak of today was, in fact, a matter of quite significant importance and some controversy in the wider community—and that is the assistance which this government is providing, and which has been supported by the opposition, to ensure that the economies of some of our major trading partners are kept in good order. Principally, we are talking about Thailand and Indonesia.

There are some outrageous suggestions going around Australia, both in the bush and in the cities, for example—Senator Conroy will be aware of these—claims such as, if we can `give' $1.4 billion to Indonesia, why cannot we `give' money to this cause or that cause, such as the aged, or whatever? The truth is that we are not `giving' any money in this case to anybody.

Honourable senators opposite, such as Senator McKiernan, will well know that I have been very critical of foreign aid and I remain sceptical about much foreign aid. I am very concerned when we give money away to multilateral organisations because I do not really believe we necessarily get value for money back. Also, I believe that often the money does not go to the people who need it.

But this is not a gift of money. Let me make it very clear while we are on broadcast today, so that people out there understand exactly what the government is doing. Principally, in the cases of Thailand and Indonesia, we are involved in a currency swap. What is a currency swap? Basically, we take some of our reserves, being either Australian dollar reserves or US dollar reserves, and we convert them into the local currency. For example, in the case of Indonesia, we take money from the Reserve Bank, we convert it into rupiah and we have a hedge—that is, a right to convert the money back into Australian dollars at a future date at a set rate. So there is no risk to the Reserve Bank of the currency deteriorating and the Reserve Bank losing out.

So, as I have said, we convert it at a set rate. What does that do? It ensures that the value of the rupiah is maintained at a high level; in other words, that the value of the rupiah does not tumble any further. Why is that important?Let me explain why that is important. If the rupiah tumbles, then the Indonesians will be less able to afford the things we sell them and, importantly, they are more likely to be competitors in our own domestic market with the things that they produce.

We all know about the dangers of import penetration; we all know about the dangers of imports coming in, attacking our backyard. I do not think that point needs to be stressed any further. If the rupiah goes down, it makes it more possible for the Indonesians to come in and steal our own backyard. We do not want that. Everybody is agreed on that.

But why is it important to keep the rupiah high so that we can sell them the things that we produce? From my state's point of view, it is very simple: without this package, we will write some $½ billion—that is, $500 million—off the exports of the state of Queensland in the next year. Queensland, more than any other state, stands to lose if we cannot continue to trade with Indonesia on the current basis. Let me give the Senate and those who are listening some simple figures to show why this is the case.

Last year we exported from Australia $213 million of live cattle, most of which came from North Queensland and the Northern Territory—$213 million of live cattle. We also exported $42 million of beef, on top of that $213 million of live cattle. All of that beef, I understand, came from Queensland. So I am talking of $42 million of beef, and the lion's share of $213 million of live cattle. But that is just the tip of the iceberg.

Additional to that, we exported $300 million of cotton, most of which came from southern Queensland and northern New South Wales; $132 million of alumina, which has principally come from Gladstone in Queensland; $94 million of copper, which has principally come either from Broken Hill or, I understand, mainly from Mount Isa and Townsville. So you can see just there, before you even take into consideration the impact of other things—for example, the estimated $½ billion of wheat from all around Australia—that, if we cannot ensure that the Indonesians can continue to afford to buy the sorts of things that we produce, Queensland and Queenslanders will be the losers.

This package is as much about assisting Australians and Australian jobs as it is about assisting Indonesia. That is why the opposition has supported it. I congratulate the opposition, and I appreciate its bipartisan support on these things. Everybody or nearly everybody in this parliament understands that if we cannot sell the things that we produce there will be no jobs for Australians, there will be no jobs for Queenslanders and there will be no future for primary industry.

The people who oppose this package are people who are saying to us and to the Australian population, `We oppose exports; we oppose selling other people things to ensure that we keep getting money flowing through to Australia.' That is what opposition to this package is about; it is about opposing Australian exports and opposing Australian jobs. That is all that those who oppose the package will achieve. They will achieve economic destruction here and they will not do a damned thing for the people over in Indonesia. It will not do them any good and it will not do us any good. But I suppose that is their short-sighted vision of this country.

It is a fact that, in primary industry on the whole, Australia produces five times more than it can eat—five times more than it can consume. So, if we say that we are just going to turn our back on the world, if we say we are going to pretend that the rest of the world does not exist, we are going to have a major problem. We will be producing five times the amount of food that we can eat—and nobody else is going to be buying it off us.

Is that an intelligent way to deal with this country's economy? Is that an intelligent way to deliver real hope and real opportunity for people who live outside the capital cities, be they the farmers, the meat workers, the shearers, or whatever—the people of regional and rural Australia? What hope do they have if their prices are cruelled? How many farm families will be forced off the land, how many meat workers will lose their jobs, because some people in this parliament have decided that they want to turn their backs on the world?

If we say that we will only bother about feeding ourselves and not worry about the opportunities overseas, this nation will be an economic ruin. Every Australian primary producer will tell you that we need those export dollars, we need those export opportunities and we need to maintain our share of those markets.

I will tell you this: leaving morality aside, if we do not participate in this bailout package, there are other countries that will—and the countries that will participate in the bailout package are our competitors. They will do it for one simple reason. They will step up to the plate and say, `We'll help you, even though Australia won't, because we're your real friends.' When the economic situation in Thailand recovers, and when the economic situation in Indonesia recovers, as they will, will these countries want to buy from us then—or will they say, with justification, `You're not our real friends; you're our fair-weather friends'? That is what they will say, and they will be primed to say that by our trade competitors who will be part of the bailout package when we are not.

That is what is at stake when we talk about the bailout of Thailand and Indonesia. We are not giving these countries money. We are not frittering away the taxpayers' dollar. And we are not obsessed with the wellbeing of people overseas at the expense of Australians. In fact, this bailout package protects the taxpayers' dollar by ensuring that primary industries that are currently paying tax because they make a profit will continue to make a profit and will continue to pay tax in the future. It protects all Australians by protecting those primary industries. It protects the tax revenue of this country. It protects jobs. It protects export markets.

In spite of all of this, Mr Acting Deputy President Hogg, there are still some people—most notably, one person from our state—who are so blind to what this is really about that they oppose keeping jobs for Queenslanders.

TALK.START.PARA: —She will come back and haunt you if you're not careful.

—Senator McKiernan, I am happy for my words to go on the record. You know me; I have been in this place for a long time. I am happy for my words to go on the record at any time. On this particular matter, I am very happy for my words to go on the record—because, if we do not ensure the stability of the rupiah in Indonesia, if we do not ensure the stability of the Thai baht, it is Queensland that loses. If the Thai baht plunges, then the companies in Queensland, the manufacturers of sugarcane harvesting equipment, are the ones that lose because they lose the Thai export orders. If the Indonesian rupiah falls, again it will be Queenslanders who lose; the citrus industry in Mundubbera will lose, as they are losing at the moment because of lost export orders. That is what this is all about.

SPEECH.PARA: I see that Senator Bishop has entered the chamber. He is a good economist, and he would understand this very basic principle: we need to maintain a situation where our exports to these countries are affordable. Most notably, of course, we also need to maintain a situation where their exports to us do not undercut Australian industries. Thailand is a major sugar competitor on the international market. We do not want a situation where Thai sugar becomes extremely cheap.

TALK.START.PARA: —We need an industry plan to upgrade the quality of our exports.
—We may well need an industry plan, Senator Bishop. But we have not seen an industry plan from your side of parliament; we did not see one when you were in government. That is one of the reasons why—
—Their plan was to put up interest rates.

—It is exactly as Senator Campbell says: their industry plan was to put up interest rates. Our industry plan has been to reduce industry rates. As a consequence of our industry plan, Senator Bishop, this country's economy is in better shape than it has been for 25 years. As a consequence of our industry plan, as a consequence of reductions in interest rates, this country has been able to avoid the Asian currency crisis that has gripped other countries in the region.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by saying this: it is absolutely critical that this aid package receive the unanimous support of the Australian parliament, not because of some spirit of good neighbourliness, not because of some sense of morality. I am going to be quite base about this: it is important that this package receive unanimous support to guarantee, to safeguard, the jobs of Australians. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —My intervention into this debate today is prompted by comments made earlier by Senator Abetz in the debate on a matter of public interest. At that time he raised matters contained in the report of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee flowing from its consideration of the constitutional aspects of the national Native Title Amendment Bill 1997.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not rise with a brief from Margo Kingston of the Sydney Morning Herald, Catherine Job from the ABC or, indeed, John Laws. I do not believe I have spoken to any of those individuals at all this year. Senator Abetz's intervention here today was another desperate attempt, being made on behalf of the government, to get the government off the hook on that piece of racist legislation, the Native Title Amendment Bill.

We know in this place that the government and certain members of the government—including very high ranking members of the government—have attacked the churches and senior figures within the churches in this country for commenting on the contents of the bill. We know that other individuals—again, at very senior levels of the government—have attacked the Governor-General of this nation for having had the audacity to make comments about the directions in which he thought this bill was going. Again, the leaders of Australia's Aboriginal people have been attacked by government representatives.

We have seen that even a commercial enterprise, the Body Shop, has been attacked because they had the audacity to put on sale some black, red and yellow ribbons and armbands. There was a call from one member of the other place that indeed that enterprise ought to be boycotted because they had the nerve to sell these colours in Australia—the colours of Australia's Aboriginals.

Senator Abetz took exception to the reporting on the hearings of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee when they were looking at the constitutional aspects of the Native Title Amendment Bill. I suppose it is a problem that besets all of us in public life, that from time to time we do not get our words reprinted true to form. I had seen some of the reports at the time and they did not cause me any great difficulty as a member of the committee. I had sat through the two hearings of the committee and was interested in the reports and how other people interpreted the evidence that was given to the committee.

It is important that there is an interpretation given of evidence to the committee, and that interpretation comes to light in the content of the report of the committee. The government members of the committee put one interpretation on the evidence that was given and put emphasis on that interpretation, whilst the opposition members of the committee put a different emphasis on different aspects of the report. We went to great lengths, in the minority report that is attached to the main report, to put emphasis on the differences that we saw in the evidence that was taken.

Before I proceed, I might take the opportunity to compliment the excellent staff of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, probably one of the busiest committee secretariats in this parliament, for the wonderful job that they have yet again done on this report. I pay particular tribute to Neil Bessell, the secretary of the committee, who is leaving the committee very shortly. He has not been sacked because we got one meeting notice wrong, he has actually been promoted, and a well deserved promotion it is too. Perhaps we might have an opportunity to say some more about that next week.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought he would be pensioned off as worn out by all the work.

—Being worn out is a problem, and we do have to give very serious attention to the work of the committees, particularly the work of this committee. They have had an enormous work load to undertake during this year. I am very pleased to see that we have fulfilled the vast majority of it, and one long awaited report will, hopefully, be presented to this place next week. But that is a different subject.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to return to the content of the majority report. It was, as I thought at the time, a very unusual majority report. Normally when a bill is referred to the committee a majority report will come forward, and this was the case in the time of the previous government, when I was a member of this committee as well. Usually there would be only one recommendation, that the bill be passed. On this occasion, the committee has not recommended that the bill be passed.

I thought it was unusual at the time. I think it is even more unusual now when the committee chair gets up and seeks to defend a report and attempts in his way to put a particular spin on the recommendations that are contained in the report. He did quote from part of it. But let me deal with each of the conclusions in turn as we go through. There are not many. Conclusion No. 1 in chapter 2 says:
A key phrase threading throughout the evidence to the Committee on the Bill is that `the only certainty in constitutional law is uncertainty'. The Committee accepts this view.
It is a very strange conclusion, but one can understand it in the context of the debate that the committee had been engaged in. It goes on:
The Committee also accepts the view that it is for the Government of the day to develop the policies by which it will govern and accordingly to introduce bills.

The Committee acknowledges that eminent counsel have provided evidence that it is arguable that the High Court would interpret the scope of the races power as limited to authorising only beneficial legislation.
The Committee is of the view that, on balance, the High Court would find the Bill is constitutionally valid.

They have come to a conclusion that they think, on balance—not as a direct conclusion but only on balance—that the bill would be found to be valid. They do agree that the only certainty is uncertainty. I move on to conclusions and recommendation in chapter 3:
The Committee notes—
only notes—

the considered opinion of a number of expert witnesses that specific provisions of the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 may not comply with section 51(xxxi) of the Constitution, relating to the power of the Commonwealth to acquire property on just terms.

the view that these possible deficiencies are not fundamental flaws but may be easily remedied by amending the Bill or by amending the legislation to the extent necessary to take account of any relevant High Court decisions.
That is an admission in the committee's conclusions that there is a problem with the bill in the form that it was before the committee. The report continues:

Accordingly, the Committee recommends that the Special Minister for State, Senator the Hon Nick Minchin, review the relevant provisions in the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 to confirm that the legislation meets the constitutional requirement for the acquisition of property on just terms.
This is hardly a ringing endorsement from the committee of the bill.
The final conclusion the committee comes to is in chapter 4. I will quote it in full for the record. It says:
The Committee notes:

the views presented that the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 may not be supported by the external affairs power because it is racially discriminatory or because it removes protections for native title holders considered to be special measures.
It has noted those very important arguments that were put to the committee. It goes on:

the contrary advice of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet that the Government's view is that the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 complies with the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 and, more particularly, international obligations arising under the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination; and

that the Government's view is that the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 falls within the races power under section 51(xxxi) of the Constitution and therefore issues relating to the external affairs power are not likely to affect the constitutional validity of the Bill.

There is a very strange conclusion here, and it is the first time I have come across it in my membership of this and other committees. The committee has not reached that conclusion itself. The committee and government members of the committee have not put their reputations on the line by saying, `Yes, we agree with the government view.' They have held themselves back from that and have said, `We note that the government's view is this, and we recognise that the evidence given by the government's own people to the inquiry is this,' but they do not go on and put their own reputations on the line.

If a particular journalist wants to pick up a report such as this and look at the membership of the committee—and the journalists that I have mentioned before are all experienced journalists, two of whom operate out of the gallery in this building and the other one from Sydney—they would know the messages that are contained in a report such as this. And, if a particular spin has been put on the story, one has got to compliment the expertise of the individual journalists who do go out and examine the work of parliamentary committees. Indeed, there was a great deal of focus from the media on this committee.

When we met in public session on the night of 23 October, we had before us the Solicitor‐General of the Commonwealth, Dr Gavan Griffith QC, who was mentioned in Senator Abetz's contribution here this afternoon. Gavan Griffith is held in high esteem by those on this side of the chamber as well as by those on the other side of the chamber. He is a very eminent Australian, probably one of the most experienced constitutional lawyers in this country, and certainly he did stand in the High Court with an array of eminent QCs up against him in one particular case. But let us see how much faith Dr Gavan Griffith, the Solicitor‐General, had in his own opinion before the committee. I want to give just two short quotes and then I will sit down. He admitted that competent counsel had reached conclusions different from his own, and then went on to say:
Why ask me for an opinion? My opinion is not worth anything. You are going to get it from the court. That is the one that matters.
Later, the Solicitor‐General repeated his claim when he said, and I will only quote this in part:

I do not think my opinion counts for anything in this debate because it is an issue set to be determined by the High Court, and I doubt very much whether any of the other opinions can take the matter any further.
That is somewhat self‐deprecating on behalf of the Solicitor‐General.

Can I speak on behalf of my colleagues, although I have not checked it with the representatives of the minority parties, to put on the record our gratitude to all of those people—there are quite a few, so I will not get through the names—who gave their evidence to the committee and assisted us collectively in forming the advice that we have in turn given to the parliament within this report. I think that the debate on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 is now much more informed than it was prior to the reference of that bill to the committee and the hearing of the evidence given by those individuals to the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator McKiernan, I was not going to speak, but I was indeed provoked by something that Senator O'Brien said earlier.
—About the recession? You're not going to tip another bucket on Canberra—we're not going to allow you.

—No, I would not, Senator McKiernan. Like yours, my family came from a different part of the globe—a few generations before yours, I suspect—and one of the places the Campbell family actually settled in was the area which is now known as Canberra. In fact, members of my clan built some of Canberra's most appreciated and best buildings long before the founding fathers in their wisdom chose this site as the place for the national capital. The Campbell family chose this site, a long time before the founding fathers chose it, as a good place to run pastoral leases, and two of those pastoral leases are now quite famous in Australian history. One, of course, was Duntroon. The Campbell family set that up and built it.

BREAK.PARA: The other probably even more famous one is Yarralumla. I found out recently from the Governor‐General that it was indeed Frederick Campbell who built that magnificent property, which, after many years operating as a very successful pastoral operation, was reclaimed by the Commonwealth, though not in fact to make a Governor‐General's residence. There is an interesting piece of history here. It was reclaimed because the clay on the property could be used to create the bricks that would be needed to build the many buildings that have since been built in Canberra.

But that was not the purpose of this speech. It was to talk about another building in Canberra, built many generations after the Campbells had their pastoral lease compulsorily acquired by the Commonwealth—on just terms. It made Frederick Campbell a very wealthy man. He did indeed have that property compulsorily acquired in about the 1920s on just terms. The building that I would like to refer to is Centenary House.

Honourable senators who have been around this place know that a couple of years ago I did take a very close interest in the leasing deal at Centenary House. Unlike the situation at John McEwen House, the Australian Labor Party secured themselves a very blue chip tenant in a federal government office, the Australian National Audit Office. The Labor Party secured them at the time on what remain the most generous lease terms in Australian history. The lease terms, just to remind honourable senators and anyone else who happens to be listening or following this debate, were that it would be for a term of 15 years. A 15‐year lease was virtually unprecedented at the time and is almost unsurpassed at any time since, in either government leases or commercial leases.

The most outstanding point about that lease was that the Australian Labor Party, the landlord, was to receive a nine per cent annual rental increase regardless of market conditions. There was a royal commission into this deal to report things factually. The royal commissioner found the terms of the lease just and not at all unusual. I disputed that at the hearings of the royal commission and I have disputed it subsequently. I said to the royal commission and to the government of the time that they should have an independent panel of valuers make an assessment of the lease. The royal commission did not do that. It had one valuer from Adelaide, whom I am sure is a highly professional gentleman, but I think they should have had an independent panel of valuers assessing the terms of this lease.

I said at the royal commission and I have said on a number of occasions subsequently that this lease was an unfair and unconscionable contract that really should be renegotiated. I said that as time passed by and the rent increased by nine per cent every year it would become very obvious to any observer—it was very obvious to me at the time—that the rent, the deal and the contract were unfair.

It is particularly unfair to Australian taxpayers. It is worth noting that the rent to the Australian Labor Party from the Australian taxpayer gets reviewed on 23 September each year. The rent was renewed eight weeks ago. I report to the Senate—I think it is important taxpayers know this—that the net rent, that is, excluding outgoings, has just risen to the amount, this year, of $580 per square metre. I can put that in context for people who want to know what a fantastic deal the Australian Labor Party is getting from the Australian taxpayer. The average rent around Barton, which is where Centenary House is located, is of the order of $230 a square metre. So the Australian Labor Party is receiving a per annum bonus of the order of $350 per square metre from the Australian taxpayer.

TALK.START.PARA: —We should have looked after the Nats too.

—That's right, Senator Bishop. It would have been good if you had been the property consultant for the Nats. To put it in annual terms, that is a $2.2 million per year gift from the Australian people to the Australian Labor Party in this deal which is without any doubt whatsoever—
—You're in government.
—Are you saying that we should reduce the rent?
—It is a new tenant, isn't it?
—No.
—The current tenant is a new tenant.
—No. The current tenant, the Australian National Audit Office, was put in there about three years ago.
—There is a new tenant in there as well.
—There may well be. The Australian National Audit Office is paying the Australian Labor Party $580 a square metre. If you want to justify it, Senator Mackay, please go out and tell Australian—
—That was the market rent at the time.
—I am saying that it is not the rent now. I will just put that in context. What is not a market value is a nine per cent per annum rental increase.
—That was the contract at the time.

—It was the contract. I am saying that it is unfair and unconscionable. I am going to give the opposition and the Australian Labor Party an opportunity at the end of this speech to suggest a way that this can be renegotiated so that there is no doubt that it is a fair contract, the rent reviews are fair, the rent is fair and you are not getting a $2.2 million a year bonus from the Australian taxpayer for nothing.

BREAK.PARA: To put this in context, the Australian Labor Party are receiving this for office space in a small building in Canberra. I know this hurts the Australian Labor Party. It is very embarrassing for them to compare it with market rentals in some of the greatest office buildings in Australia—dare I say the world. If you compare the rental they are receiving in Barton with the rents that are being received in Chifley Tower in Sydney—a massive building with harbour views—Grosvenor Place with harbour views, central Sydney, Governor Macquarie—

TALK.START.PARA: —It was good foresight on the part of the ALP.

—It was a great deal. It was the deal of the century. It should not be called Centenary House; it should be called `Deal of the Century House'. It was a fantastic deal. Fifteen years with nine per cent annual rental increases regardless of what happens in the market is a fantastic deal. Not only have they already got to more than double Canberra rents but they are also on a par with the greatest office buildings in Australia's greatest central business district, the city of Sydney. The rent is almost equivalent to net rents being paid in Chifley Tower, Grosvenor Place, Governor Macquarie Tower and Governor Phillip Tower. So we have the Australian Labor Party being paid by the Australian taxpayers. The battlers, the pay‐as‐you‐earn taxpayers, are paying them $2.2 million. They are paying them the same rent as we would pay if we put the Auditor‐General into the 60th floor of a central Sydney building.
—Who made the decision three years ago?
—The decisions were made by the previous Australian Labor Party government. The Australian Labor Party should be embarrassed about this. They should say—
—The royal commission cleared this. Are you disputing the royal commission?
—No, I have just said that.
—The royal commission cleared the Australian Labor Party.

—They did not clear the Australian Labor Party. They just said that it was a fair rental deal. And I said at the time that it was not fair. I said that time would prove that it was unfair. You are getting more than twice the rent that anyone else in Canberra is getting. You are getting the same rent as the people who own Chifley Tower, Grosvenor Place and Governor Macquarie Tower are getting. You are getting $350 per square metre per annum more than you should be getting if it was a fair deal. I say to the Australian Labor Party that if you want to make it fair—you go around saying that we should have these unfair and unconscionable contract provisions in trade practices law and that you have to watch out for these nasty landlords, these big property—
—There was nothing unconscionable in those negotiations; you just don't like the outcome now that the market has fallen—
—Well, if you accept the outcome—
—Order! Senator Campbell, would you please address your remarks through the chair.

—I will try to. You would expect that, when a $2.2 million a year rip‐off has been carried out by the Australian Labor Party, they would be very embarrassed about it. But I am giving them a way out of it. I suggest to the Australian Labor Party that they have this contract arbitrated by an independent arbitrator—set up an arbitration provision or meeting to ensure that the lease agreement is brought back to commercial terms.

BREAK.PARA: The Australian Labor Party would argue that these big property owners—the big property trusts who own the shopping centres—unfairly hurt the small retailers. But there is not one single landlord in Australia that is charging its tenant more than double the rent of any other tenant in the vicinity. There is not a single landlord in Canberra that is charging a tenant a rent that is comparable to rent in the best office buildings in one of the best capital cities on the globe. If Senator Bishop or any of the Labor senators had a constituent who came along and said, `Look, Westfield Property Trust'—or Lendlease—`are charging this tenant Sydney rents in Canberra' or `This landlord is charging nearly three times the rent of any other landlord in Canberra,' you would say, `Take it to arbitration; get it arbitrated.'

TALK.START.PARA: —No we wouldn't. We would say it was a contract fairly entered into at the time.

—You would not say that. We are saying to the Australian Labor Party, `Let's get rid of this.' We are about three years into the lease and the ALP now collect double Canberra rents—equal to Sydney rents. What is going to happen in five years? Nine per cent plus nine per cent plus nine per cent. Do you want to know? You are going to be up to over $5 million a year. They are already $2.2 million a year ahead of the market. I am suggesting that we call this farce to a halt and we say to the Australian Labor Party, `Let's reduce the embarrassment in the out‐years. Let's reduce this embarrassment.' They are very embarrassed about this $2.2 million a year rip‐off they are playing on the Australian taxpayer. Let us say, `Let's get fair. Let's go to arbitration. Let's get it arbitrated and let's come up with a fair contract for a fair term and with a fair rent review.'

BREAK.PARA: I always used to like arbitration when I was training as a valuer. Valuers make a lot of money out of arbitration. But I say we should get an independent panel of valuers—get an expert panel and have a fair contract negotiated between the lessee and the lessor, because, at this moment, the Australian taxpayers have to pay the rent on this building and give the Australian Labor Party a $2.2 million a year gift. The taxpayers are saying, `Here is a cheque for $2.2 million. You should not have it. You should just have fair rent and fair rent reviews.'

I suggest to Gary Gray and the Australian Labor Party that we get this back on a fair basis. So let us not hear any talk about John McEwen House. We need some fairness in the Centenary House deal. I have stayed quiet about it for the last 18 months. I have not said anything about Centenary House since about 20 January 1996. But I gave a commitment then that I would annually—on 23 September every year or as soon as possible thereafter—remind the Australian Labor Party and the Australian people about what rent the Australian Labor Party are receiving. The offer remains open to negotiate and to bring it back on a fair basis with fair rent reviews. If that does not happen, I will—God willing—be back in this place this time next year to remind the Australian Labor Party again of what the next rent review will do.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Herron, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. As minister responsible for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs, do you support the proposal of your colleague Mr Entsch for churchgoers to boycott attendance at churches in protest at the views of certain religious leaders on your native title legislation? Do you support Senator Abetz's alternative proposal for people to stop donating to their churches?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of any proposal from Senator Abetz, but I certainly am aware of Mr Entsch's proposal. I am on the public record as taking the opposite view. I think as many people as possible should go to church—for two reasons, the first reason being if you want to get a message to your pastor it is better to go to church and talk to him or her. So I think it is a much better tack in fact to go along to church. For that reason they should attend more frequently.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the tragedies in recent times has been the lack of trust in the churches as a whole. I would advocate that as many people as possible go to church so that they can, on the one hand, get that form of communication—particularly Mr Entsch, who has said that he goes on only a few occasions; for deaths, marriages, et cetera. I have talked to him about it, Senator Mackay would be pleased to know. It is not that I am revealing anything that is of a private nature. I have said to him that I thought that he should.

The second reason that I think people should go to church is that, if ever there was a time that we should be advocating reconciliation, now is the time. I have written to the World Council of Churches commending them for their day of prayer in relation to reconciliation. I think that is a positive thing to do. This debate has been brought to a stage where there is a need for prayer, because beaten up by Senator Mackay's party is this racist attitude that is occurring. The determination of saying that there is racism and that it is a racist debate has not come from the ministers or any on the government side. Senator Mackay would have heard nothing from this side that any of this debate is of a racist nature.

We keep hearing from Senator Mackay's party that this is a racist debate and that racism is rampant. I hear that from only one side and I hear from certain spokesmen that we are racist scum. If ever there is a racist remark, that is one. I would advocate that people who use those phrases should go to church, should pray for reconciliation, because it will not occur without that attention to that particular detail.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I quote from the Herald‐Sun of Friday, 21 November, which said:

QUESTION.PARA: Another Liberal senator on the joint parliamentary committee on native title, Eric Abetz, said an alternative way of protest was for people to stop donating money to their churches.
Mr Entsch said he thought the idea had some merit.
Minister, wouldn't a boycott on church donations have a very adverse impact on the many services churches provide for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe everything I read in the papers, even though Senator Mackay does. I am happy to talk to Senator Abetz to discover what he has in fact said and, if that account is correct, I will counsel him about that.
—I didn't say it.

—Senator Abetz denies having said it, and I accept that from Senator Abetz, a good friend and colleague of mine. I know that he is a very strong churchman. I think Senator Mackay has again fallen into the trap, like her colleague next door to her, of believing everything she reads in newspapers. I will take that up with Senator Abetz. I am sure he, as I do, supports the churches. So I dismiss that statement.
—I direct my question to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Will the minister explain the impact of the right to negotiate on resource exploration, development and jobs for all Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —There appears to be a fundamental misunderstanding, or perhaps I should say deliberate misinformation, regarding the minerals industry's willingness to negotiate with native title holders. In practice, mining companies always have sought and will always seek to reach a negotiated settlement with any holder of valid title over which exploration or mining titles are sought. In the vast majority of cases, those negotiations reach an amicable conclusion, whether the title holder be Aboriginal, pastoralist or freeholder.

ANSWER.PARA: A good example is the Chevron pipeline agreement signed yesterday and the Century Zinc agreement. Senators will recall that in relation to the Century Zinc agreement the Aboriginal community finished up with exactly the same compensation package as was freely offered when it was thought that native title did not exist.

This has been complemented by a growing awareness by Aborigines of the positive aspects of mineral exploration and the development of Aboriginal communities, including economic independence and the conservation and development of Aboriginal culture. Many of these agreements are models for recon ciliation and positive developments of the nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who wrote this—Hugh Morgan?

—Senator Bolkus interjects. I want to know, Senator Bolkus, whether you support the remarks about one of the most respected men in this country, Sir Arvi Parbo, from your own state, by Mr Pearson when he called him capitalist slime. Do you support that? It is nonsense what Noel Pearson said yesterday, `That under the 10-point plan companies don't have to deal with Aborigines, therefore they won't.'

ANSWER.PARA: There is a fundamental difference between being forced to negotiate with a claimant, particularly where dubious multiple competing claims exist, and negotiating with a land owner with defined rights, with an efficient arbitrated compensation system available should negotiations break down, as is the case already with holders of statutory title. That is why we need a system which provides legal certainty to freely negotiate agreements, which has a threshold test, which limits the rights to negotiate to claimants who are likely to have their claims upheld—that is, valid title—and which incorporates a timely, fair and efficient arbitration process where agreement cannot be reached.

Accounting firm Coopers and Lybrand have estimated that current native title legislation results in a reduction of some 28 per cent in the value of a mining project affected by the legislation. This is equivalent to a reduction in value of $30 billion. The major costs are significant time delays; higher costs for debt, equity and management time; and the delay or even loss of many real jobs, good permanent jobs in remote areas, particularly for indigenous Australians. Only a small proportion of the cost is offset by gains to native title holders. This is the native title legacy which Labor left us—a legacy of confusion, delay and enormous cost of lost opportunities; a legacy which has failed to deliver to the Aboriginal community the benefits of native title; a legacy of which the Labor Party should be thoroughly ashamed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. When will the Minister for Family Services provide the promised detailed explanatory statement of the government's latest changes to its nursing home policy? Can you, Minister, inform the Senate how long the up-front fee will remain at $4,380? Can you give an assurance that the maximum anyone will have to pay in annual fees for nursing home care will be $22,000? Minister, when will you provide answers to these and the many other questions elderly Australians and their families are asking?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator McKiernan for the question. It is obvious to me that the Senate questioners do not talk to the House of Representatives questioners, because this question was asked at least 48 hours ago in the House of Representatives, if not last week. Don't they talk to each other? I know of the factional problems. The putative member for Gellibrand is concerned. I know that factional problems exist. But, Madam President, you would think that the two chambers would talk to each other.

ANSWER.PARA: Before Senator Faulkner gets up and says, `This is not relevant to the question,' I am happy to provide the answer. The minister said in the other chamber—I am happy to get the Hansard; the attendant will get the Hansard to give you the answer by the minister—that he has been detailing the policy for some time. I suspect Senator McKiernan has brought this up today because there is a report in the papers today that three out of every four new nursing home residents will pay a maximum charge of $4,380 a year. Senator McKiernan, I am sorry to put the record straight.

TALK.START.PARA: —`Sorry to put the record straight'—well it would be a first!

—I feel sorry because he does not understand the question he has just asked. He has been given a question that he does not understand; so I feel sorry for him. More than one out of every four places nationally, 27 per cent, are set aside for concessional residents—those who have assets less than $22,500. They cannot be asked to pay any accommodation charge at all. So 27 per cent do not pay anything at all. The concessional resident quota is a minimum requirement only. So, in practice, hostels operated by the charitable sector have taken a higher proportion of disadvantaged residents. The critical point is that the $12 per day, $4,380 per annum, contribution is the maximum that a person can be asked to pay by a nursing home provider. The decision as to how much to charge is made by the provider, not by the government. It may well be the case that three out of four persons could be eligible to contribute a payment, but it does not mean that they will be asked to pay the maximum amount.

ANSWER.PARA: What is also critical is that this reasonable contribution will be used to upgrade the nursing homes, neglected and positively run down by the Labor Party when they were in power. This would not be necessary if they had not neglected it for the 13 years they were in government. We have taken an attitude that we are going to do something about it. The Leader of the Opposition, when finance minister, cut capital funds to nursing homes. Labor's recently found concern for the elderly and nursing homes is once again a charade. It is just another example of Labor saying whatever it takes to look like a party that cares. Labor is in no way the solution to the present problems that exist in nursing homes. They are coming up with this charade of an argument. We have a solution. We are injecting funds. We are asking people to pay for nursing home care according to their capacity. There are 27 per cent who will not be asked to pay anything at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. I am very pleased that eventually he realised why I was asking the question, and I thank him for responding in part to the question. Minister, never apologies for putting the record straight in response to questions. Can you now give an unequivocal guarantee that older Australians needing nursing home care will not have to pay more in the way of fees as a result of the Prime Minister's most recent backflip?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already stated that a maximum is in the advice that has been given. It will be $12 a day maximum—$4,380 a year. But it is a determination by the provider not by the government. It is a decision that is reached between the provider of the service and the person going into the nursing home. But we have said that there will be a maximum of $12 a day—$4,380 a year. The minister has stated that repeatedly. I am happy to repeat that today.

—My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Has the minister's attention been drawn to comments by a noted economic commentator that the Labor Party's approach to financing government, chapter 16 of their platform, `Sounds like a policy of running the risks as Labor did in its final years in office. The result was an accumulated Budget deficit of $70 billion, the need to tighten monetary policy and fiscal policy, and a halt to the fall in unemployment.' Will the minister outline the responsible measures the Howard government has taken to reduce debt and how its policy approach differs to recent alternative proposals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very important issue. I did read the comments by the respected commentator Mr Alan Wood. I read another one, that I thought was quite relevant, which talked about the new platform of Labor that really reflects old Labor and the policies of the past. He described this new platform on old Labor as:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . a return to the worst practices of the old industrial relations club and its protection of union monopolies, interventionist industry policy, unbelievable growth and unemployment targets, trade policies that threaten to undermine and open regional and world trading systems and more than a whiff of old‐fashioned deficit spending to support a raft of promises.
That is Labor; that is old Labor as reflected in their new platform.

It is true that when we came to office we inherited the Beazley $10 billion deficit—the Beazley black hole—an additional $70 billion of Commonwealth debt accumulated over the last five years of Labor government and $185 billion of foreign debt. This was Labor's legacy—massive debt. Labor's new platform demonstrates that it is continuing to pass down the same path.

We turned these accounts around. Last year we repaid debt. This year we are repaying debt. Next year we will get the budget back into surplus. This is restoring the health of the nation's finances. This is what the Howard government is doing by applying sound economic policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about jobs? What about the unemployed?

—What response did we get from Labor for this? We got no help at all. In fact, what Labor did in this place was to attempt to block $7.2 billion worth of savings measures. So they created the debt and then they had the audacity in opposition to come in here and try to block our attempts to put the books back into the black. Labor is not interested in responsible management. Nothing has changed. Their new platform demonstrates that they want to pass down the same path again—the path of high inflation, high interest rates, high taxation and high debt.

ANSWER.PARA: A demonstration of the benefits that come from the alternative—the alternative being the sound economic management of the Howard government—can be seen today in the latest Yellow Pages small business survey. What did it find? It found a strong improvement in small business sales in recent months and a marked rise in confidence. It said:
Apart from the election induced rise in May, confidence is at its highest level in the last 2½ years.

This is good news all brought about, made possible, by the sound economic management of the Howard government—the tough but fair decisions it has taken which have given small business the opportunity to again grow, to expand and, for Senator Cook's benefit, to start employing more Australians. That is good news. That is the legacy of good government for a change.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, can you explain how the new international standard soon to be used by the ABS to report current account data will operate? How will the standard incorporate transfers in ownership of non-produced, non-financial assets? How will they be valued?
—I will take that question on notice.

—My question is to Minister for the Environment. I refer to the AC Nielsen-McNair poll results in today's Sydney Morning Herald in relation to greenhouse. It found that: 90 per cent of Australians are concerned or very concerned about the environmental impact of global warming; 83 per cent believe that global warming is a serious threat to human beings and the environment; 79 per cent believe that Australia should sign an agreement to cut greenhouse gas emissions; and 68 per cent believe that Australia should sign an agreement even if you are right and we suffer economically. Minister, are you going to continue to rely on dodgy economic models like ABARE and go off to Kyoto tying your fortunes to fossilised industries such as the coal industry who refuse to change? Or are you going to Kyoto to represent the people of Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought I would just take the opportunity to congratulate Peter Colley of the Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union. He will be in Kyoto, as he says, representing the workers. We think we represent the workers, but we welcome his contribution. He said that he will be making sure that the needs of Australian working class people and particularly Australian jobs and incomes are addressed. There is nothing unreasonable in that. What is unreasonable in the government or Mr Colley saying that they are interested in protecting Australian jobs? What is the position of the Australian Democrats? Their position is to put at risk 90,000 Australian jobs.

ANSWER.PARA: I have said before that we are seeking to contribute to a better global outcome on greenhouse gases. We want Australia to play its fair part, but we also want to protect Australian jobs. There is no reason at all why we should be sacrificing Australian jobs to get that better outcome.

In areas where we provide world's best practice in energy efficiency, it is important that we continue to have the opportunity for that sector of the economy to thrive. What is wrong with that? It is the area of our competitive advantage—our comparative advantage economically. It is where we are able to grow industry and provide more jobs. Senator Lees's alternative is to scrap these areas of the economy where we have a comparative advantage: scrap the energy sector; scrap the energy‐intensive production in Australia—such as alumina—and sacrifice the jobs, with no better global outcome at all.

That is an extremely disappointing position for any political party. It is possible for Australia to contribute to a better global greenhouse outcome. I welcome this survey.
