I welcome the fact that Australians are interested in this issue, that they want us to play our part in a better global outcome, that they are prepared to do so even at some economic sacrifice, as the government demonstrated it was prepared to do in the statement put down last week by the Prime Minister.But I am sure if you ask these people the question: are you prepared to sacrifice 90,000 jobs, they would say no. It is only the Australian Democrats that hold the position that 90,000 jobs are worth sacrificing for no necessary benefit at all.

We will continue to maintain a responsible position on greenhouse, looking for better performance from the Australian economy across all of the sectors that contribute to greenhouse. We will do that through the policies that we announced last week, but we will also in this negotiation look to Australia to protect Australian jobs. We will make no apology about that.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. If you ask these people who were surveyed whether they believe that the Australian government is right, that there are 90,000 jobs at risk, you will find the overwhelmingly answer is no. This is why we have such a large number of Australians saying very clearly that they want you to go to Kyoto to be part of the negotiations and to sign up to some targets.

QUESTION.PARA: Minister, don't you agree that the coal industry and other industries that you are protecting are steadily losing jobs? Have you not read the state of the world report that shows that generating 1,000 gigawatts of electricity per year would create 248 jobs in a solar thermal facility, 542 in wind farms but only 116 jobs in an equivalent coal‐fired plant? Aren't the people of Australia making it very clear that they do understand the issue far better than their government does? I ask you, Minister: if you are not going to represent the views of the majority of Australians, who is going to represent them at Kyoto?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a nonsense to say that we could substitute fossil fuel for solar and wind in the creation of the base load. It is a nonsense. It has not been done anywhere in the world, and it cannot be done. Renewables can play a part. Under our policy they will be increased to 10 per cent, but they will not replace base load. The only way we could replace base load would be with nuclear. Is that what you are advocating? Is that the Australian Democrats preferred position? We would contribute a better greenhouse outcome if we converted to nuclear. Do you want us to go down the French road—75 per cent nuclear and, therefore, they have a better greenhouse result? No, Madam President, they do not. We will maintain the position that is in the best interests of all Australians, that is, we will contribute a fair share of the burden towards a better global outcome and protect Australian jobs. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, what are the current taxation consequences for transactions associated with the demutualisation of non‐insurance organisations as outlined in the government's issues paper?
—This again is a very technical question that George Campbell has asked. I would be interested to see whether George Campbell has read the issues paper.

BREAK.PARA: Senator George Campbell interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —He has read it! Good on you, George. I am delighted to hear it. George Campbell has read one page. George, what I would do is read the rest of the paper that you have there—
—Order! Senator Kemp, you should refer to the senator by his correct title.

—Thank you, Madam President. I am just advising Senator Campbell that the first thing he should do is read the rest of the paper. Then, if he has any further questions, he should come back and ask me.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Having read the rest of the paper, I will ask you a second question, Minister. Upon the demutualisation of a non‐insurance organisation, to what extent will the joining fee applicable to the mutual organisation form the cost base for capital gains tax purposes?

—I think you will find that no two cases are the same in this matter so I do not wish to give you detailed advice. Knowing your interest in this issue, Senator Campbell, if you wish to phone my office I will give you a detailed briefing. I will be very interested to see whether you phone up my office and whether you seek a detailed briefing. The briefing will probably take at least a couple of hours, so make sure you can slot it into your timetable.

—My question, which I direct to the Minister representing the Treasurer, relates to the IMF rescue packages which have recently given a framework of support through the International Monetary Agreements Bill 1997. How much money has the IMF asked Australia to contribute in various rescue packages in South-East Asia? As participants in the agreement, are we obliged to make the requested loans? Under what conditions could we ask to be excused? Can the IMF ask for more than $1.5 billion per rescue package and under what conditions can we refuse? What would be the effect and impact for Australia of notifying the fund that our present and prospective balance of payments and reserve positions prevent us meeting a call?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Margetts for the question. As she has indicated, Australia has agreed to participate in the IMF‐sponsored international finance package for Thailand by way of a currency swap arrangement between the Reserve Bank and the Bank of Thailand. Australia's contribution to Thailand is firmly linked to the IMF program. Disbursements under the Reserve Bank swap are conditional upon the Thai authorities meeting the IMF conditions. For Thailand, Australia has agreed to contribute up to $US1 billion. Australia has agreed to provide up to $US1 billion to Indonesia in the form of supplementary financing which would remain conditional on adherence to the IMF program. Australia's assistance would only be drawn down after recourse to IMF financing and would be repaid once the program has ended.

ANSWER.PARA: There has been some discussion about a package for Korea. Despite press reports on the possible size of a financing package for Korea, no decision has been made on the size of the package. However, I would like to stress that Australia will consider favourably any request to provide assistance to Korea in support of an IMF program.

Australia's willingness to provide assistance to countries in the region is in Australia's interests because this support should help, first of all, address the instability in regional finance markets and maintain growth in the region, which is important to us as purchasers of our exports contribute to the growth of this country and to employment. In answer to another part of Senator Margetts's question, Australia honours its agreements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his response but I did actually ask: under what conditions can we refuse? I did not ask whether everybody is happy with everything that is going on in the government. I asked: what would be the effect and impact for Australia of notifying the fund that our present or prospective balance of payments and reserve position prevents us making a call? Are you suggesting that we have no choice? Is it the case that Australia has no choice, having signed up to this agreement and put the legislation through? Is there an ability for the IMF to make a call on Australia which is greater than that which is proportional to the amount of our credit arrangement? How many calls can be made in a year?

—We joined these packages of our own accord. We felt that it was in Australia's interests to assist these countries, particularly in view of our direct links with the Asian region. As I said, we joined these packages of our own accord. The maximum amount of assistance that Australia can be called to provide to the IMF, under the call on the NAB that Senator Margetts referred to, is $1.5 billion. However, the financial packages being arranged currently for regional countries are outside the NAB framework and, therefore, the limit does not apply.

—My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer in his capacity as minister assisting the Treasurer. Minister, I refer to the Treasurer's press release of 13 November headed `Company Law Review Bill: taxation response' and ask: how is a tax revenue loss calculated from the tainting of a company's share capital account?
—Isn't it nice to get a question from my old friend Senator Cook, and to be asked so courteously? I will seek advice from the Treasurer and reply to him.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also addressed to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, when I asked you a question on Monday, you said:

QUESTION.PARA: In financial markets, of course, there is a whole growth area occurring in bodies apart from banks, and employment is being created in those areas.

Minister, do you actually stand by this claim given that the facts are that 58,000 jobs have actually been lost in that sector over the past seven years—that is around 14 per cent of all jobs lost—and bank margins are increasing, with our small business loans some of the most expensive in the industrialised world? I ask again specifically: what is your govern ment doing to save jobs in the finance sector or does the government truly believe that bank redundancies and increasing executive and shareholder returns are the successful message of deregulation rather than protecting jobs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator you were kind enough to provide me with an indication—or at least your office was—that you would be asking a question like this but, I regret to say, you did not quite complete the quote. I said:

ANSWER.PARA: In financial markets, of course, there is a whole growth area occurring in bodies apart from banks, and employment is being created in those areas—
Then I went on to say:
Mortgage originators is one area where there has been substantial growth.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many?

—I have checked, and Aussie Home Loans, created six years ago, now employs 800 people. We have noted in financial markets that there has been, I understand, a very rapid rise in turnover in the last year with the establishment, of course, of the Telstra float. That will also add to greatly increased interest in financial markets.

ANSWER.PARA: We are trying to create a world competitive financial sector and I think Australia is very well suited to competing in this particular area. We make no apology for the policies that we followed in this area. I think the figures that you quoted probably started off well before the arrival of this government in office.
Senator Stott Despoja interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I suspect the figures started off well before the arrival of this government in office. It was well known that, under the Labor Party, major job losses occurred. One of the great features of that Labor government which is forever indelibly imprinted in the national psyche is the massive recession that we had in this country, the worst for 60 years and for which we never received any apology from any Labor member of parliament. So those job losses may well have reflected that earlier period.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to jobs, let me make it very clear that employment in this country is a key priority for this government. There is no question of that, and that is the reason why we have worked very hard to get the fundamentals right. So we are interested in jobs right across the economy, and some particular institutions decline and other areas grow. The reason that we have been able to project an increase in employment this year is simply that this government has got the fundamentals right. The encouraging figures, of course, are the very sharp fall in interest rates mentioned in your question.
There is no dispute that interest rates have come down very sharply in this country. Equally, there is no dispute—
Senator Stott Despoja interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If the issue was the benefits which are available to home owners and small business, in that case I would have thought that the interest rate reductions were a major factor. We are making sure that this economy is well structured to compete in the global economy. Financial market reform is a key element of that. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I do not know if I should just ask the original question all over again but, as a supplementary, I ask: specifically, Minister, what is your government doing to save or create jobs in the finance sector? Not benefits but jobs specifically—that is what I would like to know.

QUESTION.PARA: I did mention on Monday that 10,000 jobs were due to be lost in the next 12 months in that sector. I believe that period is within the duration of your government. Are you not concerned about this, given that you gave a speech to the chamber in February 1995 when you attacked the former government for job losses of around 8,300 as a result of bank mergers? Do you support the merger that is about to take place between the Bank of Melbourne and Westpac in the state of Victoria, which will lead to 750 job losses? That has been approved by your government. Is that not the case? Why has your tune changed between the former government and now? Why do you allow and support job losses in the finance sector? (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —What are we doing to create jobs in the finance sector? We are creating globally competitive financial markets in this country. That is what we are doing, and the Wallis reforms are all about that. That is exactly what we are doing.

ANSWER.PARA: If we want to have a financial services market which is growing and expanding, we have to carry out the sorts of reforms which were thoroughly endorsed by the government in relation to the findings of the Wallis inquiry. Specifically in relation to the financial services area, that is the way to go. In relation to the economy overall, it is critically important to get the fundamentals right. That is precisely what we are doing and the jobs growth that we are seeing in this country is an example of that. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Are you aware that an ANAO report found the Department of Finance simply forgot to transfer bank interest from accounts set up to receive early instalment payments from the final sale of the CBA because it had not been monitoring or reconciling the accounts? Minister, how much interest was involved?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I am looking through my file for the Finance briefing supplied by the Minister for Finance and Administration. I do not have a brief on this particular matter.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Hogg interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just remain seated, Senator. Don't get too eager. I will seek advice from the Minister for Finance and Administration and will provide you with an answer.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Whilst you are doing that, Minister, will you also find out if it is a fact that the ANAO report also found that the system of early instalment payment would cost the government $2.5 million through additional administrative costs? Why was this scheme employed when it is obvious that it is administratively inefficient?
—A good supplementary.
—The supplementary has certainly got the endorsement of Senator Faulkner. I am sure that the Minister for Finance and Administration will be delighted to have the chance to reply to it.

—My question is to Senator Newman, the Minister for Social Security. What action has been taken by the government to improve the provision of social security, including better service to social security recipients, the simplification of payments and the superbly successful launch of Centrelink? In particular, what has the government done to maximise incentives for people receiving income support to return to the work force where possible?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Macdonald, for a question which is very important to Australians. This government has put in place a number of initiatives to improve the delivery of social security to Australians. It has been widely supported as well. We have put in place better service delivery through Centrelink—and I thank you for your congratulations on that because many people are now writing to say how much they value the introduction of Centrelink and the changes that that has brought about already. We have introduced simplified payments and we have improved compliance. The better customer service—the creation of Centrelink as a one‐stop shop for a range of services—means that information on all services is under the one roof. Employment registration and income support application are now in the one place, and that is a great help to those who are on unemployment benefits or who have become unemployed.

ANSWER.PARA: It is worth noting that, in its platform, Labor says that people will be treated with courtesy, respect and understanding by the people who administer the social security system—if they ever get back into government. But the interesting thing is that they did not do that while they were in government. We inherited a system which was not focused on the customer, and the introduction of Centrelink has changed already much of the culture. It puts the customer at the core of its service delivery and people are valuing that. The staff themselves like it too.

BREAK.PARA: The coalition government has also substantially improved the teleservice system. After all, that was a matter of enormous frustration for Australians trying to do business with the Department of Social Security, because the Labor government introduced a system that was underresourced. We have put the resources in. People can now get through to Centrelink over the telephone much more easily than they could in the past. It still needs improving, but we have new and upgraded call centres in regional centres and we will have had a thousand new call centre jobs created by Christmas this year, all around regional Australia in particular.

Labor also says, in its platform, that the social security system should be flexible, and simple and easy to understand and administer. They introduced and gradually developed the most complex, difficult system that anybody would have a job to try and work their way around, whether as a customer or as a member of the Department of Social Security. It is our government, the coalition government, that has moved to make it simpler with the introduction of a parenting payment, the introduction of the youth allowance and the removal of inconsistencies in the treatment of people in similar circumstances.

Labor said it wants to encourage and support people to return to the work force, but it was Labor who opposed the jobseeker diary to help jobseekers meet the requirements of the activity test by recording details of their job search efforts. Labor had to be dragged kicking and screaming to sensible reform of penalties for activity test breaches. So much for their commitment to encouraging people to enter or re‐enter the work force.

Labor talks about positive incentives to encourage people to take up work, education and training. This is the same Labor Party that was intending to oppose work for the dole. It is the same Labor Party which wanted to deny young Australians the opportunity to gain skills and to be part of their community. It is the same Labor Party that has been misleading young Australians about the effect of the youth allowance, which provides education and training incentives for young Australians and removes the disincentive under Labor to taking up education and training instead of remaining on the dole. Young people are going to have a better chance of finding work if they have skills. Labor apparently thinks it is okay to parentally means test students for Austudy but not young people who get newstart. If that was not an encouragement to go on the dole instead of getting skills, I do not know what was.
Labor had 13 years in government to deliver in this area. It failed. Labor's platform shows it will do anything and say anything to get a vote.

TALK.START.PARA: —Boring!
—The coalition is delivering better social security. Senator Cook says this is boring, but Australians believe it is a great improvement on your government. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Minister, I refer you to the new anti‐avoidance and anti‐streaming measures announced by you with regard to trading in franking credits and dividend streaming. What are the conditions under which a shareholder could be deemed to receive a greater benefit from franking credits than another shareholder?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, it is good to get a question from you but I think the answer that most people want to hear from you as a Western Australian senator is: what are you going to do on the Wik bill? I have to tell you, Senator, that a lot of people are looking and are waiting to see your particular attitude to the Wik bill.
—Order! Senator Kemp—
—A point of order, Madam President. I would like to take, on this occasion, a point of order on the basis of relevance.
—Senator Faulkner, I had already called the minister to order before you were on your feet.
—I was not aware of that. If you did, Madam President, you were quite right.
—I was going to direct the minister to the question that he had been asked.
—Thank you, Madam President. The franking credit trading measures which were announced in the Budget—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Bishop wants to know the answer to his question.

—Our desire is to prevent tax minimisation through arrangements involving trading in franking credits and the misuse of the intercorporate dividend rebate. The measures have the objective of preserving the affordability of the imputation system as originally designed. Consistent with the budget announcement, consultations have taken place with interested parties, as Senator Bishop would know, regarding the 45‐day rule. They have assisted in tailing the 45‐day rule so it only applies to transactions where a franking credit trade could objectively occur.

ANSWER.PARA: We think that the measures we have announced will strongly protect the system which we have put in place. It is a system of franking credits which is, I believe, recognised as being a world‐class system. The government has the support of the community in taking these appropriate measures.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I have a supplementary question. I noted that halfway through your response Senator Ian Campbell provided you with a note so that you might be able to answer the question. Would you please table that note for the information of the Senate.

—That is pretty smart. OK, I confess to what Senator Campbell said to me. I will be up front. What Senator Campbell said was, `Julian Grill wants you to cross the floor.' So, Senator, I truly appreciated the supplementary question you raised.
—No, you didn't.

—Don't get too excited, Senator. You know what happens when you people get excited. But thank you, Senator Bishop. I do not know whether you will be in a position to provide a response to that issue, but Western Australians are watching you, Senator Bishop, and waiting to see what you propose to do.

—My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. I refer the minister to his announcement yesterday setting out enhancements to the government's choice of superannuation fund policy. Will the minister outline to the Senate the benefits of choice and the response to his announcement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I am intrigued that every time one gets up there is a stream of abuse from the Labor benches. You would think they would have learnt their lesson but apparently they have not.

ANSWER.PARA: As Senator Calvert said, the government made an announcement yesterday regarding choice of fund arrangements. I am delighted to say that these arrangements have been widely welcomed. We have not yet heard what the Labor Party proposes to do, but we do recall that Senator Nick Sherry said that the Labor Party supports choice in principle. We wait to see whether the Labor Party will stick with that principle.

Yesterday's announcement has been very widely welcomed by people, and the Senate will be interested in some of the reactions we have received from industry. Mark Paterson, the Chief Executive of the ACCI said:

The government's announced enhancements to the budget proposal concerning choice of superannuation fund are welcome. The government has listened to our representations and has responded positively to address our concerns about employer legal liability. The minimum number of funds to be offered increasing the range of agreements through which employers can meet their obligations and providing alternative options to offering employee choice of a superannuation fund.
That came from the ACCI, and those comments are welcomed.
John Maroney, the Executive Director of LISA said:

Unlimited freedom of fund choice will allow individuals to choose the superannuation fund most suited to their particular needs, including being able to maintain a completely portable account as people move between jobs. This will become increasingly important as individuals' fund balances grow over time.
He went on to say:
Enhanced choice in superannuation should result in real benefits for consumers, provided there is adequate information disclosure and a comprehensive education campaign.
He continued:
LISA will work closely with the government and industry to ensure superannuation fund members are properly informed so that they can make the most suitable choice according to their particular needs.
Even ASFA said:
ASFA's initial response to Senator Kemp's statement acknowledges that there are some practical improvements.

Choice is extremely important in the superannuation industry. Choice will allow members to have more ownership of their superannuation. The government went to the election on a program of choice. We announced the choice arrangements in the last budget. We consulted extensively with all stakeholders in the area. The announcement made last night provides some enhancements to that policy—in particular, enhancements which will provide further options for employers as well and which will help to minimise paperwork and other aspects.

Superannuation is one of the great growth markets in Australia. It is yet another area, Senator Stott Despoja, in which we are seeing very strong growth. We believe the announcements we have made are important in helping to structure the industry as we move into the next century and helping to encourage national savings. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, can you explain the differences which now confront Australian taxpayers receiving a dividend from a wholly owned subsidiary company resident in a limited exemption listed country, relative to receiving the same level of dividend from a company carrying on the same business in a listed country?

—I rise on a point of order, Madam President. If ever you wanted to see an abuse of question time, it is that. That is a question which requires an intimate level of detail and knowledge that is never the subject of sensible question time. What this is about is simply an exercise in refusing to debate policy issues.
—Order! There are too many interjections. I need to listen and less noise would be helpful.

—What I am submitting, Madam President, is that that is an abuse of question time. Question time is about ascertaining matters of policy or matters on which ministers could reasonably be expected to provide an answer in the chamber. If you want to ask about a matter of detail, you have the committee stage of bills or estimates committees where you trawl endlessly for hours and hours wasting hundreds of thousands of dollars in this parliament. Yet you come in here and ask about matters on which you could not possibly expect to get an answer on the spot. I submit therefore, Madam President, that you should rule it out of order.

—On the point of order, Madam President: that is the weakest and most humiliating performance we have ever seen from a cabinet minister, attempting to protect a junior minister in question time who ought to be in here and whose responsibility, as Senator Alston well knows, is to answer questions directed to him by members of the Senate. Of course the question is in order and of course the opposition is entitled to a response from the minister.
—I will allow the question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —They are listening now, aren't they? Some weeks ago we saw the humiliation of Senator Cook. So we have had an incredibly detailed series of questions in an absolutely pathetic attempt at payback politics. Tax law is exceedingly complex. It is not the purpose of the chamber to provide tax advice in respect of the sorts of questions which have been raised. These have not been serious questions today. Basically, your deputy leader made a complete goose of himself and so what we have is a pathetic attempt today.

ANSWER.PARA: I always seek to assist Labor senators. I assume that the questions asked today were somewhat serious and I am looking forward to a call from George Campbell for the two‐hour briefing on the question he asked me on demutualisation.

In relation to detailed questions on the implications of tax law, we are always right to be cautious. If the senator is genuinely interested in an answer to that question, I suggest he gives my office a call and we will arrange a briefing for him, too.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, Senator Ellison. The coalition government's objective of achieving excellence in education has been shown by its all‐out commitment to increasing literacy and numeracy standards in all schools as well as with a host of other initiatives. Will the minister explain the government's initiatives in education and is the minister aware of other alternative educational proposals that have been put forward recently and are they likely to be adopted by this government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Tierney for the question. The government's strong commitment to education, both in the schools and higher education sectors, is underpinned by fairness, equity and excellence in standards. In the time permitted, I will focus on just a few examples where this is self‐evident and in stark contrast to Labor's so-called education policies announced in their draft policies last week.

ANSWER.PARA: Since coming to government this coalition has actually done something about raising literacy and numeracy standards. We have worked closely with the state and territory governments and non-government education authorities to focus national attention on this issue. What did Labor do? They adopted it from us. Literacy and numeracy is in their policy. They are going down the same path after attacking us. But they saw that we were on the right track and they copied us.

We have agreed to a national literacy plan, and we will give you a copy of it so that you can put it in your platform. That is to ensure that all children are reading and writing properly by year 3. This is a program which has been well received by Australians. It is no wonder that the opposition followed it and copied it from us.

We are also putting our money where our mouth is. The coalition has increased Commonwealth funding for literacy to the tune of $669 million in the next four years leading up to the year 2000. This includes $80 million more than Labor would have provided in its last year of the government.

In the 13 years of the Labor government they did nothing about literacy and numeracy. In fact, it was in the recently released national school English literacy survey that we saw that about 30 per cent of Australian primary school children were failing to meet an acceptable standards of literacy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that the bodgie one? That is the cooked up one?

—If you disagree with that, you go and talk to the wider community. If you disagree with that, why are you making literacy a main plank of your platform? If you disagree with that, go and talk to Blair and his government in the UK who have adopted the same policy.

ANSWER.PARA: Labor wants to re‐establish a minimum enrolment benchmark for the establishment of new non-government schools. In other words, bring back the old new schools policy. We campaigned to abolish that policy and we were elected, because the community saw what a dud policy that was. What Labor likes to call sensible planning really represents another layer of unnecessary bureaucracy and mountains of red tape. This government has placed responsibility for the planning and registration of new non-government schools with the states and territories. They are in the best position to assess the requirements of new schools.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is nonsense. You took away choice.

—The coalition government offers parents a choice. You do not want to give them a choice. You want to cut out the non-government sector where 30 per cent of Australia's children are educated. This government offered choice. We want a strong government sector and we want a strong non-government sector, and thereby we can give people a decent choice. You do not believe in that and you did not want to listen earlier when Senator Kemp was talking about choice. That is what this government is about.

ANSWER.PARA: When you look at Labor's education platform, all you see is a reintroduction of the old new schools policy which the Australian people rejected overwhelmingly last year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, would you care to add to what you have just said about the reaction of the community particularly to a very wide range of initiatives by this government on schools policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been overwhelming acceptance of this government's policies on schools generally. Of course, one of them has been to involve vocational education in schools. The jobs pathway program has been very well received, and we have approached our new apprenticeships with flexibility. In fact, the head of Woolworths training said the other day that, because of the new apprenticeships policy, they are going to take in 1,000 trainees. They are going to increase it from 350 to 1,000.

ANSWER.PARA: We are offering flexibility by combining vocational education with schools—something that the opposition never did when it was in government. By providing that flexibility, we will ensure that young school leavers are better placed to find work when they leave school. That is, after all, very important because 70 per cent of Australia's children when they leave school do not go on to tertiary education. They are out there looking for work, and we are going to help them find it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron), to a question without notice asked by Senator Mackay today, relating to comments made by religious leaders concerning native title.

The proposal that Mr Entsch has made, that people in the rural community in Australia should boycott the churches, and the remarks that were quoted in the Herald‐Sun of 21 November from Senator Abetz—`Another Liberal senator on the joint parliamentary committee on native title, Eric Abetz, said an alternative way of protest was for people to stop donating money to their churches'—are really very typical of what happens in the Howard government when any group in the community has the hide to express a view, particularly if any group in the community decides it is appropriate to criticise a decision of the Howard government. This is a prime example of the way members of the Howard government deal with any dissent; there is absolute intolerance from the government of any criticism.

There is a very long record of this now. Look, for example, at the efforts to silence the Australian Law Reform Commission when it had the temerity to criticise the government's native title legislation. We saw it from the Prime Minister's office when it attempted to undermine the former President of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, Sir Ronald Wilson, and his stolen generation report.

We have seen the government defund National Shelter. We have seen them defund the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation. We have seen it in the way the government have tried to snuff out the ABC. This is the approach that the Howard government consistently have taken to those in the community who at times are critical of their actions or their policies.

BREAK.PARA: I have to say that this has now reached new heights. You wonder why there is such concern in the Australian community. It is not just Mr Entsch's call to boycott the churches and what apparently Senator Abetz has said. In yesterday's Morning Bulletin of Rockhampton, the member for Capricornia, Mr Marek, was quoted. People have to face up to the fact that this is the sort of attitude that exists in the coalition government in this country. Let me quote the Morning Bulletin, which said:
Mr Marek also said specific indigenous services—such as the Aboriginal Legal Service and ATSIC—should be abolished once the native title issue was resolved.
About the Native Title Amendment Bill he went on to say: Secondly, the bill could have been far less if settlement was reached in Australia's early history.
Mr Marek, a member of the House of Representatives, a member of the coalition parties, was quoted as saying:
Imagine if we'd done this years ago . . . All we would have had to have given them is 20 bucks and a box of Jatz.
That is what Mr Marek said. That is the sort of person we have in the Liberal Party and the National Party in this country. There are not just the Entschs and the Abetzs; we have the Mareks as well.
Perhaps we ought to remember what the member for Dickson—that paragon of moral rectitude—Mr Tony Smith said. This is what he said in his local Christmas newsletter to Dickson constituents:

. . . the High Court and then the Keating‐Lavarch‐Kernot Native Title Act decided that if you were aboriginal or a Torres Strait Islander, you could qualify for this thing called Native Title, but if you were not of that racial grouping, you could not qualify.
Now isn't that a law based on race?

This is the sort of pig ignorance in the Liberal and National parties. This is what this government is about when it is dealing with any critical comments, any dissent at all. It is, as I have said before, an outrage. These people—Mr Marek, Mr Entsch, Senator Abetz and the others—stand condemned for what they have said and done. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —I think what the Australian people and this Senate were just treated to was the politics of division and an attempt to beat up an issue for base political motives without any real or genuine concern for the role of the churches in public debate. For the record, let me put it very clearly that I believe churches have an absolute right to engage themselves in issues that are within the public domain. As a Liberal parliamentarian, I also believe that rights have countervailing duties. The countervailing duty on the churches is to ensure that, when they engage in public debate, they do so from a well‐informed position. It is absolutely outrageous when local parish priests seek to set themselves up as constitutional experts overnight. It is just a nonsense for them to do that.

SPEECH.PARA: I relish the opportunity to clear up an article which appeared in the Herald-Sun on Friday, 21 November 1997. What was reported was, to a certain extent, the truth. But I made those comments in the context—and this will be very interesting to Senator Woodley—of somebody who is a Uniting Church minister, namely, the Reverend Gordon Moyes, refusing to pay money to the Uniting Church central committee because he and his parish disagree with certain policies being pursued by the Uniting Church. If it is good enough for the Reverend Gordon Moyes to go on public record to say that that is what his congregation is doing, why is it so outrageous if a poor, humble senator like me, knowing of that situation—

TALK.START.PARA: —So you weren't misquoted?
—Reverend Gordon Moyes, let me add, Senator Mackay, is a very well‐respected churchman within Australia. It is within that context that I said people may wish to adopt that policy.
—Aha!
—No, the policy of Reverend Gordon Moyes. That does not mean that I support stopping people from giving to churches.
—Well, do you or don't you?

—I don't, Senator Mackay. I thought I had made that clear. I will make it clear again for Senator Mackay. What is appropriate is that, if certain congregations believe their hierarchy is not representing them honestly and truthfully according to the gospel values, it is appropriate for them to say, `We will not forward money to central headquarters.' So that was that context.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party seem to have found this new-found faith in the churches. Guess what came across my desk today? A letter from the dioceses of Canberra and Goulburn from the Right Reverend George Browning. He discussed a number of important public policy issues facing this country today, including the workplace. He said, `Reform in the workplace, especially the waterfront, is a very significant matter.' He further said, `Again, on this matter I could be seen to be a supporter of the government.'

I look forward to the Labor Party embracing the churches on the issue of waterfront reform. I look forward to them saying the churches are absolutely right and how dare we attack the churches if the churches have a particular view on waterfront reform. Some of the churches, unfortunately, have written letters of a nature that is very divisive. Let me give an example of one that I received the other day: `This legislation gives massive capital gains in land values to pastoralists, many of whom voted this legislation into being.' Not even the Labor Party make that assertion.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's wrong.

—Senator Collins interjects that it is wrong. That is the sort of misinformation and ignorance that some of the churches have been relying on, whipping up hysteria in the community. As Senator Bob Collins, Labor senator for the Northern Territory, acknowledges, it is wrong. Therefore, I welcome the churches' involvement but they should do so on an informed basis. Otherwise they will let themselves down and the communities and congregations they allegedly represent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very interested in the qualification that came at the end of Senator Abetz's comments: provided that the debate was on an informed basis. What is the definition of `informed'? Who determines that? That is the issue. In relation to the correspondence on waterfront reform that Senator Abetz was waving around from one of the churches, let me say that we absolutely defend the right of churches to have a view on waterfront reform. That is fine; that is what a democracy is about.

SPEECH.PARA: The difficulty we have here is one of credibility. I believe this government is genuinely astounded when people criticise it. Let us look at the reality. The government came in with a massive majority and a very small mandate. That is the problem. In 1993 we had Fightback, which the people did not like. The government did not actually betray its policy position in 1996. It learnt from the lesson of John Hewson. The difficulty is that the government is starting to implement the 1993 agenda, and people are kicking up about that, saying that they do not like it.

This government is genuinely astounded by criticism. It cannot take criticism. That is the bottom line. This government cannot believe that Australians have the temerity and the effrontery to publicly criticise government decisions. How dare they! These are decisions of the government; the government is right. How dare they have that level of temerity and effrontery to make criticisms. The government is right; the community is wrong. Every time any trenchant criticism has emerged, what has this government tried to do? It has tried to shoot the messenger every single time. We have a government that is paranoid, insular and out of control. I know why the government is out of control. You only have to look at the polls. That is why the government is out of control. The reality is that the backbench is panicking.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—You may laugh, Senator Abetz, but it is absolutely true. What did the government say with regard to nursing homes? It was a Labor Party scare campaign. The nursing homes debacle was characterised by the government's absolute litany of backflips, obfuscation and waffle which the policy elicited. We got a response on that issue again today. The government was saying that was not genuine concern from the elderly people of Australia; that was a Labor Party scare campaign. It could not take the criticism so it tried to shoot the messenger. I will move on to the travel rorts affair or `travelgate'. The government could not find the whistleblower, so what did it do? It abolished the department. Talk about not shooting the messenger; that was driving a stake through the heart of the messenger.

SPEECH.PARA: While we are on the Public Service, it is clear the government does not like the Public Service. The backbench particularly do not like the Public Service. So what do they do? Thirty thousand Public Service jobs gone. And we have got Senator Ian Campbell's illustrious comments with regard to Canberra which we heard the other day. The ABC—they do not like what the ABC says, so what do they do? They slash the ABC. I bet John Laws is really pleased that he is not publicly funded because I imagine if he were he would be shaking in his shoes for fear of being cut.

Then we have the final outrage I believe—maybe not the final outrage but it is certainly a great landmark along the way. The churches have come out and dared to disagree with the government, and we have a call for a boycott from Mr Entsch and weasel words—if I have ever heard weasel words—out of the mouth of Senator Abetz, whose position is still not clear to me. From the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in relation to this matter and the comments of Mr Entsch, we have a grab bag of mealy‐mouth weasel words saying, `I can understand how he feels.' Call that leadership? I do not think that is leadership.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's code for `I'm right behind him'.

—That is absolutely right, Senator. The churches in Mr Entsch's own electorate have called his comments offensive. So here we have it again: the church has come out; they do not like what the government is doing; so the government shoots the messenger. Compounding the felony, we have the comments of Senator Abetz—the comments you made here today, Senator Abetz, in which you clearly equivocated.

BREAK.PARA: What you over there have got to understand is that you are squandering your opportunity. The bottom line is: start listening to people; don't shoot the messenger; and, most importantly, if you can't take the heat, get out of the kitchen.

TALK.START.PARA: —All these cliches! I'm finding it a bit difficult to understand them.

—It absolutely amazes me that we have a senior minister in Tasmania who rings around community groups leaving messages on their answering machines, slagging off at them for daring to criticise the government's policies. This is typical of the type of action we have from this government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —The role of the church and state is not a new debate, whether it is today—generated by the Wik‐type issues—or whether it was in the Middle Ages. Therefore, it is timely to ask ourselves, why do we go to church? I hope it is more than to discuss matters with the local pastor. Christians go to church to praise God, for forgiveness and for guidance.
—Praise?

—To praise God—I think we ought to remember that as legislators in this Senate. According to first catechism principles, which most of us learnt at a very early age at Sunday School, what is the chief purpose for which man is created? The chief purpose for which man is made is to glorify God and to enjoy Him forever. For those who are conversant with the Old Testament, in the Book of Ecclesiastes chapter 12, verse 13 says:

SPEECH.PARA: Fear God and keep his commandments, for this is the whole duty of man. For God will bring every deed into judgment, including every hidden thing, whether it is good or evil.

It is not surprising in this divisive environment that people are looking increasingly to the churches. The problem for the churches is how do they respond? Some to the near north believe, in some cases, that the churches have let them down. There are others who believe that those who are oppressed, depressed or disadvantaged need the church's support.

BREAK.PARA: I would like to refer to a letter from Bishop, the Right Reverend George Browning. He actually congratulates the Parliamentary Christian Fellowship on a successful year and a successful parliamentary prayer breakfast. He raises the interesting point about whether the Christian voice should be restricted to matters of private piety or private morality. While these issues are important, the Gospel—as Senator Woodley knows—reaches out to the wider community, and perhaps to those who are in greatest need, and the underprivileged, the marginalised and those who perceive themselves to be powerless.

This is, indeed, a difficult position for the churches, as to their response. As my colleague Senator Abetz said, they do have a right to speak out on issues. But, of course, as always, people view opportunities, deprivation and compensation from different perspectives depending on their location, their environment and the position in which they see themselves to be disadvantaged either by the law or through being persecuted in some way.
Again I agree with the Right Reverend George Browning when he says:
I find it is extremely unfortunate that some members of parliament are vilifying church leaders for speaking on matters of deep spiritual conviction.
And I would think that the church will continue to speak out.
Both the government and the churches actually recognise the importance for reconciliation, which should be the core of the matter.

It is unfortunate that the current community debate has been more about myths and misunderstandings about the bill than about its actual provisions and, as such, we have an issue of great difficulty and divisiveness.

I also refer to our distinguished Governor‐General; a man of great religious conviction, steeped in the law and with a great compassion for the poor and the depressed. Sometimes the authority of leaders such as the Governor‐General is narrowed by the scope of authority, be that persuasive with a nominated appointee, or legalistic though an election to office. If Australia is to have a Governor‐General who is elected rather than appointed, the question is would his voice be more considered by the whole community in terms of responses to his concerns about the poor and the needy? I ask you all to think very seriously about that in terms of the decisions that a lot of us are likely to make on the future constitutional head of state for this country. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that Senator Abetz raised the issue of Reverend Gordon Moyes. Reverend Gordon Moyes was wrong in what he said about the Uniting Church Assembly, he was wrong in his shameful attack on the Reverend Dr Dorothy McRae‐McMahon and he was wrong because he had to restore the funding which he threatened to remove. He discovered that within the church what he was saying was wrong and in fact his parish has restored that funding.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the letter from Bishop Browning, I do admit that Senator Watson certainly read a lot more of the sense of that letter than Senator Abetz did. It very clearly was saying the church has a right, a very clear right, to speak on these issues.

In the answer that Senator Herron gave to Senator Mackay's question he said that he told Warren Entsch that people should go to church to talk to their pastors. It would be a good idea if Warren Entsch went to church to listen to his pastor, because I am afraid he is not a very good listener.

In terms of people not donating money to the churches, I would like to point out to Senator Abetz that not only would that remove money that the churches spend on Aborigines but it would also remove money which the churches spend, which amounts to millions of dollars, every year in maintaining rural ministries to the very pastoralists that this government says it supports.

The Uniting Church, just to give an example of one church, through its Frontier Services, which is the successor to the Australian Inland Mission, which established the Royal Flying Doctor Service—I remind senators that the churches established that service—provides services to families, to aged care, to education, to student hostels, to patrol ministries, to counselling, to hospitals, to health care—all in remote and rural areas. Does Senator Abetz really believe that people should stop donating to the churches and remove those services from pastoralists? That is the implication of what he has said.

Senator Herron also commended the National Council of Churches in Australia, who had called for prayer for reconciliation. Certainly prayer is important, but he omitted to point out that, in that same press release in which the National Council of Churches called for prayer because it believes it is important, it also said:

The Council's Executive also called on the federal parliament, in amending the Native Title Act, "to ensure equal protection for the rights of all Australians and, in particular, to refrain from treating the rights of native title holders in a discriminatory way".

In other words, the National Council of Churches was saying two things—not one but two: first, you should pray; secondly, you should always speak the prophetic word to the contemporary society of the day. Often, unfortunately, people think all churches should do is pray and they forget the example of the whole of scripture in which the prophetic word by the Old Testament prophets and by Jesus himself was spoken to the contemporary society of the day. Always those two things must go together.

I want to repeat something I said last night, because this whole issue of attacking church leaders is very common but it has been going on for years. Former Premier of Queensland Joh Bjelke-Petersen was good at it. He used to call me and many other clergy `radicals' and `communists'. Let me quote a letter that the late Professor Roly Busch wrote to church members in 1978.

TALK.START.PARA: —Great bloke!
—Yes. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Some have referred to a `bunch of ratbag socialists' in the Uniting Church in Queensland. We who are nourished in the brilliant insights of the Bible, and who are the inheritors of Calvin, Knox, Cromwell and Wesley, need no political parties, socialist or otherwise, to form our minds on the proper liberties of Christian subjects.
In the ringing words of the forbears of one of our traditions—
`In very truth we fight not for glory, not riches, nor honour, but for that liberty which no true man relinquishes but with his life.'
(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lightfoot, Sen Phillip

TALK.START.PARA: —I am continually disturbed—
—We know!
—Stop there. You're right.
—as the debate proceeds, not with necessarily the business confronting the house at the moment.
—Stop there. You are spot on.
—Madam Deputy President, if I could just get started I would appreciate it. Perhaps then I would be able to field a few interjections if there were—
—Order! Senator Collins! If you would like to address the chair, Senator Lightfoot, and ignore the interjections.

—Thank you, Madam Deputy President. But I am concerned that the debate comes back to the issue of the politics of division. It is not just the politics of division that the church in some areas—I stress `in some areas'—promotes, but also the politics of ignorance coming from those same people. It does, if I could put this in perspective, come from only a few people. The most notable of those are the Anglican archbishops of Perth and Adelaide. It just so happens that those two gentlemen enjoy an extraordinary lifestyle—one that is well and truly above that of pastoralists, one that they are sworn to serve—and, by their own very words, are condemned as hypocritical.
—Is it half as good as yours?
—I do not, quite frankly, know what you mean, Senator Collins.
—You've got money running out of your ears and I don't begrudge it.

—What I am trying to say, in spite of Senator Collins's interjections, is that it is not all the churches and we must not condemn the churches per se because two recalcitrants, whose scant knowledge is based on ignorance, have something to say. That word is very familiar to those opposite because they did have an alleged leader at one stage that used that very same word. I am not backward in using that word because they shrink from it, but it is one that is based on ignorance and it is based on the politics of division—something that we should not do. No matter what we on this side say, there are politics of division—they have to, by compulsion, be opposed to it.

SPEECH.PARA: That is not what this is about. If there is going to be this reconciliation that you people preach with your forked tongues, surely there can be reconciliation on this problem associated with land rights. But what does not help it—it is not just those people on that side who are not helping and contributing in a positive sense to resolving the issue—is that there are churchmen in high and privileged positions, like the Anglican archbishops of Perth and Adelaide, who are dividing this nation.

Senator Bob Collins has the perception that anyone associated with the land, as I am, has—if I can quote him—`money coming out of their ears'. That is not true. People associated with the land have enormous problems these days. Pastoralists in particular have gargantuan problems. To say that we cannot speak out against churchmen is something quite extraordinary. Jesus in his day spoke out about churchmen. Senator Woodley, who is now gone and not interested in the debate, should know this. He made a bit of a contribution. He is going to copy it from Hansard and send it out to some of his select people in Queensland. Jesus spoke out about his church leaders. I do not come anywhere near the most revered man that has ever been on Earth. But we have the right to speak out against churchmen, particularly those churchmen who enjoy a chardonnay lifestyle in their mansions and who speak out on subjects that are based on ignorance.
Senator Bob Collins interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me read something, because I am finding it very difficult, as indeed Hansard must, over the rather raucous voice of Senator Bob Collins—
—You are a hypocrite.
—Order! Senator Collins, withdraw that, please.

—Madam President, on a point of order: I must say that it is slightly difficult to handle a senator talking about division who came into this chamber and said in his first contribution in here—and it is a matter of record—that the Aboriginal people of Australia—
—Order! Senator Collins.
—were the lowest part of the spectrum of civilisation.
—Order!
—To listen to that from him is a bit rich.
—Order! Senator Collins—
—I, of course, withdraw.
—Thank you.
—Where are the archbishops on your spectrum of civilisation, Senator Lightfoot?

—I am not going to ask to have that inaccurate statement withdrawn. Madam Deputy President, I am sorry that Senator Bob Collins was not able to hear your voice for some considerable time when you called him to order; perhaps it was a bit low. I have a letter from the owners of the Body Shop in Australia. When I attacked them about supporting the divisive land rights issue, they said to me, inter alia:

BREAK.PARA: We also understand that these pastoral leases are, in the main, held by a small number of wealthy individuals and corporations, and many are owned outside Australia. Why should foreign companies with economic interest prevail over the social and cultural impact of our own indigenous people?

This is the very ignorance that we talk about here. Those people on the land are not wealthy individuals. They are families that are struggling and are going to continue to struggle. They cannot get title to their leases; that is the big problem. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for the debate has expired.

BREAK.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
For permanent protection of old‐growth forests and all other areas of high conservation value, and for the implementation of tree plantation strategies.

This petition from the undersigned respectfully points out that: there is an increasing and urgent demand from the people, to protect all remaining high conservation value forests which support flora and fauna unique to Australia, thus complying with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory. We have a responsibility to future and present generations, and the necessary reasons, knowledge and technology to act now on the following achievable solutions.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate legislate to:

PARA.TAB: immediately stop all logging and woodchipping activities in high conservation value native forests;

ensure intergenerational equity by planning for the rights of future generations, and protecting in perpetuity all biologically diverse old‐growth forests, wilderness, rainforests and critical habitats of endangered species;

facilitate rapid transition of the timber industry from harvesting high conservation value native forests to establishing mixed‐species farm forestry on existing cleared and degraded lands, using non‐toxic methods to protect ecological sustainability;

maximise use of readily‐available plantation timber for industry needs, using appropriate forestry techniques and progressive minimal‐waste processing methods, such as radial sawing, and wherever possible, reuse and recycle wood and paper products;

support incentives for nationwide employment in composting, soil remineralisation programs, and the planting programs of trees and annual fibre crops, inter‐grown with appropriate fruit and nut trees and medicinal plants;

encourage sensitively‐managed, environmental education tourism in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for natural ecosystems, Aboriginal cultural heritage, sacred sites and other sites of significance; and

progressively utilise technological expertise and resources transferred from the military sector, to help implement these tree planting solutions; and to motivate the international community to follow this example.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Native Title
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned requests that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples of this country are treated justly and fairly. It is in the interest of all to build this nation in a spirit of reconciliation and cooperation with Australians of diverse racial and ethnic backgrounds.

We call on you to ensure that regional agreements with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples are pursued in good faith, so as to determine their rights to their land in a spirit of reconciliation.

The co‐existence of Native Title and Pastoral Leases on Crown Land is supported by legal principle and historic fact, upheld by the High Court. The people and Governments of Australia have a moral responsibility to give this fact real and just effect.
We call on members of the Senate to ensure that legislation regarding Native Title
(i) complies with internationally recognised principles of non‐discrimination; and
(ii) promoted Reconciliation with Australia's first peoples.

PETITION.TITLE: Sydney Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
(a) a proposal has been made by the Department of Transport to build a major no‐curfew international airport in Sydney's western suburbs;
(b) airports and attendant infrastructure are a major source of air and noise pollution;
(c) Western Sydney already suffers from the worst air pollution in Australia;
(d) an additional airport in the Sydney airshed will only serve to greatly increase such pollution; and
(e) an airport in Sydney's west will harm the lifestyle and wellbeing of citizens living and working within the Sydney airshed.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate not pass any bill which would lead to the construction of any new airport within the Sydney airshed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—In consideration of the notice of motion to produce and to table legal advice in relation to the NTAB and the compliance with the Racial Discrimination Act or Australia's international obligations, the government has clearly received extensive advice in the preparation of its policy response to the Wik decision. While the government neither confirms nor denies whether it has received any specific advice on whether the Native Title Amendment Bill complies with the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 or Australia's obligations, the government, as has previously been made clear by the Special Minister for State (Senator Minchin), has ensured that our bill takes account of the principles of the RDA. The content of any legal advice which has been incorporated into the government's policy, as reflected in the bill currently before the Senate, is therefore irrelevant to the forthcoming Senate debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The government, nonetheless, will be opposing this motion in accordance with established principle. The general position is clear. Legal advice provided to the government is subject to legal professional privilege. The Senate is well aware of the position taken by successive governments—whether ALP or coalition—that the Senate has no power to demand the tabling of documents which attract either public interest immunity or legal professional privilege.

Indeed, it is interesting to note the views previously expressed by Senator Bolkus on the tabling of legal advice in relation to the Carmen Lawrence matter when he was sitting on the government benches. After not tabling documents, which included legal advice from the Attorney-General's Department, Senator Bolkus supported this position by stating:

BREAK.PARA: These documents clearly fall within the accepted boundaries of legal professional privilege and public interest immunity. The Senate has traditionally recognised these claims.
The next day Senator Bolkus went further in referring to the return to order passed by the Senate as follows:

That is why your return to order motion is at best vacuous and at worst blatant hypocrisy. It is a disregard of the accepted principles of practice in this place. It is a disregard of the accepted principles of government. You know that but, despite knowing it, you come in here with a wish list that you know any responsible government cannot meet.
The now Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Gareth Evans) has also commented on the need to respect legal professional privilege. On 28 August 1995, Mr Evans said:

The government simply does not make available government documents which fall within accepted boundaries of legal professional privilege and public interest immunity to the Senate. We certainly will not be doing that to a Senate committee. Nor is it the practice or has it been the practice over the years for any government to make available legal advice from its legal advisers made in the course of the normal decision making process of government, for good practical reasons associated with good government and also as a matter of fundamental principle.
The then Senator Evans went on to say:

. . . we are not prepared, as I have already indicated, to make available legal advice prepared in the ordinary course for the purpose of the development of government policy or the making of specific government decisions. The confidential relationship between the government's legal advisers is an essential part of the business of government.

The claim of legal professional privilege as a basis for not tabling material in the Senate has been used by governments of all persuasions. Other recent examples include Senator Sherry in his then capacity as Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy on 1 March 1995 in response to a motion for documents associated with the grant of woodchipping licences. Similarly, the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman, on 23 May 1996 also refused to provide legal advice on the basis that it was subject to legal professional privilege.

Senators will all be aware that successive governments have refused to table legal advice on the basis that it is protected by legal professional privilege. As has previously been acknowledged by the Australian Labor Party, the availability of this privilege is an essential element of good government. The government therefore does not accept that it can be compelled to provide any such advice, if it exists, as referred to in the motion. Consequently, the government opposes the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Senator Tambling has come up with a list of quotes. It is fair to say, for people who have been in this place for some time, that for every one quote he can find from our side, we can probably get 10 from your side arguing that, despite professional privilege, the Senate does have a power to try to pursue the matter. All of us would acknowledge that, in many circumstances, governments of whatever persuasion have actually made legal advice available. We say that, in this particular instance, it is important to get that legal advice. That legal advice is not irrelevant to the debate that is going on in this place about the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 , because that advice goes very much to the heart of many of the concerns about the Native Title Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: We are involved in one of the most important debates that the Senate will see for quite some time. The basis of that debate is whether the government has the capacity to use the races power of the constitution to implement its legislation. There has been a lot of concern about that. Organisations such as the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, the Australian Law Reform Commission and, today, the International Commission of Jurists, as well as the minority report of the Senate legal committee have all claimed that the government does not have adequate power.

A lot of claims have been made also about the discriminatory nature of the government's legislation, and that is something that the advice that we are seeking through this return to order motion today goes very much to. I could talk for a long time on this but, as I said, I will not speak for too long. We are concerned that when the Senate proceeds with the debate, it has before it the relevant advice. It is fair to say that the overwhelming body of advice from outside government makes the assertion that the legislation is discriminatory and has a racist edge to it, and also is in breach of our international legal obligations. We in this place have to be concerned about that.

In terms of the government advice, you have advice from the Solicitor‐General, Mr Gavan Griffith, who with respect to the constitutionality based on the races power says two things. Essentially, he says, `I don't think my opinion counts for anything in this debate because it is an issue set to be determined by the High Court and I doubt very much whether any of the other opinions can take the matter any further.' That was, in essence, the bottom line or tenor of his advice.

The other senior adviser to government is Mr Henry Burmester, the Chief General Counsel. The opposition has information that on 25 July this year he provided very clear advice to government indicating that, in his view, in a number of instances the legislation proposed by the government could be in breach not just of the Racial Discrimination Act but also of the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination.

We have to be concerned about honesty. Honesty is important in this. In this respect, the debate in this place should proceed in a manner not like the manner in which it has been pursued over recent days in the media by people such as Mr Entsch, Senator Lightfoot and Mr Marek. To get it right, that advice is necessary; that is why we have moved this motion today.

PARA.TAB: That the motion (Senator Bolkus's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.
