INTERJECT.SPEAKER: DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I present to the Senate the second report of 1997 of the Procedure Committee.

INTERJECT.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I have not had the opportunity to look at this report of the Procedure Committee. I will be interested to do so when it is available. This matter has been before the Senate on a number of occasions. I must accept some responsibility for that. The committee has reported on the requirement for senators to stand in their seats when entering a debate or when making a vote when they have a pecuniary interest which is affected by the matter before the Senate.

For example, on a number of occasions I have raised the issue of six or eight senators who have shares in woodchip companies and the need for them to declare those shares before voting on procedural matters which advantage the woodchip companies and which could have an advantage to either the share prices or the profitability of those companies, which then flows on to the senators involved. It is a good practice and a very important one. In this day and age it is very important that members do declare their business interests.

The requirement to make such a declaration came after quite a long debate. The declaration of pecuniary interest was introduced in the Senate in 1994. It was a Labor government move and it had support from the then coalition opposition. So why has opposition now arisen to the implementation of this very wise move? It is because there has been a call for it to actually be honoured. It is because on a number of occasions I and one or two others have said senators ought to declare their interests in a matter before the Senate, and we have had this extraordinary situation where that has upset some senators. It should not have done so. It should be a clear and easy matter for people to observe. It is a clear principle and it ought to be one with which nobody has any difficulty.

Earlier this year, the matter was referred back to the declarations on interest committee and it found that nothing should change. The committee looked at it, at the request of senators, and found that the declaration provision should remain. I quote from the report of the chair, Senator Denman, to the Senate on 20 March in which she said:
In such matters it may be best to err on the side of caution and make declarations—
that is, giving advice to us. She then said:
It is not a contempt of the Senate to have a conflict of interest. It could be a serious contempt to fail to declare one.

So there it is—this provision does not say you cannot speak or you cannot vote if you have got an interest in the matter. It simply says you should declare it. I cannot go along with the idea that the requirement for declaring such an interest should be abolished. I am concerned that there is a concerted effort to achieve that end.

The matter went to the Procedure Committee, and we have its report today. I have not been able to get the results of that report, but let me say that I will take an interest in this; I want to be able to speak on it again. I want to assure the Senate that the Greens stand solidly in defence of retaining the requirement that all of us declare a pecuniary interest when we are speaking or voting on a matter which involves such an interest. We are totally opposed to any move to abolish or water down such a requirement.
This is a matter that had bipartisan support at the outset. In fact, it was the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill, who, while in opposition, said:

We actually support disclosure, and that is why one of our foreshadowed amendments specifically requires senators in debate to disclose interests that might amount to a conflict of interest, and to disclose on a vote in this place.
Pointing to his amendment, the one that created this provision in our standing orders, Senator Hill said:

My fifth amendment is the one that I mentioned a little while ago, specifically requiring senators to make declarations at the beginning of a speech and also after a division. I understand, from what the minister—
that is, the then Labor minister—
told me yesterday, the government will support that, and I am pleased it—
that is, the government—
has come to the party on that and recognises that it is important.

The problem is that when someone comes along and says, `Let us implement this requirement for disclosure,' the move is on to abolish it. It is a very peculiar situation, to say the least, and I hope that both the government and the opposition, which were strong in support of this measure of exemplary accountability just three years ago, are going to remain in support of it now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —The second report of 1997 of the Procedure Committee, of which we are taking note, also has a recommendation that there be no change to standing order No. 50. Standing order No. 50 provides for the President of the Senate to open each parliamentary day with a public prayer to God for guidance, with the Lord's Prayer to follow. Senator Brown proposed that the public prayer to God be abolished. I am very pleased to see that the Procedure Committee has recommended against that motion. At this time of all times, we need the guidance of God and that is what standing order No. 50 has us doing, and I would like to express briefly my response to the attempt by Senator Brown to remove public prayer from this place.

SPEECH.PARA: The leaders of all nations must recognise that they do not have the power to rule absolutely. Failure to acknowledge this actually leads to human rights violations. Great minds formed in the Judaeo‐Christian ethic largely influence the terms of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, whose 50th anniversary we celebrate on 10 December next year.

The Prayer for Guidance and the Lord's Prayer, publicly recited by the President on behalf of senators, is a humble, public acknowledgment that parliament itself is subject to a higher law; that unjust and immoral laws are unjust and immoral, even if correct procedures are followed. The Our Father is as close to a universal prayer as exists in human culture. All religions accept the existence of a guiding, benevolent influence in human affairs if only we hand control of our destiny to the Creator. Given our heritage and history, it is entirely appropriate that we symbolise this in the public recital of the Our Father. The preamble to the Australian constitution itself also declares our intention of:
. . . humbly relying on the blessing of the almighty God . . .
To be secular is one thing; to seek to deliberately and publicly expunge recited prayer in the Senate is quite another.

The acknowledgment of the Divine is deeply embedded in our culture. To whom do our civic leaders publicly turn at times of crisis or national mourning? Look at what happened after the Port Arthur massacre. To whom did we turn, publicly? We turned to God. I recall hearing from a Salvation Army chaplain who was consoling those affected by the massacre down at Port Arthur. He said that one person came running down and angrily thumped his, the Salvation Army officer's, chest and said, `Where is your God now? Look at what has happened. Isn't he supposed to be in control?' The Salvation Army officer said to him, `Have you given control of your life to God?' Half an hour later, that man—a strong, strapping fellow—came back and burst into tears. He recognised how much things would be better if only we gave control to the Creator.

Society loses coherence if the foundation upon which our society is based—fairness, justice and human dignity—is rejected. If democracy is about the harmonious arrangement of the civil order, the better to achieve a more humane society, then best we publicly appeal to the one who endowed each member of the human family with an inherent dignity. What comes next? Do we change the weekend because Sunday is a Christian holy day? Do we create consequentialism day for Christmas?

I am very pleased that the procedure committee recommended against changing standing order 50. Standing order 50 does have the Prayer for Guidance. Perhaps there needs to be a minor change in words in there and in the Lord's Prayer, because the Prayer for Guidance says:

Almighty God, we humbly beseech Thee to vouchsafe Thy special blessing upon this Parliament, and that Thou wouldst be pleased to direct and prosper the work of Thy servants to the advancement of Thy glory, and to the true welfare of the people of Australia.
`Vouchsafe' is not commonly used and I would have thought a word such as `grant' would do equally as well. The Lord's Prayer starts with:
Our father, which art in Heaven, Hallowed by thy name.

I would have thought that `who' might be more appropriate there. I foreshadow that, at some future time, I will be moving to have the word `grant' for `vouchsafe' and the word `who' for `which'. If anybody else has any suggestions I would be grateful to receive them. I do appreciate the work of the procedure committee in upholding standing order 50.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek the leave of the Senate to speak for no longer than four or five minutes on this other matter which has arisen out of the report. As the Senate is aware, there are a number of matters.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave not granted.
Debate (on motion by Senator Calvert) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order. I seek your advice, Mr Acting Deputy President. I did hear you say that there was one other way in which it might be possible for me to speak.
—Not on the motion.

—I want some advice from the chair, not from you, Senator O'Chee. Am I correct in saying that there is no provision for me to speak on the motion that the matter be adjourned? I was standing at the time.
—On that point of order, I would have thought that, if somebody were to move that the debate be made an order of the day for a particular day, you could speak on that.

—Senator Brown and Senator Harradine, I am advised that the motion for adjournment is not debatable. The report that has been adjourned for further discussion comes up on the next day of sitting. It is at that time that Senator Brown may seek to speak to that report further. I am also advised that it is automatically adjourned to the next day of sitting, unless some further motion is moved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the resumption of the debate be made an order of the day for two sitting days after today.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can speak to that motion, Senator Brown, but your comments must be relevant to the subject of the time to which you have proposed adjournment.

—I think it is important that this matter be discussed or be available for discussion before the end of the year. It should not float off into the ether. It is important because the committee itself said in its report that there does not appear to be a strong view that the proposed abolition of the prayer is a significant question.

—I rise on a point of order. It is patently obvious that Senator Brown is now addressing the substantive recommendations of the committee and not the day on which this matter should be discussed. Accordingly, he is no longer relevant to the motion.

—I do not think you have a point of order at this time, Senator O'Chee. I think Senator Brown is stating why he thinks there ought to be another time for this matter to be discussed. But, if Senator Brown does journey too far from the point, I am sure I will advise him accordingly.

—One thing I would like to say, because we are taking up the time of the Senate now, is that, had the government not been so curmudgeonly as to deny me leave, this matter would have been finished by now. It occurs to me, as the person who moved the motion, that it is a motion we ought to get considerable opportunity to discuss. It is not a motion to abolish prayers but a motion to abolish the current form of prayers and replace it at the start of each day with a modern, up‐to‐date invitation to people, so that they are able to either pray or reflect on their duties to Australia—to the states and territories which they represent and to future generations.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not the biggest issue on our agenda. It never will be. But my fellow Tasmanian, Senator Harradine, has just foreshadowed a move to change two words in the current prayer, and I will support his opportunity to do that. So I think that after this move to not allow me to speak on the matter now, my move to have it debated before the end of the year is a reasonable one.

This is a matter that has attracted some public attention. It has been discussed by the churches. There has been criticism from Catholic bishops, for example. However, there has been quite strong and positive feedback, and alternatives have been put forward to me by other clergy and by members of the interested public.

I do not think that the matter should disappear out of here without some airing of those different points of view, some of which are very constructive and some of which, I believe, while not necessarily supporting the idea I brought forward, would make the observance at the beginning of the day more relevant, more interesting and more appropriate to each of us as we make some connection with what Senator Harradine describes, I think, as the higher order or the almighty and what I would describe as the life force and what other people might describe using other terminologies.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order. Senator Brown is not obeying your ruling and is straying from the matter at hand.
—There is no point of order.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I will be speaking on this, if the opportunity arises as a result of this motion, in a couple of days' time. I will certainly be seeking the opportunity to speak on the real contents of this and on the public input into and interest in this matter, without occupying any great time of the Senate. I do not want to see the matter treated in a way which prevents discussion and debate. That is what the government was trying to do a moment ago.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee entitled Helping Australians abroad: A review of the Australian Government's consular services , and I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
Review by the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee of the Australian Government's consular services

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 1: The Committee recommends that DFAT continue to explore sharing arrangements with other countries to increase the reach, effectiveness and efficiency of Australia's consular services.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has consular sharing arrangements with Canada, New Zealand and the United Kingdom. Consular sharing arrangements are also discussed with the foregoing and the USA and a series of annual meetings to discuss consular co‐operation has been initiated. The first such meeting took place in February 1997 in Honolulu and a further meeting is planned for later in 1997. Proposed instructions on sharing arrangements were sent to posts following the Honolulu meeting. Responses are now being received and will be analysed.

There are some constraints on consular sharing, notably the imbalance in consular capacity of the four partner countries. There are also indications that host officials in some countries will not co‐operate with some forms of consular service sharing. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) needs to ensure that any arrangements we enter are balanced and do not result in Australia assuming an unbalanced workload on behalf of a consular sharing partner. Despite specific constraints, consular sharing arrangements improve DFAT's ability to deliver consular services.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Government Response: Accepted. We will take steps to strengthen existing arrangements and continue to explore avenues for further consular sharing.
Recommendation 2: The Committee recommends that funding for consular activities at Austrade posts be separately identified.

SPEECH.PARA: Austrade's 1997/98 Operational Plan identifies the person years and cost of providing consular services. Austrade will continue to work with the DFAT in relation to budgetary support from these Departments for services provided by Austrade.

While the consular role is challenging, Austrade is committed to continuing its role in the provision of Australian consular services. The joint consular‐trade office arrangements provide for cost effective operations. Diplomatic status and the consular title facilitate Austrade's trade role by providing high level access and contacts which can be vital in developing markets.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Government Response: Accepted. Funding for consular activities at Austrade posts will be separately identified.
Recommendation 3: The Committee recommends that funding be provided to continue to expand the Honorary Consul system.

SPEECH.PARA: Honorary Consuls significantly increase Australia's representational network overseas. Our experience is that Honorary Consuls play a useful role in promoting Australia's interests into areas which are either not served or not easily served by fully accredited High Commissions or Embassies. Currently, Australia has 30 honorary consuls and the Prime Minister recently announced the establishment of a further six Honorary Consuls in Indonesia, namely, Ambon, Balikpapan, Kupang, Medan, Surabaya and Ujung Pandang. This is a firm recognition of the importance to Australia of the relationship with Indonesia. Arrangements are also under way to establish a further eleven honorary consulates in Bratislava, Christchurch, Copenhagen, Guatemala City, Durban, Karachi, Kingston, Luanda, Maputo, Panama City and Skopje and more may be established in the very near future. The consulate in Riga will be re‐established and an appointment is soon to be made in Vilnius.
Costs associated with honorary consulates are generally modest, consisting of honoraria and some running costs.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Government Response: Accepted. However, availability of funding is still an important factor and will be taken into account when considering establishment of further honorary consulates.
Recommendation 4: The Committee therefore recommends that DFAT provide staff assistance for Honorary Consuls who have a heavy consular workload.

SPEECH.PARA: Due to the high workload in the Honorary Consulates in Copenhagen and Zagreb, funding has been allocated for additional administrative support. An open commitment to funding for administrative support for all honorary consulates would have significant funding implications and could not be supported. Currently there are no requests for additional staffing assistance under consideration.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Government Response: Accepted. Individual requests for additional administrative support will be considered closely in the light of demonstrated workload.
Recommendation 5: The Committee recommends that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade examine options to enable locally engaged staff in Australian posts overseas to undertake notarial acts.

SPEECH.PARA: DFAT agrees that it could use its locally engaged staff (LES) more effectively by enabling them, in appropriate circumstances, to perform notarial acts. This would deliver cost efficiencies and relieve Australia‐based officers, from what is essentially routine work, to concentrate on higher priority functions. Notarial acts form a large part of the consular functions performed by Australian posts overseas (over 32,000 were performed in 1996/97) and are becoming an unsustainable burden on Australia‐based officers at our overseas posts.

Currently, domestic and international law precludes LES from performing notarial acts. As a first step towards implementing this recommendation, the Consular Fees Act 1955 has been amended to provide for the appointment of LES for the purposes of charging prescribed fees. Appointments will be made under authority of the Secretary of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. Further, in most cases, the Department will only appoint LES for these purposes who are Australian nationals to avoid potential complications under the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations.

Further steps to implement the recommendation will require consultation with State and Territory Governments to examine options to appoint LES to perform notarial acts under relevant State and Territory legislation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Government Response: Accepted. Amendments to the Consular Fees Act 1955 have been made, and in consultation with State and Territory Governments, we will examine options to enable suitably qualified locally engaged staff to perform notarial acts under relevant State and Territory legislation.
Recommendation 6: The Committee recommends that DFAT:
. investigate the possibility of producing Travelling Overseas? in languages other than English;
. pursue sponsorship for the production of Travelling Overseas?; and
. consider the need for more topic specific publications, in particular publications directed at backpackers and independent travellers.

SPEECH.PARA: There is some attraction to producing Travelling Overseas? in languages other than English. However, publication in languages other than English may result in only small reductions in the number of Australians who get into trouble in foreign jurisdictions. Significant administrative effort and cost would be involved in establishing which ethnic groupings would benefit most from publications in their own languages.

In investigating the possibility of producing Travelling Overseas? in other languages DFAT will seek to use available qualitative research to ensure that appropriate linguistic groupings are targeted. DFAT will also seek to gain sponsorship from business with ethnic contacts to defray any production costs.

In regard to sponsorship generally, DFAT currently secures commercial sponsorship for Hints for Australian Travellers. These arrangements are working well and DFAT will continue to work in this direction.

Publications targeted to reach particular sectors of the Australian travelling public such as backpackers and independent travellers serve a specific and valuable need. DFAT is already developing pamphlets and fact sheets on a variety of issues which may confront Australians travelling overseas. A pamphlet on sexual assault and another which provides advice to Australians in prison overseas will be published shortly. The pamphlet on prisons will also provide useful information for families of prisoners. Topics for a number of other sector specific fact sheets are under consideration and work will begin soon on a fact sheet for backpackers.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Government Response: Accepted. The Government will continue to respond to the information needs of the general travelling public, people from diverse linguistic backgrounds and also pursue sponsorship options for publications.
Recommendation 7: The Committee recommends that the global limit of traveller's emergency loans be reviewed to have regard to the cost of living of each country in which it is issued.

SPEECH.PARA: DFAT notes that there is sufficient flexibility within current arrangements to provide larger than standard advances to adequately assist Australians in financial distress overseas. The Department is further streamlining procedures for approvals for emergency loans, including through the new 24 hours Canberra‐based duty officer service. To replace the current system in the manner recommended would have limited practical effect and entail considerable administrative input to set and re‐set rates for individual countries. This is not sustainable in the current environment in which the Department operates. However, as part of its usual monitoring and review process, DFAT will remind posts that they can be flexible in using the present advance system whereby several advances can be issued. Upon referral to Canberra, posts are also able to obtain prompt approval for advances which are larger than normal.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Government Response: Not necessary. There is sufficient flexibility within current arrangements to ensure that Australians in need are provided with traveller's emergency loans at appropriate levels, without the need to develop, implement and maintain a complex and costly schedule of country specific loan amounts.

Recommendation 8: The Committee therefore recommends that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade institute measures to impound passports of travellers, to prevent the person from travelling overseas, while they owe a debt to the Commonwealth arising from a repatriation or medical evacuation, except in special circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: DFAT has been successful in recovering about 60% of loans extended for repatriation and medical evacuations—although this excludes sums which have been written off (including write‐off in special circumstances of one payment of $107,000).

The Passports Act 1938 and Regulations do not presently allow a passport to be impounded for the purpose of recovering a repatriation or medical evacuation debt. However, there are provisions allowing the cancellation of a passport on certain grounds and the requirement that such cancelled passports be delivered‐up.
There may be circumstances in which DFAT and other Departments may wish to impound a passport. DFAT will consult with other interested agencies.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 9: The Committee also recommends that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade put in place arrangements whereby, with the agreement of the recipient, the debt incurred through a repatriation or medical evacuation can be registered against existing Government entitlements or added to the recipient's future tax liability.

SPEECH.PARA: In the absence of a request, the Commonwealth may not be able to off‐set a person's debt against certain statutory entitlements.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Government response: Further consideration required. The Government will consider making appropriate arrangements in cases where recipients voluntarily request that debts incurred in repatriation or medical evacuations be registered against existing Government entitlements.
Recommendation 10: The Committee recommends that DFAT establish a free call service for callers to the Consular Branch from within Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: DFAT is currently studying options for the establishment of a free call service within Australia. A Freecall service would provide free telephone access to the Consular Operations area within DFAT from all public and private telephones. As an initial step the Department has established a special telephone number to assess the viability of a free call system. The special number will provide access to consular services from anywhere in Australia at the cost of a local call. Final establishment of a free call service will depend upon the availability of funds from within the current DFAT budget allocation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Government Response: Partially accepted. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has established a special telephone number providing access to consular services from anywhere in Australia at the cost of a local call.
Recommendation 11: The Committee recommends that the Department should continue, with the travel industry, to highlight the need for adequate insurance cover for travellers.

SPEECH.PARA: The Consular Branch within DFAT has conducted a series of seminars with the travel industry in most State and Territories. This program will continue.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Government Response: Accepted. The Government accepts the recommendation and will continue its program of industry consultation.

Recommendation 12: Accordingly, the Committee recommends that DFAT should negotiate with State and Territory Governments and with the Coroners to make arrangements for grieving or distressed families in their respective States and Territories to have access to their counselling services. DFAT should also maintain a list of private counsellors to provide to families.

SPEECH.PARA: The Department recognises the need for more formal counselling referral arrangements. This service would be offered to families in Australia affected by the death of next of kin overseas, as well as to individuals who suffer trauma while overseas. The Department has made contact with State and Territory coroners and has received a generally positive response. Letters have been written which seek to reach agreement on appropriate referral procedures and protocols.
Our advice is that coroners in most States and Territories would be able to assist families when next of kin die overseas and provide, or refer, families to bereavement counselling.

DFAT has been in contact with The Australian Psychological Society. The Society has a Freecall service as well as an extensive database of its members and details of their various areas of specialisation. Arrangements are being developed whereby DFAT will bring the services provided by the Australian Psychological Society to the attention of its consular clients. DFAT is also meeting with the Australian Funeral Directors Association to discuss possible areas of cooperation in cases where the remains of Australians who die overseas are returned to Australia for burial.
The Department is mindful that considerable tact needs to be exercised when discussing with clients the various services and support which can be provided by coroners, counsellors and psychologists.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Government Response: Accepted. Most State and Territory Coroners indicate a strong willingness to assist distressed and grieving families through services they provide. Action is currently underway to formalise referrals.
Recommendation 13: The Committee recommends that the Department should institute a formal counselling program for consular officers as soon as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: DFAT's Consular Officers constitute a dedicated team of people who are often placed under considerable strain and personal stress while helping their consular clients. The Department recognises the impact that consular work has on individual officers and has instituted a counselling program. The counselling service consists of group seminars and individual counselling sessions conducted by the Department's dedicated Staff Counsellor.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Government response: Accepted. A counselling program for consular officers within the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has already been instituted.

Recommendation 14: The Committee recommends that, where necessary, the mission should continue the practice of obtaining legal opinion from local lawyers if it believes that an Australian has not been given due process, has been or may be subject to cruel punishment in international human rights terms or has been subject to discrimination on nationality grounds.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's Missions overseas regularly seek, and will continue to seek, legal advice from local lawyers where this is considered necessary. This advice is sought to protect Australia's interests and enable Missions to be confident that Australians in difficulties overseas are accorded all due process of applicable laws. It should be remembered that this advice is sought to assist Missions, it is not secured to provide de facto legal aid to individuals in difficulties.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Government Response: Agreed. It is important that where necessary, Australia's missions obtain legal advice in certain situations to clarify issues affecting Australians overseas.

Recommendation 15: The Committee recommends that Australian posts overseas take steps to ensure that, as far as practicable, the lawyers included on lists provided to Australians in need of legal advice are reputable. Where applicable, the jurisdictions in which each lawyer can practice should be shown.

SPEECH.PARA: All posts are required to maintain lists of lawyers which operate in their countries of accreditation. These lists have provided valuable help to individual Australian overseas in need of legal assistance. All reasonable efforts are made to ensure that the lawyers included in these lists are reputable. However, posts will not always be in a position to certify the professional standards, including the competency or probity, of the legal practitioners listed.

In many countries it is not possible to identify the jurisdictions in which individual lawyers may practice as many countries operate their legal systems with "fully fused" professions, where individuals licensed to practice are able to practice in all courts and in all areas of the law.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Government Response: Accepted. Not all legal systems operate in a manner identical to that in effect in Australia. However, we will endeavour to have Missions overseas include as much information as possible in listings of local lawyers, including applicable jurisdictions.

Recommendation 16: However, in the case of Australian victims of crime and those facing serious charges in overseas jurisdictions, the Committee recommends that DFAT provide them with translator and interpreter services.

SPEECH.PARA: A commitment to providing interpreter/translator services overseas would have significant cost implications for the Government. In many cases interpreter/translator services are already provided by courts in other countries. When Australians are involved in court matters in countries in which the first language is not English, consular officers routinely seek to ensure access to interpreters/translators. However, Australian Missions are not always informed of the detention, arrest or trial of an Australian citizen. Australian officials have no right to insist on prisoner or victim access to interpreters/translators and some countries operate closed legal systems. There is no guaranteed right that any interpreter/translator retained by a post would be admitted to court proceedings.

In the current fiscal environment in Australia, provision of interpreter/translator services on a routine and free basis would be insupportable. In accordance with normal procedures, DFAT would need to fund this from within current funding allocations or seek additional resources in the context of the annual budget.

However, there will be particular cases which arise from time to time which, for particular reasons, demand that public funding be made available for translator and/or interpreter services. We consider that DFAT, in consultation with other Government agencies such as the Attorney‐General's Department, should consider such cases as sympathetically as possible and subject to appropriate financial tests. We expect that such cases would be very rare and in that funding, of necessity, would be ad hoc.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Government response: Not supported. The Government cannot commit itself to an open obligation to fund translators overseas. However, the Government is prepared to consider carefully providing translators and interpreters on a case by case basis.

Recommendation 17: The Committee recommends that in the case of the victims of crimes special consideration should be given to ensure that they have access to adequate legal representation, if required, in a foreign jurisdiction, that travelling and in country expenses be provided if these are not met by the foreign government and that funding for these services be provided under the Special Circumstances (Overseas) Scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: Legal and Family Services from within the Attorney‐Generals Department advise that this recommendation would require the appropriation of additional funds and this will be considered in its budget context.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Government response: Further consideration necessary. The recommendation requires additional funding and will be considered in the context of the budget of the Attorney‐General's Department.

Recommendation 18: The Committee recommends that the Attorney‐General seek the co‐operation of the States and Territories to implement the arrangements necessary for the introduction of the international prisoner transfer scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: In light of the humanitarian, economic and social advantages of international prisoner transfer schemes, the Commonwealth has been working closely with the States and Territories on legislation for this purpose and will continue to do so. The Commonwealth has enacted the International Transfer of Prisoners Act 1997 , which received Royal Assent on 18 June 1997.

With the exception of the Northern Territory, all State and Territory Attorneys‐General endorsed model complementary State/Territory legislation in October 1996. The Department's most recent advice from the States and Territories indicates that the Australian Capital Territory, New South Wales, Queensland, South Australia and Tasmania are hoping to introduce legislation before the end of 1997 and Victoria hopes to do so in 1998. There is at present no indication of Western Australia's intentions in this regard. The Northern Territory is still considering whether to participate in the scheme.
The priority given to the complementary legislation is, of course, ultimately a matter for individual States and Territories to introduce and enact the complementary legislation as soon as possible.
Once this complementary legislation has been enacted it will be necessary to put in place appropriate administrative arrangements for the implementation of the legislative scheme.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Government Response: Agreed. Commonwealth legislation providing arrangements for international prisoner transfer has already been enacted. The States and Territories (except the Northern Territory) have agreed in principle to enact complementary legislation and are preparing to do so.

Recommendation 19: The Committee recommends that the Attorney‐General's Department ensure that appropriate consular officers are advised when an Australian national is to be extradited to a foreign jurisdiction and that the person being extradited be informed of the assistance that may be provided by Australian consular officials to persons in gaol overseas.

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney‐General's Department will in future advise the relevant post and the Consular Branch of DFAT when an Australian national is to be extradited to a foreign country. DFAT will liaise directly with the authorities having custody of the person who is to be extradited to arrange for the person to be informed of the assistance available from Australian consular officials in the country to which the person is to be extradited.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Government Response: Agreed. The Attorney‐General's Department will advise the Consular Branch of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade when Australians are to be extradited to foreign jurisdictions.

Recommendation 20: The Committee recommends that, given Khmer Rouge General Paet's central role in the whole David Wilson hostage crisis including the death of the hostages, the Australian Government should take the strongest possible action at an international level should he be captured or defect and not be brought to trial for the death of the hostages.

SPEECH.PARA: DFAT has consistently made representations to the Cambodian authorities expressing Australia's wish that General Paet be brought to justice because of his role in the death of David Wilson. Where it can, DFAT follows up information regarding the whereabouts of General Paet. However, to date no firm or verifiable data has been obtained. DFAT is committed to maintaining contact with the Wilson family on this issue and will keep the family informed of developments concerning General Paet.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Government Response: Agreed. The Government is committed to seeing General Paet brought to justice for his central role in the David Wilson hostage crisis including the death of the hostages.
Recommendation 21: The Committee therefore recommends that the provision of information to families, in such distressing circumstances, be a high priority for DFAT and any mission abroad.

SPEECH.PARA: The Department is committed to providing a high level of service to both clients and their families. For example, officers from the Consular Branch within DFAT have visited families in order to discuss the issues surrounding particularly serious consular cases. This service will continue to be offered in cases which justify such a personal and direct response. This complements other initiatives such as referrals to counsellors, a special telephone number which provides access to consular services from anywhere in Australia at the cost of a local call and the 24 hour consular operations service. At the heart of this approach is a strong commitment to share as much information as possible with families and to treat them, as far as possible, as partners.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Government Response: Agreed. The Government is committed to providing a very high level of service to the families of Australians in difficulties overseas.

Recommendation 22: The Committee recommends that, in any future hostage crisis or similar event, DFAT provide guidance to the media rather than ignore the media. The Department should also explain its media strategy to a hostage's family.

SPEECH.PARA: Modern communications allow the media to have a critical influence on the shaping of news. DFAT has recognised this in its general operations and now conducts regular background briefings with the media. The Department is also willing to be as cooperative as possible with the media in consular cases. DFAT worked closely with the media during the hostage case involving Justin Fraser. However, there are constraints imposed by the Privacy Act and collaboration with the media will need to take this into account. In the context of the management of hostage cases, it will also be important for DFAT to counteract irresponsible or damaging media coverage which may jeopardise the successful outcome of particular cases. DFAT will ensure that its media strategies are fully explained to families of hostages.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Government Response: Agreed. Every effort will be made to provide guidance to the media. However, there will be times when circumstances demand that media briefings be extremely limited, particularly when there is a need to ensure that a client's physical safety is maintained and not compromised and also in cases where express requests for privacy have been made by the families of those directly concerned.
Recommendation 23: The Committee recommends also that Australia continue to urge regional countries to accede to The Hague Convention.

SPEECH.PARA: DFAT is committed to widespread accession to the Hague Convention. We have pursued this diplomatic campaign vigorously. Since June 1997, the Department has undertaken another round of representation encouraging countries to become party to the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. Where appropriate, Ministerial level representations have also been made. Representations have targeted countries within the Asia‐Pacific region or where there are relatively high numbers of Australian dual nationals.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Government Response: Agreed. The Government is pleased that our representations are generally receiving a more positive hearing now than they did in 1996. The countries which are either committed or preparing to become party to the Convention are: the Czech Republic, Fiji, Hong Kong, Philippines, Slovakia, South Africa, Sri Lanka and Turkey.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.
Debate (on motion by Senator Denman) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters on electoral redistributions, and I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Government Response to Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters' report Electoral Redistributions

SPEECH.PARA: INTRODUCTION

The Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters (JSCEM) tabled its report "Electoral Redistributions" on 19 December 1995. The Australian Government's response to the recommendations of the report follows.

That subsection 46(1) of the Electoral Act be amended so that the determination of State and Territory representation entitlements shall fall due in the thirteenth month after the first meeting of the House of Representatives.
1. Supported.

2. The Government agrees that representation entitlements should be determined in the thirteenth month after the first meeting of the House of Representatives. The Australia Electoral Commission (AEC) advises that if the determination was made in the thirteenth month rather than the tenth, the population figures provided by the Australian Statistician would be one calendar quarter closer to those applying for the next election. The AEC also advises that moving the determination to the thirteenth month should not unduly affect the Redistribution timetable.

That the determination of State representation entitlements continue to be based on the latest current estimates of population, rather than statistics projected to the anticipated date of the next election.
3. Supported.

That subsection 66(3)(a) and 73(4)(a) of the Electoral Act be amended, so as to extend the variation from average divisional enrolment allowed three and a half years after a redistribution from 2 to 3.5 percent.
4. Supported.

5. The Government notes that this was the most contentious issue at the JSCEM Inquiry—whether in fact the mid‐point tolerance of two percent provides Redistribution Committees with the flexibility to give due consideration to community of interest and other qualitative criteria.

6. The JSCEM noted the AEC caution that community of interest is an elusive criterion. However, on the evidence received, the JSCEM decided that the numerical criteria do not allow due consideration to be given to the qualitative factors. The JSCEM therefore recommended that the enrolment requirements be relaxed to the extent necessary to allow a realistic degree of flexibility.

That the Minister for Administrative Services meet with members of the six largest House of Representatives electorates to discuss means—short of introducing a weighting in favour of rural electorates—of improving the members' capacity to represent their constituents.
7. Supported.

That subsections 66(3)(b) and 73(4)(b) of the Electoral Act be amended to make "existing boundaries" subordinate to the other qualitative criteria, namely community of interests, means of communication and travel, and the physical features and area of the proposed division.
9. Supported.

10. The Government agrees that Redistribution Committees and Augmented Electoral Commissions should continue to have regard to existing boundaries, but that this requirement should be subordinate to the other qualitative criteria set out in the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 .

That subject to consultation with the ABS on relative population trends in the States and Territories, subsections 66(3)(a) and 73(4)(a) of the Electoral Act be amended to provide a shorter projection period for approximate equality of enrolments.
11. Supported.

12. Currently three and a half years after a Redistribution is the point at which approximate equality of enrolments should be reached. This point was chosen because it is the halfway point of the maximum seven year cycle allowed for a Redistribution.

13. However, where the cycle is terminated by a change to State and/or Territory representation entitlements, three and a half years may not be the most appropriate point at which to aim for equality of enrolments.

14. The AEC will undertake consultations with the ABS to determine whether relative population trends in the States and Territories can be used to form a basis for an amendment to the projection period.
That the period of seven years between redistributions of a State provided for in subsection 59(2) of the Electoral Act remain unchanged.
15. Supported.
The AEC and the ABS form a working party to determine the most effective methodology for enrolment projections.
16. Supported.

17. The Government notes that the AEC has consulted with the ABS about methodologies for enrolment projections and implemented an amended methodology in relation to the 1997 Redistributions of Queensland and the ACT.

Subject to Recommendation 8, that after the AEC has agreed on its enrolment projections (including the input from the DROs) the projections be forwarded to the ABS for an opinion to be published in the volumes of the AEC enrolment projections.
18. Supported subject to not requiring additional ABS resources.
That as early as possible in a redistribution, interested parties be advised in detail on the process to be used by the AEC for determining electoral projections.
19. Supported. Such advice was given in the 1997 Redistributions of Queensland and the ACT.
20. See also Recommendation 8.

That when the High Court's decision in McGinty v Western Australia is known, the AEC will provide the Committee with a detailed report on the implications for the redistribution provisions of the Electoral Act.

21. The McGinty case sought to strike down the current State Redistribution in Western Australia on the basis of the implied guarantee of representative democracy in the Constitution. There was also a possibility that specific provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 could be found to be invalid. The decision of the High Court is that the Western Australian provisions were valid and the Constitution does not require one‐vote‐one‐value either in the States or the Commonwealth. As there are no major implications for the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 , there is no need for a detailed report.
That subsection 65(2) of the Electoral Act be amended to provide that the quota is struck as soon as practicable after a redistribution has been directed.
22. Supported.

23. Currently, in accordance with section 65 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918, the quota is determined by the Electoral Commissioner at the close of the period for public suggestions and comments. While the intention is to ensure that the Redistribution Committee works on the basis of the most up‐to‐date figures, the provision means that those making the suggestions and comments must work in ignorance of the strict numerical constraint which will govern the redistribution.

That subsection 64(1) of the Electoral Act be amended to provide that the advertisement calling for suggestions and comments is placed by the Electoral Commissioner, rather than the Redistribution Committee, so as to allow interested parties to prepare suggestions while the appointment of the Redistribution Committee is being arranged.
24. Supported.

That section 64 of the Electoral Act be amended to provide that the Gazette notice calling for the suggestions and comments is published on a Wednesday, making the closing date for suggestions a Friday. The cut‐off time for receipt of suggestions should be 6.00pm, with the suggestions required to be available for perusal on the following Monday. A cut‐off time of 6.00pm should also apply for the lodging of comments.
25. Supported.

That the Electoral Act be amended as necessary to provide that comments and objections are made available for public scrutiny in a manner similar to suggestions (including provision for a 14 day period for lodging comments on initial objections).
26. Supported.

That section 72 of the Electoral Act be amended, so as to remove the requirement that persons or organisations must object to a Redistribution Committee proposal (or make suggestions or comments) to be able to lodge an objection to an Augmented Electoral Commission's proposed redistribution.
27. Supported.

28. The Government has noted that the right to lodge objections to an Augmented Electoral Com mission proposal is currently restricted to those who lodged suggestions, comments, or objections to the Redistribution Committee proposal. This restriction may have an adverse impact on other people affected by the Augmented Electoral Commission proposal. The Government believes that the current position encourages the lodging of objections to a Redistribution Committee proposal in order to retain the option of a later objection.
That in their reports Augmented Electoral Commissions respond to as many objections as is practicable, by way of collective response to groupings of similar objections.
29. Supported.

30. There were submissions that the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 should be amended to require that objections are responded to, even when the Augmented Electoral Commission does not make changes to the earlier proposals. The Government acknowledges that, while those making the objections should be aware of why an Augmented Electoral Commission arrived at its final determination, for reasons of practicality, timeliness and clarity, it is not considered necessary to amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 to require more detail to be given on objections not accepted. The Government supports the process whereby objections can be grouped together and responded to collectively. It is noted that this process has been adopted in the past, and that to date Redistribution reports have contained reasonably comprehensive explanations of chosen boundaries.
That in future, transcripts of the proceedings before Augmented Electoral Commissions be produced as a matter of course.
31. Supported.

32. There will be cost implications. It is estimated that the cost associated with the provision of a transcript service is approximately $80.00 per hour. Assuming an average of 40 hours of hearings for each Redistribution, plus additional administrative costs such as recording costs, providing hard copies of the transcripts and transferring the transcripts onto microfiche, costs in the order of $6,000 might be expected for each Redistribution. These additional costs will be absorbed.

That at the next two redistributions a system be trialed whereby the public is able, at set times during each of the "public input" stages of the redistributions, to book time on a stand‐alone version of the computing software used by the redistribution bodies. Reports on the trials should be prepared and made available in the final reports on the redistributions.
33. Supported.

34. Software facilities were made available for the Redistributions of Western Australia, the ACT and Queensland at a total cost of $15,728. Very little public interest was shown in them. As requested, software facilities were provided to the Parliamentary Library, the Liberal Party of Australia and the Australian Labor Party. A report on the trials will be in the final reports on the Redistributions of the ACT and Queensland.
That the AEC continue to provide its enrolment projections to interested parties in hard copy and electronically.
35. Supported.

That the composition of a Redistribution Committee and an Augmented Electoral Commission for a State, and the voting rights of the three members of the AEC on the Augmented Commission, remain as currently provided for in the Electoral Act.
36. Supported.

That, subject to the agreement of the ACT government, section 61 of the Electoral Act be amended to bring the membership of a Redistribution Committee for the ACT (and consequently an augmented Electoral Commission for the ACT) into line with the equivalent body for a state.
37. Supported.
That at future redistributions, the AEC or the Redistribution Committee publicise the naming conventions when public suggestions and comments are called for.
38. Supported. However, this publication should be the responsibility of the Redistribution Committee and the Augmented Electoral Commission rather than the AEC.

39. Guidelines on the naming of Divisions have been considered by two Parliamentary committees: the House of Representatives Select Committee on the Naming of Electoral Divisions (the Fox Committee) in 1969; and the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform in 1986. The naming of electoral Divisions was also the subject of some discussion at the latest JSCEM Inquiry.

40. The Government considers that the use of guidelines, rather than binding legal provisions, allows enough flexibility for unanticipated circumstances while providing Redistribution bodies with ample assistance in performing their task. However, given the apparent lack of awareness of the naming conventions, more effort will be made to publicise the naming conventions when suggestions and comments are called for. Guidelines were published in Queensland and the ACT with respect to the 1997 Redistributions.

That the naming convention which applies when two or more divisions are combined (that as far as possible the name of the new division should be that of the old division which has the greatest number of electors within the new boundaries) be amended to provide that, where the socio‐demographic nature of the division in question has significantly changed, this should override the numerical formula.
41. Supported. This was included in the published naming guidelines.

TITLE.XREF: MIGRATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (STRENGTHENING OF PROVISIONS RELATING TO CHARACTER AND CONDUCT) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Minchin) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard
Leave granted.

BREAK.PARA: The purpose of this bill is to ensure that the Government can effectively discharge its fundamental responsibility to prevent the entry and stay in Australia of non-citizens who have a criminal background or have criminal associations. In considering this bill, we must remember that the vast majority of non-citizens who come to Australia are in fact law-abiding people.

In a world of rapidly increasing people movements, our immigration arrangements must be designed to streamline the entry and stay of all genuine visitors, students, business people and permanent residents. However, a small proportion of non-citizens seeking to enter Australia do have substantial criminal backgrounds or criminal associations. Others commit crimes while they are in Australia.

Steps to improve the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs' ability to detect visa applicants with substantial criminal backgrounds or associations are being taken including consultation with law enforcement bodies overseas. For these steps to be effective, however, they must be complemented by legislative provisions to ensure that non-citizens with criminal backgrounds or criminal associations can be refused a visa. The provisions must also enable the Government to remove those non-citizens who are detained following convictions for crimes committed in Australia.

Experience over recent years has shown that the existing legislative provisions are inadequate for this task. This is despite the fact that they were amended as recently as 1992 with the express purpose of improving the Government's ability to deal with visa applicants and visa holders with a substantial criminal background. In broad terms, the bill seeks to enhance the Government's ability to deal with non-citizens who are not of good character in three ways:
. Firstly, decision‐making in routine cases will be improved by:
- requiring applicants to show that they are of good character;
- deeming that certain levels of criminal sentences will lead to an automatic finding that the non-citizen concerned is not of good character; and
- allowing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs to give binding directions to decision‐makers.

. Secondly, in exceptional or emergency circumstances, the Minister, acting personally, will be given powers to act decisively on matters of visa refusal, cancellation and the removal of non-citizens.

. Thirdly, information provided by Australian and international law enforcement agencies will be afforded more effective protection so that such agencies can be confident about passing information to immigration decision‐makers.
I will now describe the major provisions of the bill in more detail.

The amendments proposed in this bill introduce the concept of a character test. Under this test, the onus will be on visa applicants and visa holders to satisfy decision‐makers that they can pass the test. This will redress a significant deficiency in the legislation arising from the changes made in 1992. Since that time, decision‐makers have been required to establish that a person is not of good character before they could refuse a visa to an applicant or cancel a visa. This has meant that, whenever there has been doubt about the criminal background or criminal associations of a non-citizen, the doubt has been resolved in the non-citizen's favour. I understand that this was not the intention of the 1992 amendments.

This bill then takes us back to the situation that existed before 1992 by placing the onus of proof on the visa applicant to demonstrate that he or she is of good character. This means that where there are real doubts about the criminal background or criminal associations of a visa applicant or visa holder, the objective of protecting the Australian community will take precedence in immigration decision‐making.

This bill also seeks to establish clear benchmarks for criminal behaviour that would automatically lead to a non-citizen failing the character test. Non-citizens who have been convicted to a single sentence of detention of 12 months or more, or where the length of several sentences aggregates to two years or more, will fail the character test. This will truncate the character assessment process and cover most non-citizens of character concern who come to notice. This will provide more certainty as to who is able to pass the character test.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Binding directions on exercise of the discretion

BREAK.PARA: Once it is established that a visa applicant or visa holder does not pass the character test, decision‐makers will have to decide whether to refuse the application or to cancel the visa. Exercise of this discretion will need to take into account a wide range of factors including: the non-citizen's links to Australia; the nature of crimes committed; and any international law obligations.

This bill will enable the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs to give precise written directions on what weight is to be given to each of these factors. These directions must be binding on all decision makers, including merits review tribunals, to ensure a consistency of approach. The written directions will be tabled in Parliament.

Criminal intelligence and related information is critical to assessing the criminal background or associations of non-citizen visa applicants and visa holders. At present, it is difficult for the Department to use such information in making character decisions because its disclosure might be threatened. Australian and international law enforcement agencies are reluctant to provide sensitive information unless they are sure that both the information and its sources can be protected. Greater protection for such material would complement broader national and international strategies to counter transnational crime and the activities of those associated with it.

This bill increases the level of protection for such information. I cannot overstate the importance of this protection to the job of preventing the entry of foreign criminals to Australia. This was highlighted in the Minister's recent discussions with officials of international law enforcement agencies.

The opportunity to appeal character decisions to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) will be retained. However, there is a critical need to reform these arrangements in two main respects: firstly, in terms of speeding up merits review processes; and, secondly, in terms of ensuring that merits review decisions reflect community standards and expectations.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Merits review streamlining and time limits

BREAK.PARA: Where a non-citizen who is already in Australia is refused a further visa or has their visa cancelled on character grounds, it is essential that merits review cannot be used to prolong stay in Australia at taxpayers' expense. The average time currently taken for such cases at merits review is 227 days from the initial notification to a final decision. Many cases take even longer.

During this time, the non-citizens involved, many of whom have committed serious crimes, either will be in detention at great cost to the taxpayer or will be at liberty in the community. Quite frankly, this must stop. This bill introduces more streamlined procedures for dealing with such cases. It also introduces a strict 42 day time limit for the conduct of merits review cases involving character where the non-citizen is in Australia.

It has been argued that a delay of 90 days is required to achieve justice. All this does is lead to risks to the community, cost to the taxpayer, and for non‐citizens in detention—a slower resolution of their case.

We will ensure that all relevant documentation necessary for the AAT to determine the matter will be provided quickly, at the outset of the process. The amendments will establish a new process where the Department will be required to provide two copies of the relevant documentation to the applicant at the time of the decision. Then, at the time the appeal is made, the applicant only has to lodge one copy of the documentation with the AAT. The need for strict time limits is consistent with other review processes in the immigration area where delay can prejudice both the applicant and the community.

The provision will result in a more streamlined process, with the applicant, the Department and the AAT using less time and resources to obtain the necessary documentation. Currently much effort is devoted to, and delay arises in, pursuing papers and documentation from non‐citizens and the Department.
The strict time limit will prevent non‐citizens from further attempts to delay the resolution of their case.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Minister's power to intervene or set aside Administrative Appeals Tribunal decisions

BREAK.PARA: Over the past 12 months, the AAT has made a number of character decisions that are clearly at odds with community standards and expectations. The AAT has found a number of non-citizens, who have been convicted of very serious crimes, to be of good character, and has ruled that they should be granted a visa. This has alarmed the community and I might say the community, when they are aware of these decisions, hold the Government and not the AAT responsible.

It is essential that the Minister, acting personally, have the power to intervene or set aside such decisions in the national interest. The Minister should, however, continue to be required to table the making of any such decisions in the Parliament.

From time to time, there will be emergency cases involving non-citizens who may be a significant threat to the community. These people may be threatening violence or some other act of destruction or have a prior history of serious crime. In these emergency circumstances, the Minister, again acting personally, should have the power to act without notice and have them taken into detention.

Once the visa is cancelled, the non‐citizen will have a right to make a submission to the Minister as to why the cancellation should be revoked. Natural justice will apply in such cases. However, if they cannot satisfy the Minister that they pass the character test, they should be removed immediately. Parliament should be notified of the making of such decisions but the decisions should not be subject to merits review because of their national significance. The Minister is very accountable for his actions—to the Parliament, his colleagues, and to the people of Australia.

The provision is similar in nature to other provisions already present in the Migration Act—Subdivision F of the Migration Act (section 128) provides for cancellation offshore without notice and the right of the non‐citizen to make a subsequent submission as to why the cancellation or refusal should be revoked. This Subdivision was inserted in 1992 by the previous Government.

This bill sends a clear and unequivocal message on behalf of the Australian community. The Australian community expects that non-citizens coming to Australia should be of good character. To discharge this expectation, the Government must have the ability to act quickly and decisively, wherever necessary, to remove non-citizens who are not of good character. This bill meets our election commitment to the Australian people to strengthen the character provisions of the Migration Act.

In the House of Representatives, the Opposition said that they supported the bill, and that their proposed amendments were minor and would not affect the integrity of the improvements we are making. This is not the case. These key provisions are in response to the community's legitimate view that in emergency situations, such as if we are dealing with terrorists, the Government can act decisively and in the national interest to protect the community.
Ordered that in accordance with standing order 111, further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned till the first day of the Autumn sittings of 1998.
