TITLE.XREF: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (PARENTING AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 November, on motion by Senator Parer:

BREAK.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibbs, Sen Brenda

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security Legislation Amendment (Parenting and Other Measures) Bill 1997 is, for the most part, nothing but a further attack on one of the cornerstones of our society—the family. Families are being slugged with extra costs for child-care, extra costs for aged care and extra costs for medical care as a result of this government's slash and burn approach to health, housing, education and social security. This bill really does bring us back to a fairly fundamental question: what kind of society is it that we want to be living in as we approach the 21st century? Cuts to the aged, unemployed, and those who have children with disabilities have amounted to more than $10 billion in the last two budgets. The government's so-called `reform process' appears to be being driven by polls from talkback radio. I think Mr Howard has spent too much time lately talking with Alan Jones, John Laws and their ilk.

SPEECH.PARA: I urge all of you here today: please do not diminish our nation. The very things that we fight for and stand for in Australia, like a fair go for everyone and egalitarianism, are seriously under threat. This bill is value laden to the point that the government's key focus on the social security system is one of blame—blame the unemployed and those who are poor. The underlying view of the exponents of this bill is that those on social security are not accountable enough and are getting too much. I do not understand why families with children with disabilities are regarded as bludging off the welfare system.

As one who has established ongoing communication with people with disabilities and the organisations which represent them, I have had some very disturbing letters in recent times from organisations and individuals who are greatly concerned about some of the actions of this government and how they will impact on them.

The management committees of organisations which support people with disabilities often are made up of volunteers, and such organisations often depend on volunteer workers in other areas of their operations as well. We as a community owe them a great deal. They carry out many of the functions for which people in other organisations receive payment. These mean‐spirited actions adversely affect the lives of people who have the right to dignity, self‐respect and independence.

The focus of this bill, according to this government, is on ensuring that only those who are most in need get assistance. I ask you just how needy do some of these people need to be before they qualify for assistance. Some of the examples I would like to raise in relation to this bill really show up the government for what it is—a non‐egalitarian government which really is interested only in governing on behalf of all of us who have money and do not require support from the state.

I am concerned about the amendment to the Social Security Act to introduce a new income support payment called the parenting payment, which aims to replace the sole parent pension and existing parenting allowance. Single parents will be the big losers here; 900 sole parents will be excluded as a result of the change from a tapered assets test to a sudden death approach to asset assessment. In addition, over 7,000 more sole parents will lose from the imposition of an income maintenance waiting period.

It is dishonest of the government to make these changes under the guise of simplification. I seriously have to question whether these arrangements in practice would be simpler anyway. They certainly will not be fairer. I think that simplification is really just a guise for cuts in services.

A number of the proposed changes to the qualification provisions for child disability allowance are also of concern. These proposed changes would mean that, from 1 July 1998, eligibility for the allowance will be based upon a prescribed list of disabilities and a child disability assessment tool, details of which are yet to be provided, and child disability allowance arrears will be cut from 12 months to six months.

It is estimated that over 4,000 families with young children who have disabilities will have their access to the child disability allowance denied next year as a direct result of the proposed changes. Over 4,500 will lose up to six months arrears of child disability allowance because of the proposed reduction in arrears from 12 months to six months.

The government has argued that the number of child disability allowance claimants has doubled over the last five years and has had the temerity to insinuate that this is because people who do not deserve the allowances are rorting the system. This insinuation is blatantly dishonest as well as being a sleight on those parents claiming child disability allowances. It ignores the fact that there has been no evidence of parents rorting the system. The fact is that the education campaign carried out by the DSS was effective in that it alerted people to the fact that there was assistance for them. Consequently there have been more claimants.

The most insidious part about it is that, true to fashion, the government is proposing that these changes not happen now—when public outrage is at its highest and public opinion can be most effectively mobilised—but in nine months time, when the media are busy addressing other issues. If you are going to be so cold‐blooded, at least have the honesty to bring in changes at the time they are legislated for so that people can really judge you on your record at that appropriate time.

These proposals form part of a sustained attack on people with disabilities by this government and are reminiscent of similar actions which saw 30,000 Australians lose their eligibility for financial assistance for hearing aids. These allowances are a small amount to pay to give people the chance for independence. They should be seen for what they are—an investment in people's lives, not a liability.

Schedule 3 makes 255 amendments to the Social Security Act to change the name `family payment' to `family allowance'. This will require a large amount of reprinting of information products and forms—all at taxpayers' expense. I believe this money could be spent a lot better by supporting families who have children with disabilities.

The government's continuing assault on families with children with disabilities is breathtaking and outrageous. Schedule 4 should be amended to remove the requirement that severe financial hardship has arisen because of unavoidable and essential expenditure. The requirement for severe financial hardship to have arisen because of prescribed unavoidable and essential expenditure is too harsh.

A person with liquid assets of less than two weeks payment—about $350—and no prospect of payment is desperate regardless of how they arrived at this situation. In reality, those who will be affected by this provision are either families who have less than $600 in the bank and no prospect of income or single people with less than $350 in the bank and no prospect of income.

The underhanded and misleading presentation of the proposed changes is offensive in the context of provisions supposedly designed to provide stability and support for those most in need. Schedule 5 is designed to allow children with disabilities who no longer qualify for CDA to keep their health care cards. This would seem to be a reasonable and egalitarian measure, enabling greater access to services by people suffering from a wide variety of disabilities.

However, schedule 5 contains another provision which bases eligibility for a disadvantaged person's health care card on income averaged over eight weeks rather than four weeks. This particular measure will result in over 4,500 people becoming ineligible for the card. Hence, while schedule 5 is supposedly designed to enhance service provision for those in need, it is actually enforcing further restrictions on the already stringent eligibility criteria. I think it is somewhat devious of the government to try to promote aspects of the bill that enhance service provision while ignoring aspects that will inevitably counteract any such measures.

In this context it is particularly noteworthy that the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee produced a substantial minority report on this bill. The minority report opposed the imposition of an income maintenance period for sole parents. It highlighted the fact that sole parents are the group of social security recipients most likely to be in poverty and that employment opportunities for these people are continually restricted by the demands of balancing work and family commitments. Consequently, provisions designed to assist sole parents should not be excessively punitive or difficult to access.

The minority report also condemned the proposed reduction of the maximum period for which CDA arrears are payable. Evidence provided to the committee indicated that payment of 12 months in arrears of CDA is still justifiable because parents often spend an extended amount of time seeking appropriate diagnosis and treatment for their children. In the context of such ongoing family upheaval, many find it difficult to adjust quickly to the requirements of social security agencies. The recommendations of the minority report, therefore, represent an appeal to the government to reconsider their approach to social security and aspire to a platform more conducive to the maintenance of the egalitarian values held dear by most Australians.

Schedule 6 of the bill raises new concerns with regard to privacy. It replaces references to specific social security payments in the Data‐matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act with a generic reference to payments made under the Social Security Act. This provision would ensure that data matching can continue when the government either changes the name of a current payment or introduces a new one.

Schedule 6 would also enable data matching information to be transferred between agencies by online computer connection. This provision is of particular concern, despite government assurances with regard to the security of personal information. The actual bill does not outline any measures designed to make such an online connection secure. This is a matter of considerable importance and concern for many Australians. Consequently, Labor's amendments in the Senate will insert the requirement that the transfer of data must be carried out by secure online connection. The opposition are also particularly interested in the possibility of intervention by the Privacy Commissioner with regard to these provisions.

Like the aged care legislation, the government is forcing this legislation through without providing the detail of the list of disabili ties and the child disability assessment tool. The new parenting allowance may remove the stigma of the sole parent pension, but at a price. And most of the losers will be sole parents. The government's argument that it will be simpler is dubious. The new payments essentially reproduce existing arrangements but as subtypes of a payment rather than separate payments. Hence, this bill represents an attack by the government on those least able to defend themselves: sole parents and the disabled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senators Neal, Bartlett and Gibbs for their contributions to this debate. At the outset, I would like to welcome the indications of support which the opposition and the Democrats have given for the generality of this bill. The measures in the bill are a continuation of the government's efforts to build a simple social security system that is fair to those in need and fair to taxpayers.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to very briefly mention two of the measures. The introduction of the new parenting payment says to all parents, `We value your contribution. We know looking after kids is a real job too.' One consolidated payment highlights that that is what it is all about. The role should not be stigmatised, whether you are a lone parent or whether you have a partner. Core conditions for lone parents have, of course, been protected. As Senator Bartlett has requested, I am happy to say that the government undertakes that the pensioner education supplement will continue to lone parents receiving the single rate of parenting payment.

I turn to the child disability allowance. These changes are ones which have been six years in gestation. Since 1991 my department has been diligently reviewing the adequacy of assessing CDA. After a very thorough consultation process, it has brought forward these proposals; proposals in which the previously highly subjective assessment criteria are to be replaced with a test that more objectively measures the true level of disability. These changes have been welcomed by a large number of child disability groups and the medical profession. We are also proposing to change the period in which CDA can be back paid from 12 to a still generous six months. I will say more about that during the committee stage.

Senator Allison gave notice of a motion calling on me to make an official statement regarding data on CDA recipients. While I have already answered a question on notice for Senator Allison on this issue, I would again like to make the situation clear. The facts are that in 1995 the department misinterpreted data supplied by the ABS, and this misinterpretation did not come to light until July this year. It was not obvious that the data had been misinterpreted because other data held by the department also indicated that at least 21 per cent of children qualifying for CDA did not have a disability in the same functional areas as measured by the ABS survey of disability, ageing and caring.

These corroborating data were taken from an analysis, by Coopers and Lybrand Consultants, of a sample of children who qualified for CDA in 1994. It was found that 29.7 per cent of parents and 27.2 per cent of treating health professionals rated the CDA child as having mild symptoms which did not stop the child from doing most things done at their age. Then in 1996‐97 Ernst and Young, when field testing the new CDA assessment tool, found that 22.6 per cent of children were rated by their parents as having no identifiable disability in the functional areas of communication, self‐care, social and community living skills, and fine and gross motor mobility. These areas correspond to the areas described in the ABS statistics. So, while the ABS survey of disability, ageing and caring cannot be used to measure the level of handicap of children who qualified for CDA in 1993, the other studies fully vindicate the use of a figure of at least 21 per cent.

In the interests of saving time I will not go into the other schedules, but I remain happy to answer any questions. I do thank senators again for the constructive approach that has been taken on this bill so far, and I look forward to its continuing in the committee stage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I do not think you were here when I gave my speech in the second reading debate.
—No.

—You may recall, Minister, that there have been concerns expressed by the opposition about the loss of the tapered assets test. It has been changed from that situation to a sudden death assets test. It seems, on the information from the department itself, that there are 900 sole parents who will lose as a result of this change.

SPEECH.PARA: I also have a great deal of a problem with a sudden death assets test. I think, in many cases, it discourages sole parents from trying to improve their positions. It encourages them in fact to rely on social security and not to make other efforts. So I have a real problem with these sorts of changes. There is also another group that appear to be losers as a result of schedule 1 of the government's bill and that is the 7,300 sole parents who will lose from the imposition of an income maintenance waiting period. It is of particular concern that the government has confirmed that a person will have to serve an income maintenance period when transferring from a partnered to a single rate of parenting payment or, indeed, at any time that they receive a leave payment of a lump sum. This could include a normal holiday period. I think this is a matter of great concern, and I would be pleased to hear from the minister as to why she thinks it is reasonable that, when they get their normal holiday pay, sole parents should lose the benefit that they are receiving.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum and a correction to the supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendments to be moved to this bill. The memorandum was circulated in the chamber on 18 November and the correction on 26 November.

SPEECH.PARA: In answer to Senator Neal about the 900 sole parent pension recipients who will have their payment cancelled, I think it is important to note at this stage that they are not full sole parent pensioners. In fact, they are part pensioners receiving an average payment of $200 per fortnight. But the reason that they get caught by this change is that, to lose payment under the measure, they have either got to own their home plus $125,750, or own $215,750 all up. By anybody's assessment, they are people with some personal wealth, and I think it is not without relevance that this will produce estimated program savings of $4.887 million in the first year alone.

The parenting payment aligns a number of conditions that currently vary between the existing payments, and alignment includes this measure—extending to lone parents the non‐tapered assets test that currently applies to the parenting allowance. So it inevitably means that lone parents with assets which exceed the assets test threshold that parenting allowance people receive will not be entitled in the future to parenting payment.
Progress reported.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Days and Hours of Meeting and Routine of Business

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I appreciate the fact that the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Ian Campbell) has attended the chamber so we can really establish where the Senate might take the debate on the Native Title Amendment Bill . I think there are a number of issues that are before us that need to be quickly ironed out in relation to the progress of the Native Title Amendment Bill .

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to indicate to the Senate that earlier Senator Hill provided me with a document entitled `Draft proposal to facilitate additional sitting hours', which included a number of suggestions in terms of an approach for sitting times and routine of business for the Senate, some of which appears to have not been followed through by the government. I do understand that there have been discussions between the Manager of Government Business in the Senate and the Manager of Opposition Business in the Senate (Senator Carr). I also understand that the whips have been negotiating a number of issues that are before us.

There is, as I understand it, a suggestion before us that the Senate sit on Thursday night. There is a proposal before us that the Senate sit on Friday of this week. As far as the opposition is concerned, there is a significant issue for us, and I believe all senators, in relation to the scheduling of general business tomorrow, Thursday.

As I understand it, there had been a suggestion floated at one point that the Senate sit this evening also. I understand that that has not found favour around the chamber and the government has indicated that it is not proceeding with that particular proposal.

I want to indicate that the opposition is willing to provide general business time tomorrow and Thursday to deal with government business. We are willing to agree to a proposition that the Senate sit on Thursday evening to deal with government business. We are willing to agree with any proposition that is put forward that suggests the Senate can deal with government business on Friday. But, as far as we are concerned, that government business must be the Native Title Amendment Bill .

We are also of the view that, in that circumstance and in putting forward that proposal in the spirit that I do, it is incumbent on the government to give a commitment that it will bring the Native Title Amendment Bill on for debate as of the commencement of government business tomorrow. That seems to me to be a very reasonable approach in this circumstance.

I put to the Manager of Government Business that I think we have reached the stage where there is a need for us to provide a level of clarity and certainty about sitting times for the remainder of this week's sitting period. I really think it is now overdue that the matters that have been discussed informally amongst senators are clarified and that we make some clear decisions in relation to how the Senate approaches the remainder of this week's sittings.

I think what I put forward on behalf of the opposition is a very generous proposal, and I do it in the spirit that I understand there are a very significant number of speeches to be made in the second reading debate on the Native Title Amendment Bill . Obviously, a long and complex committee debate has to be carried out in this chamber, and I believe it is essential that we get to that committee debate as soon as possible and commence the work that I think senators right around the chambers have acknowledged needs to be done as soon as is possible or practicable.

We really have to honour that commitment we have to the broader community to deal with what I believe and have said previously is one of the most important pieces of legislation that this parliament will have to deal with, if not the most important piece of legislation, during the life of this parliament. I put forward that proposition to the Manager of Government Business. With general business time tomorrow, if the Senate sits on Thursday evening and on Friday, it will really provide quite a significant amount of time to deal with these important matters before us.

But I also believe the government needs to give a commitment that that time that the Senate can utilise for government business will be dedicated to the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 . I believe it is appropriate in these circumstances also that the manager gives a clear commitment—that the government shows its bona fides and demonstrates that it is also fair dinkum about this debate—that the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 will be brought on for debate as the first item of government business tomorrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The Democrats fully support the bringing on of the native title debate as soon as we possibly can. We support sitting through tomorrow night—I presume we are talking about 10.30 p.m.—and dealing with government business all day Friday. I know that the government has to get at least two of the other bills through. But there will probably be about six senators carrying the bulk of the work as we move into the committee stage of the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 . I am sure they would appreciate a couple of breaks through the next week as we sit through I do not know how many hundreds of amendments—I think we are up over 500. Other government business can be slotted in for an hour or two at a time as we work our way through the committee stage of native title.

SPEECH.PARA: But I think it is extremely important that we continue with the second readings uninterrupted and that all senators who want to have their chance to speak are able to do so, if possible this week. We have probably close to 1,000 people here, who would not normally be in Canberra, waiting for this debate to come on. We saw how many people were in the gallery last night. I have been approached by a number today, particularly from the Aboriginal community, who are worried about their resources if this bill just drags on and on. We as a parliament have to think about the resources of those people who have come, I feel, to make the democratic process work a lot better. I felt last night, as we sat here with so many people in the gallery, that it is a shame they do not come for social security bills and a whole range of other legislation. But obviously this particular bill is seen by the community as one of the most important bills we will deal with this year, if not the most important bill, and I think we should get on with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The issue of the disempowerment of indigenous people is quite clear when it comes to the way this legislation has been put together. But there is no reason to compound that error by making sure that those people who come to see, at the very least, the second readings and the start of the committee stage do not have the chance to see that at this time. If people want to put the debate into quiet times in backrooms, you can only wonder why. Perhaps it is because the tide is turning in the community debate. Perhaps the government sees the need to be in the dark, in the quiet and on the quick. But that is not what the community deserves. The very least we deserve is to now deal with the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: As has been mentioned, there will continue to be times during this debate when we will need time to take a break from the legislation. There will be opportunities to do other committee stage work during that time if we have to wait for messages from the House of Representatives and so on. We do have the opportunities to do that. There is absolutely no excuse for not getting on with what we are now in fact being forced to do by the government, which is to consider the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 . But we at least owe it to those people who have been disempowered from the process of decision making to at least let them hear what excuses people have for the positions they are taking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I appreciate the consensus that has emerged in the offer of the opposition to give up general business time tomorrow afternoon to facilitate the second reading debate of the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 and the indication that they would support a move to sit tomorrow evening—which was a move initiated by Senators Margetts and Brown in a letter to me dated last night—and to facilitate government business on Friday.

SPEECH.PARA: At this stage—and I think people recognise this; certainly Senator Lees did in her contribution—the government does need to complete the piece of legislation we have interrupted for this short debate, that is the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Parenting and Other Measures) Bill 1997 . We do need to have the States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 . I do not think anyone would deny that we cannot go without that; I am sure the states would not. I think there is a recognition from Senator Lees that the migration agents matter needs to be resolved. If it is not resolved, then there is no regulatory scheme for migration agents in Australia.

Senator Lees, it may be the case that there may be some sort of hiatus or interregnum at some stage during the native title debate. However, it is very hard to envisage that at the moment. As much as you might think it is a good way to say, `We'll give you a wink and a nod and we'll fix it up at some stage next week,' we have taken the view that it will be better to get these things done, then get into native title and keep it going non-stop.

I cannot agree totally to what Senator Faulkner sought in relation to our saying that we will commence native title at a specific time. However, we will seek to make that agreement before I bring a motion forward. We will seek to find an agreement on these remaining items.

We are into the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Parenting and Other Measures) Bill 1997 . If that is dealt with quickly, it could take only half an hour. I thought sugar would take only an hour this morning, but there were a number of Democrat and Labor Party speakers who ensured that the debate was longer than I thought it needed to be—but that is entirely up to senators. I believe discussions are taking place about migration, and it may not take as long as people envisaged it might.

There is no doubt that it is possible to get through the remaining items on today's red in a relatively short time. I would have thought by the middle of tomorrow morning you should be able to get through those items with good will and—

TALK.START.PARA: —Good will from you, Ian.

—Yes, good will from me as well. I am not going to commit the government at this stage. I am happy to have a chat with the Manager of Opposition Business in the Senate, Senator Carr, and other senators over the next few minutes to try to work out a sensible compromise to this. These are pieces of legislation we need. I already indicated, Senator Lees, in a debate this morning that the government would have liked to have used any hiatus in the native title debate to deal with other items we have already dropped off.

SPEECH.PARA: We have already said that we will drop the Legislative Instruments Bill message and have it considered during any hiatus period. The same applies to the Workplace Relations Amendment Bill 1997 [No. 2] , which again should not take long. We were hoping to deal with that if there is any hiatus in the native title committee stage. I think the Productivity Commission Bill is something that could be dealt with quickly, but we have dropped that below native title.

If we can get an agreement from all senators that the migration bills will be facilitated before the Senate adjourns at the end of 1998, it will make it a lot easier for the government. I think you will respect that.

TALK.START.PARA: —You might even suggest 1997.

—That would be even better for the migration agents. I have been looking at the sitting schedule for 1998 over the last half‐hour and I am a bit ahead of myself for once in my life. That would be the government's position. We appreciate the undertakings that have been made. We hope that we can make an undertaking that will make everybody happy. I will talk to the Manager of Opposition Business over the next few minutes. I indicate that I will seek to come back and, by leave, move a motion to facilitate the changes to the Senate's orders to achieve what I hope will be a unanimous agreement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The opposition, as has been indicated by Senator Faulkner, is concerned to ensure that we progress the discussion of the Wik legislation as soon as possible. We have been told for many weeks now that this government has every intention of proceeding. We are very concerned that good intentions are not translated into actions. I trust that from these discussions you are proposing we will see genuine action follow. We were told that we were to start the Wik legislation on 24 November. We were told that this was a matter that would take precedence over all other matters. That has not occurred.
—We never did.
—Yes, you did. You said that many times to me, Senator Campbell.
—We did not say that.

—You said that this is a matter of such importance to this parliament that it would take precedence over all other matters from 24 November. That has not occurred. We have been told on many occa sions many different things about the legislative program.
—Who did I say that to?
—To me.
—I did not. That is an outrageous lie!

—What I would suggest to you, Senator Campbell, is that this is a matter that is now drawing considerable public attention. It is your responsibility to ensure that this parliament has adequate time to discuss these matters. Serious questions are now being asked as to whether or not this government wants these matters considered.

SPEECH.PARA: If it was your intention to keep this parliament sitting until Christmas, you should have made that very clear. I think you will find a number of senators here will be very interested in your response to that proposition. What is your proposal in regard to the sitting periods in the weeks ahead of us? Is it your intention to actually seek additional sitting periods or not? We are concerned that what we have before us today is a strategy that will see this parliament sit for longer than has been proposed to this point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I thought we were coming to a consensus before Senator Carr got to his feet. We have been over all of those matters that Senator Carr raised. Those sorts of comments are not helpful. I must say that I am rather anxious to get on to the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 . But for weeks I have understood that the government indicated we would do so after the bottom line had been reached. I know that they have put quite a number of things below the bottom line in order to get a realistic bottom line.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand the point the Manager of Government Business (Senator Ian Campbell) makes—that is, we do need to get the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Parenting and Other Measures) Bill 1997 and the States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 dealt with. If we do not resolve or deal with in some way the Migration Legislation Amendment (Migration Agents) Bill 1997 and related bills, the sunset clause will come into effect and the whole thing will hurtle over the edge and there will be a free-for-all in that particular area. That will be a great problem. So we have to deal with that.

When we deal with it is another question. If there is a hiatus at some time during the Native Title Amendment Bill considerations, I think that hiatus has to be identified at some stage beforehand so that we know that we will be going off native title to wrap up the other measures. It certainly will not give me a rest from sitting in this seat and being in the chamber because the social security measure and the migration legislation measures are matters which I will need to be here for.

Nonetheless, if we are going to identify a hiatus, let us do so. When the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Faulkner), the Manager of Government Business and the Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Lees) and the Greens talk about these matters, if they can then identify that so that we know precisely when we will go back to the migration legislation, we will be able to be prepared for that. All in all, if we get on with it we will finish social security and states grants tonight and be on migration legislation for a few minutes before the adjournment motion is put at 7.20 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I clarify the procedure at this stage? We and the Democrats have some amendments to these amendments. Should our amendments be put first or should these amendments be put first and then we amend those things that have already been carried?
—The amendments that the opposition and Democrats are planning to move, as I understand it, are amendments to the minister's amendments. So the minister moves hers first and then you can move yours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bartlett, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Item 40, definition of income maintenance period, omit ``, 1068A‐E3 and 1068A‐E4''.
Item 236, omit subsections 015A(12) and (13).

TALK.START.PARA: —These amendments, and those following that are foreshadowed on the running sheet, deal with the income maintenance period. They need to be moved separately because of the logistics of the situation. The income maintenance period is being proposed by the government in relation to sole parents. It is widely acknowledged that sole parents are the group of social security recipients who are most likely to be living in poverty. That is something the Democrats are always very conscious of when considering any legislation that alters payment rates or conditions for sole parents.

SPEECH.PARA: As I indicated in my speech on the second reading, the Democrats' initial response to the legislation was one of some concern. It seemed that sole parents had much to lose from some of these proposals and little to gain. As I said previously, the minister's office was able to reassure us on a number of issues—and I do thank them for that—most particularly that the rate of payment to sole parents would be maintained at the pension rate and pegged to average weekly earnings and that sole parents would continue to receive the pensioner concession card.

It is fair to say in light of those undertakings that the peak body representing sole parents, the National Council of Single Mothers and their Children, broadly supported the introduction of this payment, but it is true that they have a number of outstanding concerns nonetheless. One of those is the effect that an imposition of an income maintenance period will have on sole parents. They point out, and the Democrats support them, that this move is likely to increase the level of poverty amongst sole parents, who are undeniably those who are most likely to be living in poverty in the community. I highlight the fact that sole parents are more likely to have a broken connection with the work force as a result of their need to balance work and family responsibilities.

Broadly speaking, the Democrats have not been overly keen on income maintenance periods in any case, so I suppose to that extent it is not surprising that we are not too keen on this one either because we believe it reinforces the potential for poverty traps. Given the particular poverty levels of sole parents especially, the Democrats are opposing the imposition in this legislation of an income maintenance period for sole parents.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments moved by Senator Bartlett for the Democrats are joint amendments with the opposition and concern a matter that I mentioned earlier in discussion. There are some 7,300 sole parents who are going to be worse off because of this measure. I am particularly concerned about the matter I raised earlier. There may be some sole parents who receive a pension and also work who might be adversely affected such that when they take their annual holidays they lose their payment. I would like the minister to deal with that matter in particular, because I could see that as causing great hardship if, every time these sole parents take a holiday, they suddenly substantially lose part of their income. That will mean that they cannot take holidays. It seems to me a particularly harsh provision, and I would really be pleased if the minister could explain that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to those who are taking leave, I understand that that is the position that already exists. That is not a change for them. I will try as simply as I can to deal with what I think is some confusion about how the income maintenance period works. If you leave a job and you are paid out for accumulated leave, the payment is treated as income as if you earned it over the period of the leave, just as if you were still in work.

SPEECH.PARA: For example, Barbara is on a parenting payment at the single rate. She works permanent part-time, earning $200 a fortnight. She accordingly receives a part rate of the parenting payment of around $315 a fortnight. If she leaves her job and is paid out $200 for two weeks accumulated leave, in the two weeks after she has left work, she is assumed to have earned $200 in that fortnight and will receive a part rate parenting payment of $315. In the following fortnight she will be assessed as having no income and will receive the full rate parenting payment of $353.20.

Examples show that some of the claims about an income maintenance period are simply wrong; they are inaccurate. You do not have to spend all your leave pay to qualify for benefits. All it is saying is that if you have been paid out for leave, you are effectively earning income in that period of leave. All we are doing is extending to the leave payments the normal income testing that has always applied to lone parents. This measure currently applies to all allowees. It is inconsistent to apply it to these other income support recipients leaving jobs but not lone parents.

It is those sorts of ad hoc exemptions that have made the social security system even more complicated. I know that Senator Bartlett is very keen to see simplicity in the system. Consistency of treatment of people who are in like circumstances is surely a basic in making this system simpler. This is not a cruel or unconscionable measure. I think the opposition to it has perhaps been based on misunderstandings.

These amendments relate to schedule 4 of the legislation and deal with applying consistent hardship rules to ordinary waiting periods, liquid assets tests waiting periods and income maintenance periods. As I have said a couple of times on this bill, consistency is a wonderful thing and is to be much encouraged.

Having had a bit to do with social security legislation issues off and on over the years, the utilisation of the word `consistency' has sometimes caused me to develop a bit of cynicism about it being a cloak for saving money. Therefore, it was quite pleasing to see in the explanatory memorandum and from further discussions with the minister's office that this, as I understand it, is a utilisation of consistency which is going to be of some benefit to people. It will be around $10 million in a couple of years' time. So my cynicism has now been reduced, which is much appreciated. I thought it always got worse when you got into parliament, but I will turn it around, at least for the moment.

The amendments that the Democrats are putting up basically ensure that the measure is more likely to end up operating in the way it is intended. We still have reservations about the use of the term `unavoidable and essential'. I understand that the reason why this is going to result in slightly more payments to people, as is put forward, is that the current provisions have been strictly interpreted, or interpreted in a strict way. This new wording will be interpreted in a way that will enable more people to receive payments.

The Democrats believe that it might be safer to utilise the wording that we are putting up here, which is `unavoidable or reasonable'. It is still a subjective assessment but one that is less open to a strict interpretation and perhaps more likely to provide clearer guidance to the hardworking officers in the department when they have to interpret these subjective clauses.

SPEECH.PARA: If a person earning less than $286 a week applied for a low income health care card today, they would get it. For example, it means that a person who earns a perfectly adequate income in the course of a year but does not work over a three-week Christmas shutdown could get a card—three weeks of low income; six months of a concession card.

There is another situation in which these provisions can be used for purposes for which they are not intended. Senator Bartlett talked about these great people who worked for Social Security and who now work for Centrelink. I agree with him. It was people like that who told me about what I think is a misuse of the card: that is, TAFE students who apply for a low income health care card over the Christmas holidays simply so they have the evidence to get a reduction from state governments in their TAFE fees. That may be a worthy outcome, but it is not the purpose for the which the cards were intended. I think that is a distortion of the system. It is something which was probably never thought of when the low income health care card was produced. That is what we are talking about. We are not talking about people on benefits; we are talking about people who have been on low incomes and who currently have only their previous four weeks income averaged. If their income level is eligible, then they go on to it.

Assessment over eight weeks will ensure that cards are going not to people for whom low income is an anomaly but to people for whom low income is a reality. Every genuine low income earner remains fully protected. Let me reiterate that: it will not make for a waiting period. Assessment is in the weeks prior to the application, not after. So not one low income earner will have to wait for a card any longer than at present. I urge the opposition parties to reconsider their amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite common to have the minister come in and tell us about these fictional people rorting the system.
—You should go round Centrelink like I do.

—What I would like the minister to provide us with is evidence of all these rorters manipulating the system. I remember that on the last occasion when the minister was going to provide us with evidence we had a correction put on the record. Minister, do you have any such evidence about these sorts of people that you allege we must guard against?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I made it quite clear that I go around Centrelink offices as much as my Senate duties allow and I get this advice and information from people working behind the desks in the Centrelink offices. I came back to the department and said, `Do you know that this is one of the uses to which our low income health care cards are being put?' They are designed to provide health benefits and health assistance for people who are on low incomes. These are not necessarily people who have been on low incomes at all. For example, they can be on a break before they go to TAFE and have little or no income at all. That is a fact. It is not a rort. It is allowable under the current system. I am sure when they were introduced that that was not the intention.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, people employed in industries which have shutdowns over Christmas are also eligible. It is not a rort, but surely it is not something that should be continued. These are people who are in employment and who happen to have a lay‐off period. It might be for three weeks, but that means that over the four‐week period their income fits them into the category of making them immediately eligible for a low income health care card. Do you think that was really what was intended with this? Surely it is an opportunity to make sure that it is not misused in this way. It was designed for people who are on low incomes for a continuing period. It was not intended to be used by people who are in employment but are simply having a quiet time off for a few weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have one question that I want the minister to clarify about the current situation with the health care card. Is it the case that the department already has the power to revoke a health care card where a person's income subsequently exceeds the allowable level?
—I am advised that, while people with a health care card are obliged under the legislation to report if their income does increase, there is a very low incidence of people doing that.

—I have a follow‐up question on the matter that I raised earlier. Minister, are you saying that the only evidence you have is anecdotal evidence of you wandering around Centrelink being grabbed by people on the counter? Are you saying that you have received no reports, no surveys and nothing substantial that you have relied on?

—I have had advice from my department on this matter, as you would understand, for it to have got to the stage of being legislation. But if you deny the evidence that is given to me by the people who are working in the system who constantly see people applying for low income health care cards, what are you saying about these people? That they are making it up? Senator, is that what you are really saying?
—I am asking you what evidence you have.

—That is the particularly telling evidence that I have had. Either you think that I am lying to the Senate or you think that Centrelink staff have lied to me. When I go to these offices, I say to the officers: what things need to be done to improve this system? What things need to be done to help people access their benefits better? What things do we need to do to make sure the system has more integrity? Where are the gaps in the system? What payments do you think need to be worked on to make it easier—for instance, family payments where it is so complex for many families to estimate income? How do we get around that? I ask them questions about how the system can be improved. That is why I know and that is why they talk to me.

—Minister, how do they know? There is no necessity to report it. How do they know that these people are just on the Christmas shutdown? How do they know that they are manipulating the system? From what you have said, there is no requirement and no investigation—that is why I asked you for the evidence—that would pick up that process? It seems to me that it is like me saying, `I think Joe Bloggs is doing this,' when there is no process by which I can actually know whether he is. You may be surmising that that is the case, but that is a long way from actually knowing. Secondly, how many people in Australia who are receiving the health card does the department believe are doing what you are alleging?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —If any are doing it, then it is surely something that needs to be fixed. In addition, some of the Centrelink officers that I have visited over the last year or so have been situated very close to TAFEs. They are the officers who have drawn this to my attention in the context of the TAFE. They get a very seasonal influx of, particularly, young people coming in to apply for a low income health care card and they are not averse to saying that they need evidence. That is well known. What do you think people are doing when they are working behind the counter—that they have their eyes and ears shut?

SPEECH.PARA: If you go to a Centrelink office that is in a country town or a rural area, they know full well that such and such an industry in their area has shut down and people come in then to get low income health care cards. Do you think they do not know what is going on in their own area? Maybe because you live in Sydney and you are very metropolitan‐centred, you do not realise the knowledge that is in country areas.
Senator Neal interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Where do you live? The suburbs?

BREAK.PARA: Items 2 to 9, schedule 5, agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Newman) read a third time.
Consideration resumed from 19 November.
The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 1, page 3 (after line 4), before item 1, insert:

PARA.TAB: (2) Financial assistance to which a State is entitled under this section in relation to a grant year is granted on the condition that the Treasurer is satisfied:

TAB.TAB: (a) that amounts paid to the State will be audited by the State Auditor‐General; and
(b) that the State Auditor‐General is not subject to any direction from any person in relation to any aspect of the audit, including the planning and conduct of, and reporting on, the audit.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment is an accountability measure and again seeks to protect grants to the states by requiring that the Treasurer, before he makes payment of any general revenue assistance to the states, is satisfied that the state government has in place an independent state Auditor‐General, and for almost a century, every state has met this criterion with some ease.

But that all changed in Victoria late last week, when the lower house of the Victorian state parliament passed its legislation which will see that the Auditor-General is deprived of his auditing function and will no longer be able to conduct financial or performance audits himself. His role will be one of a contract administrator, in effect. He can appoint private auditors, prepare specifications for the audits and terminate the appointment of an auditor who does not perform but he cannot himself conduct any audits.

The Premier of Victoria claims that the Auditor-General will have complete discretion in the exercise of his functions or powers. However, the separation of the policy and services functions of the audit office comprises the real regulatory role of the Auditor-General. I suggest that, in order to be truly independent, the Auditor-General must retain that operational oversight of all the functions fulfilled by the Office of the Auditor-General.

The Kennett government further compromises the independence of the Auditor-General by insisting that the government has a role in appointing the board of management of Audit Victoria, which is the corporatised, I suppose, body that once formed the Office of the Auditor-General. The incumbent, Mr Ches Baragwanath, has maintained his very strong opposition to these changes and described the new role late least week as imposing enormous restrictions on operational independence.

The government's plans have been attacked by just about everyone this week—the Chairman of the Victorian Bar Council, the Victorian Council of Churches, the Good Shepherd Youth and Family Service and many others. The Herald‐Sun ran a telephone poll on 30 October and it demonstrated that 94.5 per cent of respondents supported the continuing independence of the Auditor-General. The state council of the Liberal Party also voted overwhelmingly in support of this objective, and about 50,000 Victorians in all have so far signed petitions and written to Mr Kennett to oppose this policy.

I strongly commend this amendment to the committee in order that we can ensure that Victoria cannot change the mandate of its Auditor-General without risking its federal grants. I remind the committee that this amendment is constitutionally valid because the states have no right to financial assistance per se.

I note that the opposition did not support us on this amendment back in September, when the last states grants bill came through the Senate, but I urge them to reconsider this position. The situation has become much more pressing now that the legislation has moved through the lower house and progressed to the upper house. So I strongly urge the ALP to think very carefully about that.
I would like to quote a couple of ALP members of the Victorian state parliament. The opposition leader, John Brumby, said:
The Opposition regards it as the greatest threat to the rights of Victorians and to democracy that this parliament has witnessed in its more than 140-year history.

The Opposition regards the proposed legislation as corrupt and as being introduced by a government which is corrupt. It is rotten legislation; it is tainted legislation; it is dishonest legislation; it is morally indefensible legislation.
The deputy opposition leader, Mr John Thwaites, said:

If the legislation proceeds, in future years backbenchers, ministers and public servants will end up being subject to criminal action because the climate of corruption that will be created will lead to a situation in which government members will be the losers.
So it is very clear that there is widespread opposition to this provision and that there are dangers inherent in its passing in relation to Commonwealth funds which flow through to the states.

No doubt the Mitcham by-election will be used by the ALP as an opportunity to point out how opposed they are to these changes. I want to say to the ALP that support for this amendment will send a very clear message to the electorate in Mitcham about how serious the ALP are about supporting their position on the independence of the Auditor-General and therefore the accountability of governments. Clearly, support for this amendment would give support to their state colleagues, who have been so very outspoken on this issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleague Senator Allison. The Australian Democrats feel very strongly indeed about this issue. As she has clearly outlined, we have consulted at length with the association—if that is the proper term—of the Auditors-General at large in Australia and they, as with many people in Victoria, feel alarmed by the changes that Premier Kennett has wrought in that state.

SPEECH.PARA: We recall, as Senator Allison just has, that we moved this amendment to a previous states grants bill. I recall clearly Senator Carr and Senator Conroy from Victoria appearing in that debate and making very impassioned speeches against the perfidy of Premier Kennett and his policies. Then the ALP voted down, not to our surprise, this amendment which would have required accountability in terms of the Auditor-General and how Commonwealth moneys are dealt with in Victoria. At that time the Labor Party said to us that that was not the appropriate forum, that the preferred package to deal with this was the Auditor-General's package. So we brought that amendment to the Auditor-General's package and we were not surprised that the Labor Party voted it down.

We think now is judgment day. Either the Labor Party are going to be accused of posturing and of not being capable of executing proper accountability measures which are constitutional and which will protect the Commonwealth or they are going to support us in this measure. If the ALP have an alternative we would certainly gladly consider it, but we feel that the most important accountability mechanism that is available to any parliament in Australia which protects the public purse as far as that is possible is the Auditor-General. It is a fundamental matter which is of critical importance to all parties and all sides of the parliament, and it is only in one state of Australia that this onslaught has been conducted against an Auditor-General. We think it is appropriate for all parties to be supportive of the intention of Senator Allison's amendment, which simply says:
Financial assistance to which a State is entitled under this section in relation to a grant year is granted on the condition that the Treasurer is satisfied:
(a) that amounts paid to the State will be audited by the State Auditor-General; and
(b) that the State Auditor-General is not subject to any direction from any person in relation to any aspect of the audit, including the planning and conduct of, and reporting on, the audit.

All that says is that the amounts paid by the Commonwealth to a state will be audited and that the auditor will be independent. I would expect that sentiment as well as the amendment to be fully supported by every party and every Independent in this place. I strongly support Senator Allison's amendment and I hope that you will find it in your hearts to be accountable and to strongly support it, too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the opposition, might I make a few points to the chamber concerning this matter. I do appreciate the deep concern there is in Victoria about the fate of the Auditor-General. There is a by-election being fought in Mitcham on 13 December. As I understand it, the people of Mitcham will express very grave concerns about the way in which the Auditor-General has been treated in that state. On numerous occasions we have expressed the opposition's view about the treatment of the people of Victoria by the government of Victoria with regard to basic issues of public accountability and democratic decision making. Perhaps at a later point in this discussion I will need to go through those in some detail just to be clear so that those following this matter do understand the depth of deep concern that the opposition has about the way in which the government of Victoria is pillaging that state.

SPEECH.PARA: We also, however, are concerned to make sure that there is a proper discussion of the legislation that is actually before the parliament. As I understand it, this is the States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 , which seeks to give assistance and a response to the states and territories to alter their share of revenue replacement of payments for tobacco under the safety net arrangements that came about as a result of the High Court decision on various tobacco tariffs. This is a measure which seeks to provide assistance to the states for a whole range of services. The consequence of denying those services also needs to be weighed up pretty carefully and to be considered quite carefully.
I draw the committee's attention to the amendment which the opposition will move to the motion that the report of the committee be adopted. The amendment seeks to add the following words:
`and that the following matter be referred to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit for inquiry and report by 30 June 1998:

PARA.TAB: Conditions which may appropriately be attached to:
(i) general purpose payments to States; and
including conditions relating to the role of State Auditors-General, with particular reference to recent developments concerning the Victorian Auditor-General".

SPEECH.PARA: To propose that we should support the Democrats' amendment on the basis that we are concerned about the situation in Victoria is in itself a fairly superficial argument. What we would like to put to the committee is that this is not necessarily the most appropriate means of expressing that concern. I do not think there can be any doubt about the general view as to what is happening in Victoria and how inappropriate it is that the Kennett government should seek to muzzle the Auditor-General. But, equally, I do not think it is appropriate that the Senate be used as part of the leadership battles of the Democrats. It is fair enough that both the candidates are here today, and I trust that they are enjoying the full support of the Democrats in their campaign.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman. This amendment was first moved in September 1997 under the states grants bill at that time. At that time Senator Kernot was still a member of the Democrats.
—Senator Murray, what is your point of order?
—My point of order is relevance. It is the usual Victorian nonsense—
—There is no point of order.

—Thank you very much, Mr Temporary Chairman. The issue of the appropriateness of this measure is at the core of the contribution I am making. The political significance of it cannot be lost, however, in terms of the present timing of the disputes within the Democrats themselves. We do understand. Senator Allison has sent letters around concerning my behaviour on this matter. She has drawn attention to my voting record on this matter in Victoria, which she is fully entitled to do. Equally, I am entitled to point out her particular interest in this matter at this particular time. It is only appropriate that the Senate is acquainted with all of the facts in this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: It also has to be understood, Senator Allison, that your deep concern about the Auditor-General is widely shared within the Victorian political community, except within the Liberal Party itself. This is a question the government has to address: to what extent is it prepared to stand up to what is happening in Victoria and to defend appropriate levels of integrity and probity in public affairs in this country, particularly when it concerns Commonwealth moneys?

I just do not believe that this is the most effective way in which this matter can be pursued. The Labor Party proposes that this issue is more appropriately dealt with through reference to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts for inquiry. This is in fact the parliamentary committee specifically charged with this responsibility. It has already undertaken inquiries in a range of related matters and only recently has been charged to increase its level of review and activity in the issue of public accounts auditing. It is a responsible committee which ought to undertake an inquiry of this particular type. It has recently undertaken inquiries into the issue of the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill 1996 . It has undertaken inquiries into the Commonwealth Auditor-General's packages. It is therefore suitably qualified and is the appropriate body to investigate the issues concerned.

What the Democrats are proposing is that we should follow the same argument that they have presented to the parliament on a number of occasions, which the opposition has consistently opposed. Let me put it to you that the opposition is very concerned about the attacks on the Auditor-General in Victoria and the activities of the Victorian government when it comes to the issues of public financing.

BREAK.PARA: We respect and totally support the need for an independent and properly resourced Auditor-General's office. However, we cannot see that the federal parliament should be using this particular bill to seek to pursue that political agenda. What we believe is that the issue should be separate from the general matters being discussed in this particular bill.

Senator Sherry, on previous occasions, has stated the position on behalf of the opposition whereby we have sought to direct the Democrats to the more appropriate courses of action that are available to them. We say that the relevant committees of the parliament are the more effective way of securing agreement around this general proposition.

I would suggest to you that, in the case of Victoria, the upcoming by-election in Mitcham is another opportunity for the people of Victoria to express their clear intentions and to support the Labor Party's candidate Mr Tony Robinson in that by-election. It will probably be the most effective of all means of expressing disappointment and displeasure at the actions of the Kennett government and its high-handed treatment of the public sector in that state.

It is quite clear that the Auditor-General has exposed deep‐seated corruption within the state of Victoria. He has quite clearly exposed the actions of the Victorian government in regard to the ambulance contracts. He has exposed the deep‐seated corruption in the education in that state and the casino licences. He has equally been able to highlight just how inadequate and systematic the corruption is in that state.

However, that is not to say that this parliament ought to use the States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 , which is aimed at providing revenue sharing in relation to the payment of tobacco excises, as the vehicle to express the displeasure of this parliament at what is quite clearly the blatant abuse of political process in the state of Victoria.
Progress reported.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Ian Campbell) agreed to:
That consideration of government documents not be proceeded with today.
Consideration resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I just need to make a couple of points about my colleague Senator Carr's remarks. We had this debate back in September when the ALP said, in their view, that the States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 was not an appropriate bill. So we then moved on to the next bill, which was said to be more appropriate—that was the Commonwealth Auditor-General's bill. That turned out not to be appropriate either. We put up some terms of reference for inquiry, as suggested by the ALP. That also was not appropriate. I do note that Senator Carr has now put together some terms of reference for an inquiry. I want to indicate that the Australian Democrats will be supporting this. We will do whatever we can to see that there is some action taken in this respect.

SPEECH.PARA: But I also need to put on the record that one of the reasons why our terms of reference were not supported by the ALP was that there had not been enough prior warning—that they had not been circulated and there was not a chance to talk about them. That is what has happened tonight with Senator Carr's amendment. That is not to say that we will oppose it. As I have already indicated, we will support this. It is interesting to note that when the Democrats do it, it is not acceptable, but when the opposition does it is okay.

Senator Carr has quite rightly given us a list of the matters which the Auditor-General has raised about the current Kennett government. But we know that Mr Baragwanath was just as unpopular with the former Labor government. He uncovered a number of serious problems with the administration of the Labor government. In fact, it is probably fairly well acknowledged that it was the undoing of the Cain and Kirner governments at the time. Having said that, I think this is probably the end of the debate, from our point of view, on this amendment. I commend it to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will not support either of the amendments. The JCPA reference which Senator Carr will propose as an amendment on behalf of the opposition has not been, as I understand it—and I have sought to speak to coalition members of that committee to see whether it has been discussed with them—discussed with our members of the committee or in our party room or anywhere else. It seems to have emerged in the last few minutes, and it is entirely Senator Carr's right to do that.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition will oppose it on the same grounds that we oppose Senator Allison's motion. We are not generally opposed to having matters investigated by parliamentary committees. We think it is a sensible thing to do. However, we normally like these matters to be taken to our party room to be discussed with colleagues. We are happy to progress it in that way. But, clearly, Senator Carr wants this matter brought to a vote tonight. I do understand the politics of both the Democrats and Victoria to a certain extent and recognise that there is a game being played here. We are not even really part of the game.

TALK.START.PARA: —There's no game. This was done in September; come on now.

—Quite seriously, as a matter of process I think most people recognise that if you are trying to send a reference to a committee you would normally allow other parties the right to take it to their party room and discuss it with their colleagues. I know the Democrats generally seek to have matters like this discussed in their party room before they form a position. The position I am placed in on behalf of the government is to make a decision on the run about whether this matter goes to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. I certainly will not support the amendment, purely because of the lack of notice at this stage in relation to that.

—I have a question to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, Senator Campbell, and I would appreciate a short answer because it is a short question. Do you and the coalition government support the proposition that state finances provided by the Commonwealth should be audited by an independent auditor‐general?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think that is germane to the bill before the chamber. We have made it quite clear that we will be voting against an amendment. We believe that when the Commonwealth gives a grant to a state it is up to the state government to determine those matters and that the financial management of a state and those processes are for the state. I think I made that quite clear in the debate on this bill or it might have been on the Charter of Budget Honesty or some other bill that I have done recently. I made that quite clear then, and that is the position of the Commonwealth in relation to this matter.

PARA.TAB: That the amendment (Senator Allison's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Ian Campbell) proposed:
That the report from the committee be adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add "and that the following matter be referred to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit for inquiry and report by 30 June 1998:

PARA.TAB: Conditions which may appropriately be attached to:
(a) general purpose payments to States; and
including conditions relating to the role of State Auditors-General, with particular reference to recent developments concerning the Victorian Auditor-General".

SPEECH.PARA: I briefly draw to the Senate's attention the very deep concerns that have been expressed right across the political spectrum about the way in which the Auditor-General in the state of Victoria has actually been treated. We have seen a litany of examples whereby there has been a gross abuse of due process and probity in relation to the expenditure of public moneys in the state of Victoria. The expenditure of Commonwealth moneys in the state of Victoria is a matter of great concern to the Commonwealth parliament. As a consequence, it requires the Commonwealth parliament to come up with the most effective and appropriate means by which these matters can be investigated to ensure that Commonwealth moneys are not being used in a manner which supports arrangements which quite clearly have been subject to considerable public challenge.

We have seen a list of issues ranging from education, health, gambling and media contracts in a whole range of areas. The government of Victoria seems quite prepared to abandon any pretence of public accountability. However, we cannot willy-nilly say that we are going to cut off money to any particular state in terms of our constitutional obligations. We have an obligation to see that the appropriate committees of this parliament are used to make proper inquiries into what is actually occurring in the state of Victoria. I urge senators to support this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to repeat the fact that the Democrats will be supporting this amendment. We look forward very much to an inquiry of this nature. We think it will go a long way to improving accountability across the board—not just across the board for Victoria; this could be a way in which we set a pattern or a model for the future. I think it would be a very worthy inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Days and Hours of Meeting and Routine of Business

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Further to a short debate that was done by leave earlier today, there have been discussions between the government and the opposition.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Faulkner, could I invite your colleagues to keep their conversation down to a dull roar so I can hear you a little better?
—It is the excitement, Madam Acting Deputy President. There are two very great speeches—the Gettysburg address and this one—and I am sure that they would acknowledge that.

The government's proposed scheduling of the migration agents package and Legislative Instruments Bill message for 3.30 p.m. next Tuesday is understood, as are the hours of meeting on Friday this week being 9.30 a.m. to 4.25 p.m. with the adjournment being moved at 3.45 p.m.
