SPEECH.SPEAKER: Synon, Sen Karen

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, 25 November 1997, marked the 20th anniversary of the judgment in the landmark case of Clark v. University of Melbourne & Others. In that case, His Honour Justice Kaye ruled that the University of Melbourne did not have the legal power to levy a compulsory union fee on students. He went on to rule as illegal and improper a large number of payments made by the Students Representative Council and its national affiliated body, the Australian Union of Students. The impact of that decision sent shock waves throughout every extreme left‐wing group on every university campus in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: So who is this Robert Clark, who had taken on and defeated the full might of the most privileged university in Australia and the financial resources of the bloated Australian Union of Students with a multimillion dollar budget? Robert Clark was a gifted student, winning a scholarship to University High School before going on to enter the combined law‐commerce course at Melbourne University. Robert was the son of immigrant working‐class parents from St Albans, in the heartland of Melbourne's western suburbs. He was a person who had come to his strong, personally held belief in liberalism and freedom by discussion, debate and deliberation. He joined the local campus Liberal club in 1975, when he started at university.

In 1976 Robert was elected, along with two other members of the local Liberal group, to a position on the executive of the Students Representative Council and took office as honorary treasurer on 1 December 1976. With one other moderate student generally supporting the students against the more esoteric views of the four extremists, the executive that year was deadlocked at four votes all. The significance of this electoral victory cannot be overemphasised. Back in 1976 the campus mood was venomous towards Liberal students. The activism of the late 1960s over the Vietnam War and the drug crazed peace movement had been rekindled by the justifiable sacking of the Whitlam government in 1975. Yet Robert Clark and his associates had managed to take 50 per cent of the positions.

For student politics, in many ways 1977 was a watershed year. Nationally, a coalition of centre‐unity ALP, Jewish, Christian and Liberal students were clamouring for a more representative and responsible national student body. Meanwhile the communists, Trotskyists and Maoists, who ran the Australian Union of Students, were resisting moves to directly elect their office‐bearers and remove a notorious electoral gerrymander and vote rigging. In a scene reminiscent of Nero's feast, they fiddled the books and sent compulsorily collected student fees to extremist causes they supported, such as the Bangsu Moro Liberation Front and the Panak People's Independence Movement, and passed resolution after resolution of the most vitriolic condemnations of Western society.

BREAK.PARA: Perhaps the most memorable resolution was one supporting terrorism and hijacking as a legitimate political tactic in the struggle for a people's state—memorable not just for its inane content but also because at that time the Australian Union of Students owned the largest student travel company in the world. I suppose they took it as a badge of honour that they were the only travel proprietors to support hijacking of their own planes.

It is no wonder a person as principled and fair‐minded as Robert Clark found it increasingly difficult to stomach these abuses. When he raised the issue of the legality of payments being made at the student executive and submitted unequivocal legal advice that supported his position, he was censured. Ultimately, it left only one course of action: litigation.

In most places, taking legal action is a democratic right. However, in the frenzied environment of the Australian Union of Students, dominated by the opponents of Western style democracy, it was a very risky proposition. Already that year two students, Michael Danby from Melbourne University and Peter Costello from Monash University, had been physically assaulted and, in one case, hospitalised. You might think it strange that a leading member of the ALP like Michael Danby, whom I understand to be a frontrunner for Melbourne Ports preselection, was linked up with Peter Costello, an evangelical Christian and Liberal supporter. But that gives you an idea of the unrepresentative nature of the AUS leadership.

The university had its lawyers, the SRC had its lawyers and the AUS had its lawyers all pitted against a student, Robert Clark, and his meagre legal team. The final result, however, represented nearly a complete vindication of the position argued by Robert Clark. For the first time in living memory, students on enrolment had a choice as to whether they would pay student fees. Despite the university bludgeoning students with the threat of legislation to make the fee compulsory and backdate the payment for the full year, students voted with their dollars. About half did not pay, even though it meant they were denied student services until they did.

Then, in one of the most perfidious and disgraceful moves ever by a Liberal government, Alan Hunt, the then minister for education, introduced legislation to make the fee compulsory again, but introduced a provision to make membership of student unions voluntary. In effect, you had to pay, but you could choose whether you got any benefit from paying. All those students who had not paid and had not used the services for the intervening period were forced to cop the full year's fee.

I am embarrassed that this action was taken by a Liberal government. Alan Hunt infringed the freedom of association principles enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. What is the situation 20 years later? Even though we have coalition governments in five states, two territories and federally, not much has changed. The vice‐chancellors of Australia still act as the shop stewards of the radical Left student unions in almost every state.

Not even the allegedly hairy‐chested government of Joh Bjelke‐Petersen in Queensland moved to make student union fees voluntary. Sir Joh must have enjoyed the vitriolic abuse hurled at him so much that, `Golly, never you mind', it was okay to conscript National Party students and Liberal Party students into paying for the rotten eggs thrown at him.

The Greiner and Fahey Liberal governments did nothing in New South Wales, and I do not see Premier Carr doing anything either. In South Australia, the Liberal government is sitting on its hands. In Tasmania, the governing council of Tasmania University has spooked the government into inaction by amending some of its own statutes to allow only a limited power of conscientious objection.

Most regrettably, in my home state of Victoria the normally `can do' government of Jeff Kennett has failed to deliver on its 1992 election promise to make student union fees voluntary. In fact Haddon Storey, in a repetition of the deceit and treachery of Alan Hunt, introduced a totally ineffectual piece of legislation that has explicitly made the fee compulsory, even though it sets some limit on how the fee can be spent. I can say, without any fear of contradiction, that thousands of Liberal students rejoiced that Haddon Storey chose to retire at the 1996 election.

Only in Western Australia—your state, Madam Acting Deputy President Knowles—is there any half‐decent legislation. It asserts that membership of and payments to student associations are entirely voluntary.

Federally, the Australian Democrats have totally ignored the views of their founder, Don Chipp, who is a passionate supporter of voluntary student unionism. They have joined with the ALP. In effect, as my colleague Senator Abetz has stated on more than one occasion, the ALP has rewarded with extra federal funding the least popular and least representative organisations. The more you fail to attract members, the more money you get. Some $14,578,974 was paid by federal taxpayers in 1995‐96 to prop up these campus relics of the Stalinist era.

Fortunately, following the election of the Howard government in March 1996, my Senate colleague Amanda Vanstone stopped the abuse and refused to approve any more grants. The new Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, the Hon. David Kemp, has told me that the federal government is considering ways of implementing Liberal Party policy that supports voluntary student unionism.This government has a clear mandate to introduce voluntary student unionism and to abolish the closed shop on campus. I call on the government of which I am proud to be a member to celebrate the 21st anniversary of the Clark judgment next year by ensuring that this fundamental democratic right of voluntary membership and payment of fees to student unions becomes a reality.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I—

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chris Evans interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you trying to interfere with my right of free speech?
—Me?
—No, Senator Chris Evans just commented that I have become a real problem since I went off the front bench.

SPEECH.PARA: Madam Acting Deputy President, I do think it is appropriate, since the whip has raised the question of free speech, that I remind the Senate of the recent admonition made by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to church leaders in the Wik debate. Prime Minister Howard, as honourable senators may recall, told church leaders that the right to free speech brought with it the obligation to speak in an informed, objective and constructive manner. He also referred to the parallel right of others in the community to `freely criticise the views of church figures, if they do not accord with the facts or display undue bias'.

I have no argument with the conditions the Prime Minister has put on church leaders in terms of the mutual obligations that go along with free speech, but I cannot help comparing these with the totally unconditional support the Prime Minister initially gave to the appalling remarks made by the honourable member for Oxley, Pauline—the voice from the grave—Hanson.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now on video.

—Yes, in a store near you, Senator Schacht. I have never forgotten—and I have reminded the Senate of it on a number of occasions—the Prime Minister's initial reaction to the member for Oxley's maiden speech, spread all over the front pages of Australian newspapers. The Prime Minister unconditionally defended the right of the honourable member for Oxley to say whatever she liked. He went on to say, in that coded language we have just heard him revive again in respect of Mr Warren Entsch, the member for Leichhardt, that he understood that the concerns that the member for Oxley was raising were felt by many people in mainstream Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: It was the Prime Minister unblushingly trying to have two bob each way, treating the electorate as mugs and hoping no‐one would notice. I have news for the Prime Minister, and it is all bad. They did notice, out there.

BREAK.PARA: After that appalling performance—that coded message that told us he really was supporting what the honourable member for Oxley said, while at the same time condemning it—I was dismayed to see a repeat performance in the House of Representatives in respect of the call to boycott churches by the honourable member for Leichhardt. The Prime Minister said he understood Mr Entsch's frustration with church leaders. He used precisely the same language he used in respect of Pauline Hanson.

As I said, the Prime Minister gave the parallel right to others to criticise the views of church leaders, and I have risen in the debate on the adjournment tonight to exercise my parallel right, graciously granted to me by the Prime Minister, to take issue with a contemptible public statement from the National Party member for Capricornia, Mr Marek. The statement was published on the front page of yesterday's edition of the Morning Bulletin in Rockhampton.

Mr Marek is worried about any possible compensation bill arising out of the Howard government's Native Title Amendment Bill. Any prospective compensation, he told the newspaper, could have been far less if settlement was reached in Australia's early history. He went on to say:
Imagine if we'd done this years ago. All we would have to have given them—
`them', I stress—
is $20 and a box of Jatz.

That is an appalling and contemptible statement, particularly from a member of parliament who has a great many Aboriginal Australians living in his electorate. I knew that much. But I was more dismayed when I learnt today that up until last month the member for Capricornia was also a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. He is also a delegate to the National Party's central council.

I find this comment totally offensive. On any measure, it is a racist statement—not a word that I throw around with gay abandon, as honourable senators and others know. It should be repudiated immediately by the leadership of the National Party. I am disappointed that the Leader or the Deputy Leader of the National Party have not done so today, especially given the fact that they used question time in the other place today to answer a number of dorothy dixers on the Wik legislation. The fact that they did not do so clearly suggests that they have no problem with this type of grossly offensive statement. If that is the case, I should remind the Senate of what the Leader of the National Party and currently our Acting Prime Minister, Mr Fischer, had to say on the subject of racism in his party during the last election campaign. You may recall that the subject became an issue during the campaign following the comment by the member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) about `slanty eyed ideologues and femonazis'.

Mr Fischer appeared on ABC's Lateline show on 14 February 1996, on the same day Mr Katter made that comment. He said that he was very angry about the comment, had taken immediate action under the proceedings of the National Party and had cited the matter to the Queensland state president of the National Party, David Russell QC. This had resulted in apology from the member for Kennedy. Mr Fischer went on to say that in his six years as Leader of the National Party he had worked hard to ensure `there is no racist element in the National Party'. Later he said, `The National Party will not endorse racists as their candidates.'
I am afraid, Deputy Prime Minister or Acting Prime Minister, that you have actually got one sitting behind you on your back bench in the House of Representatives, and not one word of public rebuke—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I take a point of order. It is entirely unparliamentary to accuse a member of this chamber or the other place of being a racist. I ask that it be withdrawn.
—Senator Collins, I would ask you to withdraw that reference to being a racist.

—I withdraw, but I am disappointed that Senator O'Chee felt it necessary to attempt to defend a remark this offensive. The Deputy Prime Minister said, `The National Party will not endorse racists as their candidates.' One might question the public silence on this matter also of the Deputy Leader of the National Party, Mr Anderson. How does he square the reported remark of Mr Marek with his statement to this parliament earlier in May this year that we must increase tolerance in this country? At the very least I think we could expect the Leader of the National Party to take the same action in regard to these appalling statements in the last 24 hours by Mr Marek, totally denigrating Aboriginal Australians, in the same way as he did with Mr Katter.

BREAK.PARA: On the question of free speech, I want to conclude tonight by reminding the Senate of the extraordinary direct attack made on the Governor-General last week by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron). The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, in an extraordinary attack on the Governor-General, told him to back off making any statements about Aboriginal affairs in Australia and said basically that he was stretching the envelope.

I have noted carefully all of the statements made by the Governor-General since he was appointed to that position. I am aware of the statements the Governor-General has made about the need to further and advance the reconciliation process in Australia, the need to improve the appalling health situation of Aboriginal Australians, the right of Australians to free speech, the right of church leaders to comment on matters other than helping us all to get into the bosom of Abraham at the end of our lives—not an unreasonable position when you consider that the mainstream churches in this country carry the lion's share of the burden of social welfare in Australia and think they might have a comment about it.

I understood that every single one of these things was high policy of the government and, with few exceptions, high policy of this parliament. I cannot see a single statement ever made by the Governor-General that contradicts the stated policy of the government, unless of course there is an unstated policy of the government.

What I am asking, with respect, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to do is to nominate a single statement by the Governor-General of Australia which contradicts the stated policy of his government or that he disagrees with. If he cannot do that, perhaps he should consider giving the Governor-General a call and saying he is sorry—although if he did that, that would conflict with the policy of his government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a matter which I have raised a number of times already in this place but which I also took to the Australian Local Government Association's national assembly this morning. It is the matter of electromagnetic fields generated by power and telecommunications industries, our current standards and the relationship between those fields, the proliferation of breast cancer, childhood leukaemia and brain tumours, greenhouse gas emissions and sick buildings. I suggested to the Local Government Association that there are relatively simple solutions to some of these health and environmental problems. They are: unground cabling, easements between power and radio transmission and human habitat and the development of standards which take account of the risks.

SPEECH.PARA: There is enough evidence to show us that the Australian human exposure standards, that is AS 2771.2, do not actually protect us from cancer. I find it extraordinary that governments have been prepared to accept the increasing incidence of cancer without insisting on a better understanding of what is leading to this increase.

We have tended to buy the line from the industry that all is well, and the propaganda from vested interests has been given the same or more weight than independent research. The public at large has become quite complacent in the knowledge that early detection and better treatment of cancer is reducing early mortality rates for most patients. But we are not asking why it is that more people are getting cancer or what might be the cause.

The electrical power standard in Australia is 1,000 milligauss, but cancers are known to occur with exposures in the two milligauss to four milligauss range. Exposure to 10,000 milligauss is acceptable for up to two hours, according to our standard. Fortunately, nobody ever faces such levels. The standard for radio frequencies is 200 microwatts, but cancers are evident at 0.02 microwatts to eight microwatts. In other words, our standards are many times higher than we know to be safe. It is not just cancer that we need to worry about. Neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's and Lou Gehrig's disease are also linked to exposure to magnetic fields.

Our regulations are set by the National Health and Medical Research Council, which adopted those of the International Radiation Protection Agency. It is an entirely voluntary exposure standard with no enforcement or verification program either at state or federal levels. I have said before that the evidence worldwide is mounting, and the very considerable library of material in my office, mostly from overseas, leaves me in no doubt about the risks.

At the same time, given the growth in electromagnetic generating technology over recent decades, we have a very dismal record, both here and overseas, in conducting independent research into the subject. The federal government agreed a year ago to allocate $4.5 million to a 4½ year program of research, but so far the only money which has been spent has been on public relations damage control. Of course, this happened quite early in that period.

Research is very costly. Telstra, for instance, spent more than $500,000 on just one study on the effects of mobile phone emissions on mice. They were surprised to find that the rates of lymphoma were twice as high in the exposed group. When it finally emerged, the study was pretty well buried, and the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) made jokes about the inadvisability of mice using mobile phones. That was when I asked him what the implications of this study were for health and safety.

It is time the government got out of the pockets of the industry and got tough on electrical and telecommunications utilities. It is now time to introduce regulations which would protect public health.

Some local governments have already given up on state and federal governments and have begun to set their own standards, developing much better regulatory and planning regimes. Moreland in Victoria, Pine Rivers shire in Queensland and Sutherland shire in New South Wales are some examples. They are setting standards of two milligauss for electrical power and two microwatts for radiofrequencies. Of course, power utilities have operated in a virtual vacuum of regulation, and we also know that that was the case in telecommunications up until quite recently too.

In Sweden, the government acts on the presumption that exposure to power frequency electromagnetic fields is a cancer risk, and its prudent avoidance policy means that no new children's facilities are to be built in areas where ambient fields exceed two milligauss to three milligauss. In New Zealand, local government introduced radiation exposure limits in its Resources Management Act. Electromagnetic radiation is designated as a contaminant in New Zealand because it changes, or is likely to change, the physical, chemical or biological nature of the receiving environment. As a contaminant, it is controlled and restricted by regional councils.

For the past 18 years evidence has been mounting about the occupational and childhood cancer risks associated with electrical magnetic fields. A rational approach to this would be to change the way that we plan and locate human habitat in relation to electrical power. The Democrats would like to see a national urban undergrounding plan developed over an agreed period of time, and we think that the utilities should be contributing at least 80 per cent of the cost of that undergrounding. In other words, we would adopt the polluter pays principle.

After some pressure, the federal government set up a national working party on undergrounding, which seems to have gone underground, as far as I can see. The question that needs to be asked is whether electromagnetic radiation is on their agenda. As far as I understand it, it is not. As long as it is not there, then polluters will evade paying their dues.

The Western Australian government together with the WA local government association has an undergrounding strategy. In Western Australia the storm damage is another reason for a more robust electrical distribution system. Of course, other states in the east may well face similar conditions as we experience more cyclonic and changing weather patterns.

Magnetic fields are a problem for houses located near corners where there are pole transformers and where there are high and low voltage convergers. But where is this in our standards? Our standards do not deal with the health risks for librarians, for instance, yet code scanners in libraries create very hazardous electromagnetic fields. This is something that the unions are aware of, but it is not something that is taken care of by our own standards.

In this country we have a very poor record on verifying compliance, even with our very loose standards. Last year I wrote to mobile phone carriers and phone manufacturers asking for their emission levels for the phones that they sell. They said that they could not answer my question. They did not carry out any tests and all they knew was that their phones complied with Australian standards. They said that it was up to Austel to monitor compliance. Austel, it turned out, had no testing capacity and accepted the assurances of compliance too.

I understand that for the first time a low emission mobile phone has now been developed and is being promoted in Europe. For a defensive and an evasive industry which denies that there might even be a problem, this is a very important breakthrough. One might talk about it in terms of breaking ranks.

If Australia is to be taken seriously as a clever country, gearing up for high-tech markets, it must recognise that research into technology which reduces electromagnetic emissions is the way of the future. What do we know in this country about shielding alloys? This is a manufacturing industry with huge potential for new skills and new jobs. But first and foremost we need simple and transparent standards. We need to be confident of compliance and we need to be given informed choices so that, at the very least, consumers can make judgments for themselves about prudent avoidance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran, Sen Julian

TALK.START.PARA: —Few would argue that one of the major reforms this government has introduced is in the area of industrial relations: namely, the Workplace Relations Bill. The thrust of the government's workplace relations legislation has been to free up the old rigidities of the workplace in order to link wage negotiations directly with productivity improvement and to give employers and employees the primary responsibility for determining matters affecting their relationship.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very clear break from the past, when the emphasis was on centralised determination of wages and conditions through awards determined by the Industrial Relations Commission. However, down on the waterfront, reform is non-existent, to the detriment of the rest of Australia. This is detrimental not only for Australian exporters and importers but also for so many Australians that seek genuine and secure employment.

The inefficiencies and outright rorting occurring on our waterfront are such that the flow‐on effect is found in increased business costs which affect the ability to employ. Product costs eat into the family household budget, and waterfront inefficiencies and strike action deter new investment in this country. The level of industrial action on the waterfront is unacceptably high. In 1996 there were 1,250 working days lost per 1,000 employees compared with an all industries average of 131 per 1,000. That is a ratio of 10 to one. Australia, with two per cent of the world's shipping trade, has the highest level of industrial unrest with 23 per cent of days lost.

While all sectors are affected by Australia's disgraceful waterfront, I particularly single out the farm sector—a major export industry. Given the major markets to which we export and the fact that these markets require on‐the‐spot delivery dates, every time the Marine Union strikes, our reliability as a supplier is diminished and frequently markets have been lost. It is true to say that the flow‐on effect goes right down to the farm gate, where asset values of the farm itself are affected. It was found with the improvement of ports in New Zealand over the past decade it could be calculated that the asset values of properties in New Zealand rose.

In a competitive international market, reliability is everything. I want to refer to one particular industry in the rural sector, the wool industry. This industry was responsible for $3.2 billion in export earnings in 1995-96, and even a marginal improvement in waterfront performance promises substantial returns. Wool represents the largest containerised export from Australia, with about 40,000 containers of wool exported per annum.

Wool exporting is a very complex operation. The coordination involved is further highlighted by the typical requirement for wool to be shipped from the export port within two weeks of purchase. Many consignments include multiple containers loaded at more than one port. They face financial penalties if the wool misses the ship, as they are not paid until all of the consignment is delivered to overseas mills.

Exporters experience frustration when, after successfully organising their own part of the logistical task, they are unable to have their consignments delivered on time to overseas mills because of delays and inflexibilities on the Australian waterfront. Difficulties occur at two stages at the port terminals. Firstly, at some terminals wool exporters experience difficulty in obtaining time slots for trucks delivering containers to the terminals. The second type of difficulty concerns the reliability of ship schedules.

The inefficiencies on the waterfront are well documented. In fact, they are folklore. One notable benchmark is the crane rates per hour, which is a vital statistic given the obvious flow‐on effects to ship turnaround times, truck delivery times and stevedoring charges. The added costs are obvious. Let us consider the flow-on effects.

In September 1997, the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics' publication Waterline reports that the five-port average is 18.3 containers per hour. On the basis of the available information, the government considers that a reasonable achievable initial target and the basis for continuing improvement in Australia is the five-port average crane rate of 25 containers per hour, not the existing 18.3. Such an improvement could be expected to reduce typical ship turnaround times by the order of one day. The flow-on effects are obvious.

Industry sources suggest that delays in Australian ports accounted for an average of 1.5 days delay per voyage. The Waterline article indicates that there were average delays of approximately three hours per ship visit at overseas ports in 1995 and 1996. Using those figures, the three‐hour delay estimate is the best practice.

An achievement of best practice in Australia would result in a reduction of port delays of one day per voyage. This would flow on to a reduction in voyage times and ship tie‐up times which is estimated at $16,000 per day. This one‐day saving equivalent then would also flow on to stevedoring charges, and it is estimated that a saving of about 10 per cent would be achieved under the 25 containers per hour benchmark.

A 10 per cent reduction in stevedoring charges would amount to about $20 per container. This modest reduction in stevedoring charges would result in savings to the industry of $42 million per year. This then would have a flow-on effect to the road transport charges, or truck slot times, with the delivery of containers, where truck turnaround times have recently averaged 1.5 hours compared with the agreed achievable target of 30 minutes; so truck times would fall from 1.5 hours to 30 minutes. This has been estimated as a saving of around $14 million per year at the Sydney port alone.

The core of the problem, needless to say, is the Maritime Workers Union. It has taken on the attitude of invincibility. It is no exaggeration to say that the MUA, backed by the ACTU, run the ports. The two stevedoring companies are hardly in control of operations. Consequently, their profits are underperforming, if not in the negative.

BREAK.PARA: The extraordinary rorts that occur on the wharves were best highlighted in a paper produced by the minister in charge of the waterfront, Peter Reith, focusing on what was considered to be one of the better ports, Cairns, and the payments received by members of the Waterside Workers Union. For example, on a Sunday, it was recorded in Peter Reith's paper that the average hours actually worked were only 4.5. It was also recorded that some of the employees regularly go home two hours before the end of the shift but still receive the same pay; they are paid for up to 22.05 hours on a Sunday.

Last year the average grade 3 waterside worker in the same port—that is, Cairns—earned nearly $84,000, and spent almost one day in five at home on full pay. Waterside workers are on a 35‐hour week, and have been for many years, but the effective rate is really 31 hours. The total of days available to work the 6.25 hours in a day is 175.5 in a year. The number of days absent on full pay is 85.5, or 17.1 weeks. So Peter Reith's paper goes on, naming every rort from being paid during tea and meal breaks to walking time, dust time, and so on. As I said in my opening remarks, the matter of the waterfront is folklore.

I am not convinced that the existing stevedores can be relied upon to bring about change, even for their own good. The answer lies more in there being new entrants into the industry, new ports and privatisation of ports, and new unions in competition with the old, or workplace reforms. While the task is great, it is necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Synon tonight made a very nasty and vicious attack on a very honourable Victorian Liberal by the name of Mr Alan Hunt. Alan Hunt has been a member of the Liberal Party—and still is—for something like a duration of 40 years. He has served the Liberal Party loyally and well. I say that he deserved better than to be described tonight as treacherous. He has always had the respect of the Labor Party.

BREAK.PARA: Rather than delay the Senate, I just give notice that tomorrow night on the adjournment I not only intend to defend Alan Hunt from the vicious attack made on him tonight by Senator Synon; I also intend to have a close look at Senator Synon's political links in Victoria and how the Kennett government rewarded her not only in terms of employment but in terms of putting her in this place.
